And straight the maiden arose, and went on her feet. For she was of the age of twelve year. And they were astonied at it out of measure.

Mk 5:43
And he charged them straitly that no man should know of it. And commanded to give her meat.

Mk 6:1
And he departed thence, and came into his own country, and his disciples followed him.

Mk 6:2
And when the saboth day was come, he began to teach in the synagogue. And many that heard him were astonied, and said: From whence hath he these things? and what wisdom is this that is given unto him? and such virtues that are wrought by his hands?

Mk 6:3
Is not this that carpenter Mary's son, the brother of Iames, and Ioses and Iuda and Simon? and are not his sisters here with us? And they were hurt by the reason of him.

Mk 6:4
And Iesus said unto them: a prophet is not despised but in his own country, and among his own kin, and among them that are of the same household.

Mk 6:5
And he could there shew no miracles but laid his hands upon a few sick folk and healed them.

Mk 6:6
And he marvelled at their unbelief. And he went about by the towns that lie in circuit, teaching.

Mk 6:7
And he called the twelve, and began to send them, two and two, and gave them power over unclean spirits.

Mk 6:8
And commanded them, that they should take nothing unto their Journey, save a rod only: Neither scrip, neither bread, neither money in their purses:

Mk 6:9
but should be shod with sandals. And that they should not put on two coats.

Mk 6:10
And said unto them: wheresoever ye enter into an house, there abide till ye depart thence.

Mk 6:11
And whosoever shall not receive you, nor hear you, when ye depart thence, shake off the dust that is under your feet, for a remembrance unto them. I say verily unto you, it shallbe easier for Sodom and Gomor, at the day of judgement, than for that city.

Mk 6:12
And they went out and preached, that they should repent:

Mk 6:13
and they cast out many devils. And they anointed, many that were sick with oil and healed them.

Mk 6:14
And king Herode heard of him, for his name was spread abroad, And he said: Ihon Baptist is risen again from death, and therefore miracles are wrought in him.

Mk 6:15
Other said, it is Helias: and some said: it is a prophet, or as one of the prophets.

Mk 6:16
But when Herode heard of him, he said: it is Ihon whom I beheaded, he is risen from death again.

Mk 6:17
For Herode himself, had sent forth, and had taken Ihon, and bound him and cast him into prison for Herodias' sake which was his brother Philip's wife. For he had married her.

Mk 6:18
Ihon said unto Herode: It is not lawful for thee to have thy brother's wife.

Mk 6:19
Herodias laid wait for him, and would have killed him, but she could not.

Mk 6:20
For Herode feared Ihon, knowing that he was just and holy, and gave him reverence, And when he heard him he did many things, and heard him gladly.

Mk 6:21
And when a convenient day was come: Herode on his birthday made a supper to the lords, captains, and chief estates of Galile.

Mk 6:22
And the daughter of the same Herodias came in and danced, and pleased Herode and them that sat at board also. Then the king said unto the maiden: ask of me what thou wilt, and I will give it thee.

Mk 6:23
And he sware unto her, whatsoever thou shalt ask of me, I will give it thee, even unto the one half of my kingdom.

Mk 6:24
And she went forth and said to her mother: what shall I ask? And she said: Ihon baptist's head.

Mk 6:25
And she came in straightway with haste unto the king, and asked saying: I will, that thou give me by and by in a charger the head of Ihon baptist.

Mk 6:26
And the king was sorry yet for his oath's sake, and for their sakes which sat at supper also, he would not put her beside her purpose.

Mk 6:27
And immediately the king sent the hangman and commanded his head to be brought in.

Mk 6:28
And he went and beheaded him in the prison, and brought his head in a charger and gave it to the maiden, and the maiden gave it to her mother.

Mk 6:29
When his disciples heard of it, they came and took up his body, and put it in a tomb.

Mk 6:30
And the apostles gathered themselves together to Iesus, and told him all things, both what they had done, and what they had taught.

Mk 6:31
And he said unto them: come ye apart into the wilderness, and rest awhile. For there were many comers and goers. And they had no leisure wos for to eat.

Mk 6:32
And he went by ship aside out of the way into a desert place.

Mk 6:33
And the people spied them when they departed: and many knew him, and they hasted afoot thither out of every city, and came thither before them, And came together unto him.

Mk 6:34
And Iesus went out and saw much people, and had compassion on them, because they were like sheep which had no shepherd. And he began to teach them many things.

Mk 6:35
And when the day was now far spent, his disciples came unto him saying: this is a desert place, and now the day is far passed,

Mk 6:36
let them depart, that they may go into the country round about, and into the towns, and buy them bread: for they have nothing to eat.

Mk 6:37
He answered and said unto them: give ye them to eat. And they said unto him: shall we go and buy ij.C. pennyworth of bread, and give them to eat?

Mk 6:38
He said unto them: how many loaves have ye? Go and look. And when they had searched, they said: v. and ij. fishes.

Mk 6:39
And he commanded them to make them all sit down, by companies upon the green grass.

Mk 6:40
And they sat down here a row and there a row, by hundreds and by fifties.

Mk 6:41
And he took the v. loaves and the ij. fishes And looked up to heaven and blest, and brake the loaves, and gave them to his disciples to put before them, and the ij. fishes he divided among them all.

Mk 6:42
And they all ate, and were satisfied.

Mk 6:43
And they took up twelve baskets full of the gobbets and of the fishes.

Mk 6:44
And they that ate were about five thousand men.

Mk 6:45
And straightway he caused his disciples to go into the ship, and to go over the water before unto Bethsaida, while he sent away the people.

Mk 6:46
And as soon as he had sent them away, he departed into a mountain to pray.

Mk 6:47
And when even was come the ship was in the midst of the sea, and he alone on the land,

Mk 6:48
and he saw them troubled in rowing, for the wind was contrary unto them. And about the fourth quarter of the night, he came unto them, walking upon the sea, and would have passed by them.

Mk 6:49
When they saw him walking upon the sea, they supposed it had been a spirit, and cried out:

Mk 6:50
For they all saw him, and were afraid. And anon he talked with them, and said unto them: be of good cheer, it is I, be not afraid.

Mk 6:51
And he went up unto them into the ship, and the wind ceased, and they were sore amazed in themselves beyond measure, and marvelled.

Mk 6:52
For they remembered not of the loaves, because their hearts were blinded.

Mk 6:53
And they came over, and went into the land of Genazareth, and drew up into the haven.

Mk 6:54
And as soon as they were come out of the ship, straight they knew him,

Mk 6:55
and ran forth throughout all the region round a about, and began to carry about in beds all that were sick, when they heard tell that he was there.

Mk 6:56
And whithersoever he entered into the towns, or cities, or villages, they laid their sick in the streets, and prayed him, that they might touch and it were but the edge of his vesture. And as many as touched him were safe.

Mk 7:1
And the pharises came together unto him, and divers of the scribes which came from Ierusalem.

Mk 7:2
And when they saw certain of his disciples eat bread with common hands (that is to say, with unwashen hands) they complained.

Mk 7:3
For the pharises, and all the jews, except they wash their hands often, eat not, observing the traditions of the seniors.

Mk 7:4
And when they come from the market, except they wash themselves they eat not. And many other things there be, which they have taken upon them to observe, as the washing of cups and cruses, and of brazen vessels, and of tables.

Mk 7:5
Then asked him the pharises and scribes: why walk not thy disciples according to the traditions of the seniors, but eat bread with unwashen hands?

Mk 7:6
He answered and said unto them: well prophesied hath Esaias of you hypocrites as it is written: This people honoureth me with their lips, but their heart is far from me:

Mk 7:7
In vain they worship me, teaching doctrines which are nothing but the commandments of men,

Mk 7:8
for ye lay the commandment of God apart, and ye observe the traditions of men as the washing of cruses and of cups, and many other such like things ye do.

Mk 7:9
And he said unto them: well, ye put away the commandment of God, to maintain your own traditions.

Mk 7:10
For Moses said: Honour thy father and thy mother: and whosoever saith evil of his father or mother, let him die for it.

Mk 7:11
But ye say: a man shall say to his father or mother Corban, that is, whatsoever thing I offer, that same doeth profit thee.

Mk 7:12
And ye suffer no more that a man do anything for his father or mother,

Mk 7:13
and thus have ye made the commandment of God of none effect through your own traditions which ye have ordained. And many such things ye do.

Mk 7:14
And he called all the people unto him, and said unto them: Hearken unto me every one of you and understand:

Mk 7:15
There is nothing with out a man that can defile him when it entereth into him, but those things which proceed out of him are those which defile a man.

Mk 7:16
If any man have ears to hear, let him hear.

Mk 7:17
And when he came into a house away from the people, his disciples asked him of the similitude,

Mk 7:18
and he said unto them: Do ye than lack understanding: Do ye not yet perceive, that whatsoever thing from without entereth into a man, it cannot defile him,

Mk 7:19
because it entereth not into his heart, but into the belly: and goeth out into the draught that purgeth out all meats.

Mk 7:20
And he said that defileth a man which cometh out of a man.

Mk 7:21
For from within even out of the heart of men, proceed evil thoughts: advoutry, fornication, murder,

Mk 7:22
theft, covetousness, wickedness, deceit, uncleanness, and a wicked eye, blasphemy, pride, foolishness:

Mk 7:23
All these evil things, come from within, and defile a man.

Mk 7:24
And from thence he rose and went into the borders of Tyre and Sidon, and entered into an house, and would that no man should have known of him: But he could not be hid.

Mk 7:25
For a certain woman whose daughter had a foul spirit when she heard of him, came and fell down at his feet.

Mk 7:26
The woman was a greek out of sirophenicia, and she besought him that he would cast out the devil out of her daughter.

Mk 7:27
Iesus said unto her: let the children first be fed. It is not meet, to take the children's bread, and to cast it unto whelps.

Mk 7:28
She answered and said unto him: even so Master, nevertheless, the whelps also eat under the table of the children's crumbs.

Mk 7:29
And he said unto her: for this saying go thy way, the devil is gone out of thy daughter.

Mk 7:30
And when she was come home to her house she found the devil departed, and her daughter lying on the bed.

Mk 7:31
And he departed again from the coasts of Tyre and Sidon, and came unto the sea of Galile throwe the midst of the coasts of the x. cities.

Mk 7:32
And they brought unto him one that was deaf, and stammered in his speech, and prayed him to lay his hand upon him.

Mk 7:33
And he took him aside from the people, and put his fingers in his ears, and did spit, and touched his tongue,

Mk 7:34
and looked up to heaven and sighted, and said unto him: ephatha that is to say, be opened.

Mk 7:35
And straightway his ears were opened, and the string of his tongue was loosed, and he spake plain.

Mk 7:36
And he commanded them that they should tell no man. But the more he forbade them, so much the more a great deal they published it.

Mk 7:37
And were beyond measure astonied, saying: He hath done all things well, and hath made both the deaf to hear and the dumb to speak.

Mk 8:1
In those days when there was a very great company, and had nothing to eat, Iesus called his disciples to him and said unto them:

Mk 8:2
My heart melteth on this people, because they have now been with me iij. days, and have nothing to eat:

Mk 8:3
And if I should send them away fasting to their own houses, they should faint by the way. For divers of them came from far.

Mk 8:4
And his disciples answered him: from whence might a man suffice them with bread here in the wilderness?

Mk 8:5
And he asked them: how many loaves have ye? They said: seven.

Mk 8:6
And he commanded the people to sit down on the ground. And he took the vij. loaves, gave thanks, brake, and gave to his disciples, to set before them. And they set them before the people.

Mk 8:7
And they had a few small fishes. And he blessed them and commanded them also to be set before them.

Mk 8:8
They ate and were sufficed, and they took up of the broken meat that was left, vij. baskets full.

Mk 8:9
They that ate were in number about four thousand. And he sent them away.

Mk 8:10
And anon he took ship with his disciples, and came into the parts of Dalmanutha.

Mk 8:11
And the pharises came forth, and began to dispute with him, and sought of him a sign from heaven tempting him,

Mk 8:12
and he sighed in his spirit and said: why doth this generation seek a sign? Verily I say unto you, there shall no sign be given unto this generation.

Mk 8:13
And he left them and went into the ship again, and departed over the water.

Mk 8:14
And they had forgotten to take bread with them, neither had they in the ship with them more than one loaf.

Mk 8:15
And he charged them saying: take heed, beware of the leaven of the pharises, and of the leaven of Herode.

Mk 8:16
And they reasoned among themselves saying: we have no bread.

Mk 8:17
And when Iesus knew that he said unto them: why take ye thought because ye have no bread? perceive ye not yet, neither understand? Have ye your hearts yet blinded?

Mk 8:18
Have ye eyes and see not? and have ye ears and hear not? Do ye not remember?

Mk 8:19
When I v. five loaves among v.M. men: How many baskets full of broken meat took ye up? They said unto him, xij.

Mk 8:20
When I brake .vij. among .iiij. M. how many baskets of the leavings of broken meat took ye up? They said, .vij.

Mk 8:21
And he said unto them: how is it that ye understand not?

Mk 8:22
And he came to Bethsaida, and they brought a blind man unto him and desired him, to touch him.

Mk 8:23
And he caught the blind by the hand, and led him out of the town, and spat in his eyes and put his hands upon him, and asked him if he saw anything,

Mk 8:24
and he looked up and said: I see men, For I see them walk as they were trees.

Mk 8:25
After that he put his hands again upon his eyes, and made him see. And he was restored to his sight, and saw every man clearly.

Mk 8:26
And he sent him home to his own house saying: neither go into the town, nor tell it any in the town.

Mk 8:27
And Iesus went out and his disciples into the towns that long to the city called Cesarea Philippi, and by the way he asked his disciples saying: whom do men say that I am?

Mk 8:28
They answered: some say that thou art Ihon Baptist: some say Helias, and some one of the prophets.

Mk 8:29
And he said unto them: But whom say ye that I am? Peter answered and said unto him: Thou art very Christ.

Mk 8:30
And he charged them, that they should tell no man of it.

Mk 8:31
And he began to declare unto them, how that the son of man must suffer many things, and should be reproved of the seniors and of the high priests and scribes, and should be killed, and after three days arise again.

Mk 8:32
And he spake that saying openly. And Peter took him aside, and began to chide him.

Mk 8:33
He turned about, and looked on his disciples, and rebuked Peter saying: Go after me Satan. For thou savourest not the things of God but the things of men.

Mk 8:34
And he called the people unto him, with his disciples also, and said unto them. Whosoever will follow me, let him forsake himself, and take up his cross, and follow me.

Mk 8:35
For whosoever will save his life, shall lose it. But whosoever shall lose his life for my sake and the gospel's, the same shall save it.

Mk 8:36
What shall it profit a man, if he should win all the world and lose his own soul?

Mk 8:37
or else what shall a man give, to redeem his soul again?

Mk 8:38
Whosoever therefore shall be ashamed of me and of my words, among this advoutrous and sinful generation: of him shall the son of man be ashamed, when he cometh in the glory of his father with the holy angels.

Mk 9:1
And he said unto them: Verily I say unto you: There be some of them that stand here, which shall not taste of death, till they have seen the kingdom of God come with power.

Mk 9:2
And after vj. days Iesus took Peter, Iames, and Ihon and led them up into an high mountain out of the way alone, and he was transfigured before them.

Mk 9:3
And his raiment did shine, and was made very white, even as snow: so white as no fuller can make upon the earth.

Mk 9:4
And there appeared unto them Helias with Moses: and they talked with Iesu.

Mk 9:5
And Peter answered and said to Iesu: Master, here is good being for us, let us make iij. tabernacles, one for thee, one for Moses, and one for Helias.

Mk 9:6
And wist not what he said. For they were afraid.

Mk 9:7
And there was a cloud that shadowed them. And a voice came out of the cloud saying: This is my dear son, hear him.

Mk 9:8
And suddenly, they looked round about them, and saw no man more, but Iesus only.

Mk 9:9
As they came down from the hill, he charged them, that they should tell no man what they had seen, till the son of man were risen from death again.

Mk 9:10
And they kept that saying within them, and demanded one of another, what that rising from death again should mean?

Mk 9:11
And they asked him saying: why then Say the scribes, that Helias must first come?

Mk 9:12
He answered and said unto them: Helias at his first coming, shall bring all things again into good order: And even so is it written of the son of man, that he shall suffer many things, and shall be set at nought.

Mk 9:13
And I say unto you, that Helias is come, and they have done unto him whatsoever pleased them, as it is written of him.

Mk 9:14
And he came to his disciples, and saw much people about them, and the scribes disputing with them.

Mk 9:15
And straightway all the people beheld him and were amazed, and ran to him, and saluted him.

Mk 9:16
And he said unto the scribes: What dispute ye with them?

Mk 9:17
And one of the company answered and said: Master I have brought my son unto thee, which hath a dumb spirit.

Mk 9:18
And whensoever he taketh him, he teareth him, and he foameth, and gnasheth with his teeth, and pineth away. And I spake to thy disciples that they should cast him out, and they could not.

Mk 9:19
He answered him and said: O generation without faith, how long shall I be with you. How long shall I suffer you? bring him unto me.

Mk 9:20
And they brought him unto him. And as soon as the spirit saw him, he tare him. And he fell down on the ground wallowing: And foaming.

Mk 9:21
And he asked his father: how long is it ago, since this hath happened him? And he said, of a child.

Mk 9:22
And often times casteth him into the fire, and also into the water, to destroy him. But if thou canst do anything, have mercy on us, and help us.

Mk 9:23
Iesus said unto him: yea if thou couldest believe, all things are possible to him that believeth.

Mk 9:24
And straight way the father of the child cried with tears saying: Lord I believe, succor mine unbelief.

Mk 9:25
When Iesus saw that the people came running together unto him, he rebuked the foul spirit, saying unto him: Thou dumb and deaf spirit, I charge thee come out of him, and enter no more into him.

Mk 9:26
And the spirit cried, and rent him sore and came out: And he was as one that had been dead, insomuch that many said, he is dead.

Mk 9:27
But Iesus caught his hand, and lift him up, and he rose.

Mk 9:28
And when he was come into the house, his disciples asked him secretly: why could not we cast him out?

Mk 9:29
And he said unto them: this kind can by no other means come forth, but by prayer and fasting.

Mk 9:30
And they departed thence, and took their journey thorow Galile, and would not, that any man should have known it.

Mk 9:31
For he taught his disciples, and said unto them: The son of man shall be delivered into the hands of men, and they shall kill him, and after that he is killed he shall arise again the third day.

Mk 9:32
But they wist not what that saying meant, and were afraid to ask him.

Mk 9:33
And he came to Capernaum, and when he was come to house, he said to them: what was it that ye disputed between you by the way?

Mk 9:34
And they held their peace (for by the way they reasoned among themselves, who should be the chiefest)

Mk 9:35
And he sat down, and called the twelve unto him, and said to them: if any man desire to be first, the same shallbe last of all, and servant unto all.

Mk 9:36
And he took a child, and set him in the midst of them, and took him in his arms and said unto them:

Mk 9:37
Whosoever receive any such a child in my name, receiveth me:

Mk 9:38
And whosoever receiveth me, receiveth not me, but him that sent me. Ihon answered him, saying: Master, we saw one casting out devils in thy name, which followeth not us and we forbade him, because he followeth us not.

Mk 9:39
But Iesus said: forbid him not. For there is no man that shall do a miracle in my name, and can speak lightly evil of me.

Mk 9:40
Whosoever is not against you, is on your part.

Mk 9:41
And whosoever shall give you a cup of water to drink for my name's sake because ye are belonging to Christe, verily I say unto you, he shall not lose his reward.

Mk 9:42
And whosoever shall hurt one of these little ones, that believe in me, it were better for him, that a millstone were hanged about his neck, and that he were cast into the sea.

Mk 9:43
And if thy hand offend thee, cut him off. It is better for thee, to enter into life maimed, then to go, with two hands into hell, into fire that never shall be quenched,

Mk 9:44
where their worm dieth not, and the fire never goeth out.

Mk 9:45
And if thy foot offend thee, cut him off. It is better for thee to go halt into life, than with ij. feet to be cast into hell, into fire that never shall be quenched:

Mk 9:46
where their worm dieth not, and the fire never goeth out?

Mk 9:47
And if thine eye offend thee pluck him out. It is better for thee to go into the kingdom of God with one eye, than having two eyes to be cast into hell fire:

Mk 9:48
where their worm dieth not, and the fire never goeth out.

Mk 9:49
Every man therefore shall be salted with fire: And every sacrifice shall be seasoned with salt.

Mk 9:50
Salt is good. But if the salt be unsavoury: what shall ye salt therewith? See that ye have salt in yourselves. And have peace among yourselves, one with another.

Mk 10:1
And he rose from thence, and went into the coasts of Jewry through the region that is beyond Iordan. And the people resorted unto him afresh: And as he was wont he taught them again.

Mk 10:2
And the pharyses came and asked him a question: whether it were lawful for a man to put away his wife: To prove him.

Mk 10:3
He answered and said unto them: what did Moses bid you do?

Mk 10:4
And they said: Moses suffered to write a testimonial of her divorcement, and to put her away.

Mk 10:5
And Iesus answered, and said unto them: For because of your hard hearts he wrote this precept unto you.

Mk 10:6
But at the first creation, God made them man and woman, saying:

Mk 10:7
For this thing's sake shall man leave father and mother, and bide by his wife,

Mk 10:8
and, ij. shall be made one flesh. So then are they now not twain, but one flesh,

Mk 10:9
therefore that which God hath coupled, let not man separate.

Mk 10:10
And in the house his disciples asked him again of that matter.

Mk 10:11
And he said unto them: Whosoever putteth away his wife, and marrieth another, breaketh wedlock to herward.

Mk 10:12
And if a woman forsake her husband, and be married to another, she committeth advoutry.

Mk 10:13
And they brought children to him that he should touch them. And his disciples chid those that brought them.

Mk 10:14
When Iesus saw that, he was displeased, and said to them: Suffer the children to come unto me and forbid them not. For unto such belongeth the kingdom of God.

Mk 10:15
Verily I say to you, whosoever shall not receive the kingdom of God as a child, he shall not enter therin.

Mk 10:16
And he took them up in his arms, and put his hands upon them, and blessed them.

Mk 10:17
And when he was come out into the way, there came one running and kneeled to him, and asked him: Good Master, what shall I do, that I may inherit eternal life?

Mk 10:18
Iesus said to him: why callest thou me good? there is no man good but one, which is God.

Mk 10:19
Thou knowest the commandments: break not matrimony, kill not, steal not, bear no false witness, defraud no man, honour thy father and thy mother.

Mk 10:20
He answered and said to him: master, all these I have observed from my youth.

Mk 10:21
Iesus beheld him, and had a favour to him, and said unto him: One thing is lacking unto thee Go, and sell all that thou hast, and give it to the poor, and thou shalt have treasure in heaven, and come and follow me, and take thy cross on thee.

Mk 10:22
But he was discomforted with that saying, and went away mourning, for he had great possessions.

Mk 10:23
And Iesus looked round about, and said unto his disciples: with what difficulty shall they that have riches enter into the kingdom of God.

Mk 10:24
His disciples were astonied at his words. Iesus answered again, and said unto them: children, how hard is it for them, that trust in their riches, to enter into the kingdom of God?

Mk 10:25
It is easier for a camel to go thorow the eye of an needle, than for a rich man to enter into the kingdom of God.

Mk 10:26
And they were astonied out of measure, saying between themselves: who then can be saved?

Mk 10:27
Iesus looked upon them, and said: with men it is unpossible, but not with God: for with God all things are possible.

Mk 10:28
And Peter began to say unto him: Lo, we have forsaken all, and have followed thee.

Mk 10:29
Iesus answered and said: Verily I say unto you, there is no man that hath forsaketh house, or brethren, or sisters, or father, or mother, or wife, other children, or lands, for my sake and the gospel's,

Mk 10:30
which shall not receive an hundred fold now in this life, houses, and brethren, and sisters, and mothers and children, and lands with persecutions, and in the world to come eternal life.

Mk 10:31
Many that are first, shall be last. And the last first.

Mk 10:32
They were in the way going up to Ierusalem. And Iesus went before them, and they were amazed, and as they followed, were afraid. And Iesus took the xij. again, and began to tell them what things should happen unto him.

Mk 10:33
Behold we go up to Ierusalem, and the son of man shall be delivered unto the high priests and unto the scribes: and they shall condemn him to death, and shall deliver him to the gentiles,

Mk 10:34
and they shall mock him, and scourge him and spit upon him, and kill him, and the third day he shall rise again.

Mk 10:35
And Iames and Ihon the sons of Zebedee, came unto him, saying: Master, we would that thou shouldest do for us whatsoever we desire.

Mk 10:36
He said unto them: what would ye I should do unto you?

Mk 10:37
They said to him: grant unto us that we may sit one on thy right hand, and the other on thy left hand, in thy glory.

Mk 10:38
But Iesus said unto them: Ye wot not what ye ask. Can ye drink of the cup, that I shall drink of? And be baptised in the baptism that I shall be baptised in?

Mk 10:39
And they said unto him: that we can. Iesus said unto them: ye shall drink of the cup that I shall drink of, and be baptised with the baptism that I shall be baptised in:

Mk 10:40
But to sit on my right hand and on my left hand, is not mine to give, but to them for whom it is prepared.

Mk 10:41
And when the x. heard that, they began to disdain at Iames and Ihon.

Mk 10:42
But Iesus called them unto him, and said to them: Ye know well that they which seem to bear rule among the gentiles, reign as lords over them. And they that be great among them exercise authority over them.

Mk 10:43
So shall it not be among you but whosoever of you will be great among you shall be your minister.

Mk 10:44
And whosoever will be chief, shall be servant unto all.

Mk 10:45
For even the son of man came, not that other should minister unto him: but to minister, and to give his life for the redemption of many.

Mk 10:46
And they came to Hiericho, and as he went out of Hiericho, with his disciples and a great number of people: Barthimeus the son of Thimeus which was blind, sat by the highways side begging.

Mk 10:47
And when he heard that it was Iesus of Nazareth, he began to cry and to say: Iesus the son of David, have mercy on me.

Mk 10:48
And many rebuked him, because he should hold his peace. But he cried the more a great deal, thou son of David have mercy on me.

Mk 10:49
And Iesus stood still, and commanded him to be called, and they called the blind, saying unto him: Be of good comfort, rise, he called thee.

Mk 10:50
He threw away his cloak, and rose and came to Iesus:

Mk 10:51
And Iesus answered, and said unto him: what wilt thou that I do unto thee? The blind said unto him: Master, that I might see.

Mk 10:52
Iesus said unto him: go thy way, thy faith hath saved thee: And by and by he received his sight, and followed Iesus in the way.

Mk 11:1
And when they came nye to Hierusalem, unto Bethphage, and Bethani, besides mount Olivete, he sent forth ij. of his disciples,

Mk 11:2
and said unto them: Go your ways into the town that is over against you. And as soon as ye enter into it ye shall find a colt bound, whereon never man sat: loose him and bring him hidder.

Mk 11:3
And if any man say unto you: why do ye so? say that the Lord hath need of him: and straightway he will send him hither.

Mk 11:4
And they went their way, and found a colt tied by the door without in a place where two ways met, and they loosed him.

Mk 11:5
And divers of them that stood there, said unto them: what do ye loosing the colt?

Mk 11:6
And they said unto them even as Iesus had commanded them. And they let them go.

Mk 11:7
And they brought the colt to Iesus, and cast their garments on him, and he sat upon him.

Mk 11:8
And many spread their garments in the way. Other cut down branches of the trees, and strawed them in the way.

Mk 11:9
And they that went before and they that followed, cried, saying: Hosianna: blessed be he that cometh in the name of the Lord.

Mk 11:10
Blessed be the kingdom that cometh in the name of him that is Lord of our father David. Hosianna in the highest.

Mk 11:11
And the Lord entered into Hierusalem, and into the temple. And when he had looked round about upon all things, and now the eventide was come he went out unto Bethany with the twelve.

Mk 11:12
And on the morrow when they were come out from Bethany, he hungered,

Mk 11:13
and he spied a fig tree afar off, having leaves, and went to see whether he might find anything thereon: but when he came thereto, he found nothing but leaves. For the time of figs was not yet.

Mk 11:14
And Iesus answered and said to it: never man eat fruit of thee hereafter while the world standeth. And his disciples heard it.

Mk 11:15
And they came to Hierusalem, and Iesus went into the temple, and began to cast out them which sold and bought in the temple. And overthrew the tables of the money changers, and the stools of them that sold doves:

Mk 11:16
and would not suffer that any man carried a vessel thorow the temple.

Mk 11:17
And he taught saying unto them, is it not written, how that mine house shall be called the house of prayer unto all nations? But ye have made it a den of thieves.

Mk 11:18
And the scribes and high priests heard it and sought how to destroy him. For they feared him because all the people marvelled at his doctrine.

Mk 11:19
And when even was come, he went out of the city.

Mk 11:20
And in the morning as they passed by, they saw the fig tree dried up by the roots.

Mk 11:21
And Peter remembered, and said unto him: master, behold, the fig tree which thou cursedst, is withered away.

Mk 11:22
And Iesus answered, and said unto them: Have confidence in God.

Mk 11:23
Verily I say unto you, that whosoever shall say unto this mountain: take away thyself, and cast thyself into the sea, and shall not waver in his heart, but shall believe that those things which he sayeth shall come to pass, whatsoever he sayeth shall be done to him.

Mk 11:24
Therefore I say unto you, whatsoever ye desire when ye pray, believe that ye shall have it and it shall be done unto you.

Mk 11:25
And when ye stand and pray, forgive if ye have anything against any man: that your father also which is in heaven, may forgive you your trespasses.

Mk 11:26
But if you do not forgive: neither will your father, which is in heaven, forgive you your trespasses.

Mk 11:27
And they came again to Hierusalem, and as he walked in the temple, there came to him the high priests, and the scribes, and the seniors,

Mk 11:28
and said unto him: by what authority doest thou these things? and who gave thee this authority, to do these things?

Mk 11:29
Iesus answered, and said unto them: I will also ask of you a certain thing, and answer ye me, and I will tell you by what authority I do these things.

Mk 11:30
Whether was the baptism of Ihon from heaven, or of men? Answer me.

Mk 11:31
And they thought in themselves, saying: if we shall say, from heaven, he will say: why then did ye not believe him?

Mk 11:32
but if we shall say, of men, then fear we the people. For all men counted Ihon, that he was a very prophet.

Mk 11:33
And they answered, and said unto Iesu: we cannot tell. And Iesus answered, and said unto them: neither will I tell you, by what authority I do these things.

Mk 12:1
And he began to speak unto them in similitudes. A certain man planted a vineyard, and compassed it with an hedge, and ordained a winepress, and built a tower in it, and let it out to hire unto husbandmen, and went into a strange country.

Mk 12:2
And when the time was come he sent to the tenants a servant that he might receive of the tenants of the fruit of the vineyard.

Mk 12:3
And they caught him and beat him and sent him again empty.

Mk 12:4
And moreover he sent unto them another servant, and at him they cast stones and brake his head, and sent him again all too reviled.

Mk 12:5
And again he sent another, and him they killed: and many other, beating some, and killing some.

Mk 12:6
Yet had he one son whom he loved tenderly, him also sent he at the last unto them, saying: they will fear my son.

Mk 12:7
But the tenants said within themselves: This is the heir, come let us kill him and the inheritance shall be ours.

Mk 12:8
And they took him and killed him, and cast him out of the vineyard.

Mk 12:9
What shall then the lord of the vineyard do? He will come and destroy the tenants, and let out the vineyard to other.

Mk 12:10
Have ye not read this scripture? the stone which the builders did refuse, is made the chief stone in the corner:

Mk 12:11
This was done of the Lord, and is marvellous in our eyes.

Mk 12:12
And they went about to take him, but they feared the people. For they perceived that he spake that similitude against them. And they left him and went their way.

Mk 12:13
And they sent unto him certain of the pharises with Herode's servants, to take him in his words.

Mk 12:14
And as soon as they were come, they said unto him: master, we know that thou art true, and carest for no man: For thou considerest not the degree of men, but teachest the way of God truly: Is it lawful to pay tribute to Cesar, or not?

Mk 12:15
ought we to give, or ought we not to give? He knew their dissimulation, and said unto them: Why tempt ye me? Bring me a penny, that I may see it.

Mk 12:16
And they brought him one. And he said unto them: Whose is this image and superscription? And they said unto him, Cesar's.

Mk 12:17
And Iesus answered, and said unto them: Then give to Cesar that which belongeth to Cesar: and give God that which pertaineth to God. And they marvelled at him.

Mk 12:18
And the saduces came unto him, which say, there is no resurrection. And they asked him saying:

Mk 12:19
Master, Moses wrote unto us, if any man's brother die, and leave his wife, behind him, and leave no children: that then his brother should take his wife, and raise up seed unto his brother.

Mk 12:20
There were seven brethren and the first took a wife, and when he died left no seed behind him.

Mk 12:21
And the second took her, and died: neither left he any seed, and the third likewise.

Mk 12:22
And seven had her, and left no seed behind them. Last of all the wife died also.

Mk 12:23
In the resurrection then, when they shall rise again: whose wife shall she be of them? For seven had her to wife.

Mk 12:24
Iesus answered, and said unto them: Are ye not therefore deceived because ye know not the scriptures? Neither the power of God?

Mk 12:25
For when they shall rise again from death, they neither marry, nor are married: but are as the angels which are in heaven.

Mk 12:26
As touching the dead, that they shall rise again: have ye not read in the book of Moses, how in the bush God spake unto him saying: I am the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Iacob?

Mk 12:27
He is not the God of the dead, but the God of the living, ye are therefore greatly deceived.

Mk 12:28
And there came one of the scribes, and when he had heard them disputing together, and perceived that he had answered them well, he asked him: Which is the first of all the commandments?

Mk 12:29
Iesus answered him: the first of all the commandments is. Hear Israhel, our Lord God, is one Lord.

Mk 12:30
And thou shalt love thy Lord God with all thy heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy mind, and with all thy strength. This is the first commandment.

Mk 12:31
And the second is like unto this. Thou shalt love thy neighbor, as thy self. There is none other commandment greater than these.

Mk 12:32
And the scribe said unto him: well master, thou hast said the truth, that there is one God, and that there is none but he.

Mk 12:33
And to love him with all the heart, and with all the mind, and with all the soul, and with all the strength. And to love a man's neighbor as himself, is a greater thing than all holocausts and sacrifices.

Mk 12:34
And when Iesus saw that he answered discreetly, he said unto him: Thou art not far from the kingdom of God. And no man after that durst ask him any question.

Mk 12:35
And Iesus answered, and said teaching in the temple: how say the scribes, that Christ is the son of David?

Mk 12:36
for David himself inspired with the holy ghost said: The Lord said to my Lord, sit on my right hand till I make thine enemies thy foot stool.

Mk 12:37
Then David himself calleth him Lord, and by what means is he then his son? And much people heard him gladly.

Mk 12:38
And he said unto them in his doctrine: beware of the scribes which love to go in long, clothing: and love salutations in the market places,

Mk 12:39
and the chief seats in the synagogues, and to sit in the uppermost rooms at feasts,

Mk 12:40
and devour widows' houses, and under a colour pray long prayers. These shall have greater damnation.

Mk 12:41
And Iesus sat over against the treasury, and beheld how the people put money into the treasury. And many that were rich, cast in much.

Mk 12:42
And there came a certain poor widow, and she threw in two mites, which make a farthing.

Mk 12:43
And he called unto him his disciples, and said unto them: Verily I say unto you, that this poor widow hath cast more in, than all they which have cast into the treasury.

Mk 12:44
For they all put in of their superfluity: But she of her poverty, cast in all that she had, even all her living.

Mk 13:1
And as he went out of the temple, one of his disciples said unto him: Master, see what stones, and what buildings are here.

Mk 13:2
And Iesus answered, and said unto him: Seest thou these great buildings? There shall not be left one stone upon another, that shall not be thrown down.

Mk 13:3
And as he sat on mount Olivet over against the temple, Peter and Iames and Ihon and Andrew asked him secretly,

Mk 13:4
tell us when these things shall be? And what is the sign, when all these things shall be fulfilled?

Mk 13:5
And Iesus answered them, and began to say: take heed lest any man deceive you.

Mk 13:6
For many shall come in my name saying: I am Christ, and shall deceive many.

Mk 13:7
When ye shall hear of war, and tidings of war, be ye not troubled. For such things must needs be. But the end is not yet.

Mk 13:8
For there shall nation arise against nation, and realm against realm. And there shall be earthquakes, in all quarters, and famishment, and troubles. These are the beginning of sorrows.

Mk 13:9
But take ye heed to yourselves. For they shall bring you up to the councils and into the synagogues, and ye shall be beaten, and ye shall be brought before rulers and kings, for my sake, for a testimonial unto them.

Mk 13:10
And the gospel must first be published among all nations.

Mk 13:11
But when they lead you and present you take no thought, aforehand what ye shall say, neither imagine: but whatsoever is given you at the same time, that speak. For it shall not be ye that shall speak, but the holy ghost.

Mk 13:12
Yea and the brother shall deliver the brother to death. And the father the son, and the children shall rise against their fathers and mothers, and shall put them to death.

Mk 13:13
And ye shall be hated of all men for my name's sake. But whosoever shall endure unto the end shall be safe.

Mk 13:14
Moreover when ye see the abominable desolation, whereof is spoken by Daniel the prophet, stand where it ought not, let him that readeth understand it. Then let them that be in jewrie, flee to the mountains.

Mk 13:15
And let him that is on the housetop, not descend down into the house, neither enter therein, to fetch anything out of his house.

Mk 13:16
And let him that is in the field, not turn back again unto those things which he left behind him, for to take his clothes with him.

Mk 13:17
But woe is then to them that are with child, and to them that give suck in those days.

Mk 13:18
But pray, that your flight be not in the winter.

Mk 13:19
For there shall be in those days such tribulation, as was not from the beginning of creatures, which God created, unto this time, neither shall be.

Mk 13:20
And except that the Lord had shortened those days, no man should be saved. But for the elects' sake, which he hath chosen, he hath shortened those days.

Mk 13:21
And then, if any man say to you: lo, here is Christ, lo, he is there, believe not.

Mk 13:22
For false christs shall arise, and false prophets, And shall shew miracles and wonders, to deceive if it were possible, even the elect.

Mk 13:23
But take ye heed, behold I have shewed you all things before.

Mk 13:24
Moreover in those days after that tribulation, the sun shall wax dark, and the moon shall not give her light,

Mk 13:25
and the stars of heaven shall fall, And the powers which are in heaven, shall move.

Mk 13:26
And then shall they see the son of man coming in the clouds, with great power and glory.

Mk 13:27
And then shall he send his angels, and shall gather together his elect from the four winds, and from the one end of the world to the other.

Mk 13:28
Learn a similitude of the fig tree. When his branches are yet tender, and hath brought forth leaves, ye know, that summer is near.

Mk 13:29
So in like manner when ye see these things come to pass, understand, that it is nye even at the doors.

Mk 13:30
Verily I say unto you, that this generation shall not pass till all these things be done.

Mk 13:31
Heaven and earth shall pass, but my words shall not pass.

Mk 13:32
But of the day and the hour, knoweth no man: no not the angels which are in heaven: neither the son himself, save the father only.

Mk 13:33
Take heed, watch, and pray, for ye know not when the time is.

Mk 13:34
As a man which is gone into a strange country and hath left his house, and given authority to his servants, and to every man his work, and commanded the porter to watch.

Mk 13:35
Watch therefore, for ye know not when the master of the house will come, whether at even, or at midnight, whether at the cock crowing, or in the dawning:

Mk 13:36
lest if he come suddenly, he should find you sleeping.

Mk 13:37
And that I say unto you, I say unto all men, watch.

Mk 14:1
After two days followed ester, and the days of sweet bread. And the high priests and the scribes sought means, how they might take him by craft and put him to death.

Mk 14:2
But they said: not on the feast day, least any business arise among the people.

Mk 14:3
When he was in Bethania, in the house of Simon the leper, even as he sat at meat, there came a woman having an alabaster box of ointment, called nard, that was pure and costly, and she brake the box and poured it on his head.

Mk 14:4
And there were some that disdained in themselves, and said: what needed this waste of ointment?

Mk 14:5
For it might have been sold for more then two hundred pence, and been given unto the poor. And they grudged against her.

Mk 14:6
And Iesus said: let her be in rest, why grieve ye her? She hath done a good work on me.

Mk 14:7
Yea, and ye shall have poor with you allways: and whensoever ye will ye may do them good: but me ye shall not have always.

Mk 14:8
She hath done that she could: she came aforehand to anoint my body to his buryingward.

Mk 14:9
Verily I say unto you: wheresoever this gospel shall be preached thorowout the whole world: this also that she hath done, shall be rehearsed in remembrance of her.

Mk 14:10
And Iudas Iscariot, one of the twelve, went away unto the high priests, to betray him unto them.

Mk 14:11
When they heard that, they were glad, and promised that they would give him money. And he sought, how he might conveniently betray him.

Mk 14:12
And the first day of sweet bread, when men offer the paschal lamb, his disciples said unto him: where wilt thou that we go and prepare that thou mayest eat the ester lamb?

Mk 14:13
And he sent forth two of his disciples, and said unto them: Go ye into the city, and there shall a man meet you bearing a pitcher of water, follow him.

Mk 14:14
And whithersoever he goeth in, say ye to the good man of the house: the master asketh where is the guest chamber, where I shall eat the ester lamb with my disciples?

Mk 14:15
And he will shew you a great parlour, paved, and prepared: there make ready for us.

Mk 14:16
And his disciples went forth, and came in to the city, and found as he had said unto them, and made ready the ester lamb.

Mk 14:17
And at even, he came with the twelve.

Mk 14:18
And as they sat at board and ate, Iesus said: Verily I say unto you: that one of you shall betray me, which eateth with me.

Mk 14:19
And they began to mourn, and to say to him one by one: is it I? And another said: Is it I?

Mk 14:20
he answered, and said unto them: It is one of the xij. and the same dippeth with me in the platter.

Mk 14:21
The son of man goeth, as it is written of him: but woe be to that man, by whom the son of man is betrayed. Good were it for him, if that man had never been born.

Mk 14:22
And as they ate, Iesus took bread, gave thanks, brake it and gave it to them and said: Take, eat, This is my body.

Mk 14:23
And he took the cup, gave thanks, and gave it to them, and they drank all of it.

Mk 14:24
And he said unto them: This is my blood of the new Testament, which shall be shed for many.

Mk 14:25
Verily I say unto you: I will drink no more of this fruit of the vine, until that day, that I shall drink it new in the kingdom of God.

Mk 14:26
And when they had said grace, they went out into the mount olivet.

Mk 14:27
And Iesus said unto them: All ye shall hurt thorow me this night. For it is written: I will smite the shepherd, and the sheep shall be scattered.

Mk 14:28
But after that I am risen again I will go into Galile before you.

Mk 14:29
Peter said unto him: And though all men should be hurt, yet would not I.

Mk 14:30
And Iesus said unto him: Verily I say unto thee this day even in this night, before the cock crow twice, thou shalt deny me thrice.

Mk 14:31
And he spake bolder: no, if I should die with thee, I will not deny thee. Likewise also said they all.

Mk 14:32
And they came into a place named Gethsemani. And he said to his disciples: Sit ye here while I go apart and pray.

Mk 14:33
And he took with him Peter, Iames, and Ihon, and he began to wax abashed and to be in an agony.

Mk 14:34
And said unto them: My soul is very heavy even unto the death, tarry here and watch.

Mk 14:35
And he went forth a little and fell down on the ground and prayed: That if it were possible, the hour might pass from him.

Mk 14:36
And he said: Abba father, all things are possible unto thee, take away this cup from me. Nevertheless not that I will, but that thou wilt be done.

Mk 14:37
And he came and found them sleeping, and said to Peter: Simon sleepest thou? Couldest not thou watch with me one hour?

Mk 14:38
watch ye, and pray, least ye enter into temptation, the spirit is ready, but the flesh is weak.

Mk 14:39
And again he went away and prayed, and spake the same words.

Mk 14:40
And he returned and found them asleep again, for their eyes were heavy: neither could they tell what they might answer to him.

Mk 14:41
And he came the third time, and said unto them: sleep hence forth and take your ease. It is enough. The hour is come, Behold the son of man shall be delivered into the hands of sinners.

Mk 14:42
Rise up, let us go. Lo he that betrayeth me, is come nye.

Mk 14:43
And immediately while he yet spake came Iudas, one of the twelve, and with him a great number of people with swords and staves from the high priests and scribes and seniors.

Mk 14:44
He that betrayed him, gave them a general token, saying: whosoever I do kiss, he it is, take him, and lead him away warily.

Mk 14:45
And as soon as he was come, he went straightway to him, and said unto him: master, master, and kissed him.

Mk 14:46
And they laid their hands on him, and took him.

Mk 14:47
And one of them that stood by drew out a sword, and smote a servant of the high priest, and cut off his ear.

Mk 14:48
And Iesus answered and said unto them: ye came out as unto a thief with swords and with staves for to take me.

Mk 14:49
I was daily with you in the temple teaching, and ye took me not, but that the scriptures should be fulfilled:

Mk 14:50
And they all forsook him and ran away.

Mk 14:51
And there was a certain young man that followed him clothed in linen upon the bare, and the young men caught him,

Mk 14:52
and he left his linen and fled from them naked.

Mk 14:53
And they led Iesus away to the highest priest of all, and to him came all the high priests and the seniors, and the scribes.

Mk 14:54
And Peter followed him a great way off even into the palace of the high priest, and he was there and sat with the servants, and warmed himself at the fire.

Mk 14:55
And the high priests and all the council sought for witness against Iesu, to put him to death, And they found none.

Mk 14:56
Yet many bare false witness against him, but their witness agreed not together.

Mk 14:57
And there arose certain and brought false witness against him, saying:

Mk 14:58
We heard him say: I will destroy this temple made with hands, and within three days I will build another, made without hands.

Mk 14:59
And their witness agreed not together.

Mk 14:60
And the highest priest stood up amongst them all, and asked Iesus saying: answerest thou nothing? How is it that these bear witness against thee?

Mk 14:61
And he held his peace, and answered nothing. Again the highest priest asked him, and said unto him: Art thou the Christ the son of the blessed?

Mk 14:62
And Iesus said: I am. And ye shall see the son of man sit on the right hand of power, and come in the clouds of heaven.

Mk 14:63
Then the highest priest rent his clothes and said: what need we any further witness?

Mk 14:64
ye have heard the blasphemy, what think ye? And they all gave sentence that he was worthy of death.

Mk 14:65
And some began to spit at him, and to cover his face, and to beat him with their fists, and to say unto him, aread unto us. And the servants buffeted him on the face.

Mk 14:66
And Peter was beneath in the palace, and there came one of the wenches of the highest priest,

Mk 14:67
And when she saw Peter warming himself, she looked on him, and said: was not thou also with Iesus of Nazareth?

Mk 14:68
And he denied it saying: I know him not, neither wot I what thou sayest: And he went out into the porch, and the cock crew.

Mk 14:69
And a damsel saw him, and again began to say to them that stood by, this is one of them.

Mk 14:70
And he denied it again. And anon after, again they that stood by, said to Peter: surely thou art one of them, for thou art of Galile, and thy speech agreeth thereto.

Mk 14:71
And he began to curse and to swear, saying: I know not this man of whom ye speak.

Mk 14:72
And again the cock crew. And Peter remembered the word that Iesus said unto him: before the cock crow twice, thou shalt deny me thrice, and began to weep.

Mk 15:1
And anon in the dawning held the high priests a council with the seniors and the scribes, And also the whole congregation, and bound Iesus and led him away, and delivered him to Pilate.

Mk 15:2
And Pilate asked him: art thou the king of the jews? And he answered, and said unto him: thou sayest it.

Mk 15:3
And the high priests accused him of many things.

Mk 15:4
Pilate asked him again, saying: Answerest thou nothing? Behold how many things they lay unto thy charge.

Mk 15:5
Iesus yet answered never a word, so that Pilate marvelled.

Mk 15:6
At the feast Pilate was wont to deliver at their pleasure a prisoner: whomsoever they would desire.

Mk 15:7
And there was one named Barabas, which lay bound with them, that caused insurrection, and in the insurrection committed murder.

Mk 15:8
And the people called unto him, and began to desire of him, according as he had ever done unto them.

Mk 15:9
Pilate answered them, and said: Will ye that I loose unto you the king of the jewes?

Mk 15:10
For he knew that the high priests had delivered him of envy.

Mk 15:11
But the high priests had moved the people that he should rather deliver Barabas unto them.

Mk 15:12
Pilate answered again, and said unto them: What will ye then that I do with him, whom ye call the king of the jewes?

Mk 15:13
And they cried again: crucify him.

Mk 15:14
Pilate said unto them: What evil hath he done? And they cried the more fervently: Crucify him.

Mk 15:15
Pilate willing to content the people, loused them Barabas, And delivered Iesus scourged for to be crucified.

Mk 15:16
And the soldiers led him away into the common hall, and called together the whole multitude,

Mk 15:17
and they clothed him with purple, and they plaited a crown of thorns and crowned him withall,

Mk 15:18
And began to salute him: Hail king of the jewes.

Mk 15:19
And they smote him on the head with a reed, and spat upon him, and kneeled down and worshipped him.

Mk 15:20
And when they had mocked him, they took the purple off him, and put his own clothes on him, and led him out, to crucify him.

Mk 15:21
And they compelled one that passed by, called Simon of Cyrene (which came out of the field, and was father of Alexander and Rufus) to bear his cross.

Mk 15:22
And they brought him to a place named Golgotha (which is by interpretation, the place of dead men's skulls)

Mk 15:23
and they gave him to drink wine mingled with myrrh, but he received it not.

Mk 15:24
And when they had crucified him, they parted his garments, casting lots for them, what every man should have.

Mk 15:25
And it was about the third hour, and they crucified him.

Mk 15:26
And the title of the cause of his death was written: The king of the jewes.

Mk 15:27
And they crucified with him two thieves: the one on his right hand, and the other on his left hand.

Mk 15:28
And the scripture was fulfilled, which sayeth: and he was counted among the wicked.

Mk 15:29
And they that went by, railed on him: wagging their heads, and saying: A wretch, that destroyest the temple and buildest it in three days.

Mk 15:30
Save thyself, and come down from the cross.

Mk 15:31
Likewise also mocked him the high priests among themselves with the scribes, and said: He saved other men, himself he cannot save.

Mk 15:32
Let Christ the king of Israel now descend from the cross, that we may see and believe. And they that were crucified with him, checked him also.

Mk 15:33
And when the sixth hour was come, darkness arose over all the earth, until the ninth hour.

Mk 15:34
And at the ninth hour Iesus cried with a loud voice, saying: Eloi, Eloi, lama sabaththani, which is if it be interpreted: my God, my God, why hast thou forsaken me?

Mk 15:35
And some of them that stood by when they heard that said: behold he calleth for Helias.

Mk 15:36
And one ran, and filled a sponge full of vinegar, and put it on a reed, and gave it him to drink, saying: let him alone, let us see whether Helias will come and take him down.

Mk 15:37
But Iesus cried with a loud voice, and gave up the ghost.

Mk 15:38
And the veil of the temple did rent in two parts, from the top to the bottom.

Mk 15:39
And when the undercaptain which stood before him saw that he so cried and gave up the ghost, and he said: truly this man was the son of God.

Mk 15:40
There were also women a good way off beholding him: among whom was Mary Magdalen, and Mary the mother of Iames the little and of Ioses, and Mary Salome:

Mk 15:41
which also when he was in Galile, followed him and ministered unto him, and many other women which came up with him to Hierusalem.

Mk 15:42
And now when night was come (because it was the even that goeth before the saboth)

Mk 15:43
Ioseph of Arimathia a noble senator (which also looked for the kingdom of God) came And went in boldly unto Pilate, and begged the body of Iesu.

Mk 15:44
Pilate marvelled that he was already dead, and called unto him the under captain, and asked of him, whether he had been any while dead.

Mk 15:45
And when he knew the truth of the under captain, he gave the body to Ioseph.

Mk 15:46
And he bought a linen cloth, and took him down and wrapped him in the linen cloth, and laid him in a tomb, that was hewn out of the rock. And rolled a stone unto the door of the sepulcre.

Mk 15:47
And Mary Magdalene and Mary Iose beheld where he was laid.

Mk 16:1
And when the saboth day was past, Mary Magdalen, and Mary Iacobi, and Salome, bought ointments, that they might come and anoint him.

Mk 16:2
And early in the morning the next day after the saboth day, they came unto the sepulchre, when the sun was risen.

Mk 16:3
And they said one to another: who shall roll us away the stone from the door of the sepulchre?

Mk 16:4
And when they beheld it, they saw how the stone was rolled away. For it was a very great one,

Mk 16:5
and they went into the sepulchre, and saw a young man, sitting on the right side, clothed in a long white garment, and they were abashed.

Mk 16:6
He said unto them, be not afraid, ye seek Iesus of Nazareth, which was crucified. He is risen, he is not here. Behold the place, where they put him.

Mk 16:7
But go your way, and tell his disciples, and namely Peter, that he is gone before you into Galile, there shall ye see him, as he said unto you.

Mk 16:8
And they went out quickly and fled from the sepulchre. For they trembled and were amazed. Neither said they anything to any man, for they were afraid.

Mk 16:9
When Iesus was risen the morrow after the saboth day, he appeared first to Mary Magdalen, out of whom he cast seven devils.

Mk 16:10
And she went, and told them that were with him, as they mourned and wept.

Mk 16:11
And when they heard, that he was alive, and had appeared to her: they believed it not.

Mk 16:12
After that, he appeared unto two of them in a strange figure, as he walked, and went into the country.

Mk 16:13
And they went, and told it to the remnant. And they believed them neither.

Mk 16:14
After that he appeared unto the eleven as they sat at meat: and cast in their teeth their unbelief, and hardness of heart: because they believed not them which had seen him after his resurrection.

Mk 16:15
And he said unto them: Go ye into all the world, and preach the gospel to all creatures:

Mk 16:16
Whosoever believeth, and is baptised, shall be safe: And whosoever that believeth not, shall be damned.

Mk 16:17
And these signs shall follow them that believe: In my name they shall cast out devils, and shall speak with new tongues,

Mk 16:18
and shall kill serpents. And if they drink any deadly thing, it shall not hurt them. They shall lay their hands on the sick, and they shall recover.

Mk 16:19
So then when the Lord had spoken unto them, he was received into heaven, and sat on the right hand of God.

Mk 16:20
And they went forth, and preached everywhere. And the Lord wrought with them, And confirmed their preaching with miracles that followed. <The end of the gospell of. S. Marke.>

Lk 1:1
Forasmuch as many have taken in hand to compile a treatise of those things, which are surely known among us,

Lk 1:2
even as they declared them unto us, which from the beginning saw them with their eyes, and were ministers at the doing:

Lk 1:3
I determined also, as soon as I had searched out diligently all things from the beggining, that then I would write unto thee, good Theophilus,

Lk 1:4
that thou mightest know the certainty of those things, whereof thou art informed.

Lk 1:5
In the time of Herode king of jewry, there was a certain priest named Zacharias, of the course of Abie. And his wife was of the daughters of Aaron: And her name was Elizabeth.

Lk 1:6
Both were perfect before God, and walked in all the laws and ordinances of the Lord that no man could find fault with them.

Lk 1:7
And they had no child, because that Elizabeth was barren, And both were well stricken in age.

Lk 1:8
It came to pass, as he executed the priest's office, before God as his course came

Lk 1:9
(according to the custom of the priest's office) his lot was to burn odoures. And went into the temple of the Lord,

Lk 1:10
and all the multitude of people were without in their prayers while the odoures were a burning.

Lk 1:11
There appeared unto him the Lord's angel, standing on the right side of the altar of odoures.

Lk 1:12
And when Zacharias saw him, he was abashed, and fear came on him.

Lk 1:13
The angel said unto him: fear not Zacary, for thy prayer is heard: And thy wife Helizabeth shall bear thee a son, and thou shalt call his name Ihon:

Lk 1:14
And thou shalt have joy and gladness: And many shall rejoice at his birth.

Lk 1:15
For he shall be great in the sight of God, and shall neither drink wine nor strong drink. And he shall be filled with the holy ghost, even in his mother's womb:

Lk 1:16
and many of the children of Israhel shall he turn to their Lord God.

Lk 1:17
And he shall go before him in the spirit and power of Helias to turn the hearts of the fathers to their children, and the unbelievers to the wisdom of the just men: to make the people ready for the Lord.

Lk 1:18
And Zacary said unto the angel: Whereby shall I know this? seeing that I am old, and my wife well stricken in years.

Lk 1:19
And the angel answered, and said unto him: I am Gabriel that stand in the presence of God, and am sent to speak unto thee: and to shew thee this glad tidings.

Lk 1:20
And take heed thou shalt be dumb, and not able to speak until the time that these things be performed, because thou believedst not my words, which shall be fulfilled in their season.

Lk 1:21
And the people waited for Zacharias and marvelled that he tarried in the temple.

Lk 1:22
When he came out, he could not speak unto them. And they perceived, that he had seen some vision in the temple. And he beckoned unto them, and remained speechless.

Lk 1:23
And it fortuned, as soon as the time of his office was out, he departed home into his own house. And after those days,

Lk 1:24
his wife Elizabeth conceived, and hid herself v. months, saying:

Lk 1:25
This wise hath God dealt with me in the days when he looked on me, to take from me the rebuke that I suffered among men.

Lk 1:26
And in the vi. month the angel Gabriel was sent from God unto a city of Galile, named Nazareth,

Lk 1:27
to a virgin spoused to a man, whose name was Ioseph, of the house of David, and the virgin's name was Mary.

Lk 1:28
And the angel went in unto her, and said: Hail full of grace, the Lord is with thee: blessed art thou among women.

Lk 1:29
When she saw him, she was abashed at his saying: and cast in her mind what manner of salutation that should be.

Lk 1:30
And the angel said unto her: fear not Mary, thou hast found grace with God.

Lk 1:31
Lo: thou shalt conceive in thy womb, and shalt bear a child, and shalt call his name Iesus.

Lk 1:32
He shall be great, and shall be called the son of the highest. And the Lord God shall give unto him the seat of his father David:

Lk 1:33
And he shall reign over the house of Iacob for ever, and of his kingdom shall be none end.

Lk 1:34
Then said Mary unto the angel: How shall this be, seeing I know not a man?

Lk 1:35
And the angel answered, and said unto her: The holy ghost shall come upon thee, and the power of the highest shall overshadow thee. Therefore also that holy thing which shall be born, shall be called the son of God.

Lk 1:36
And mark, thy cousin Elizabeth, hath also conceived a son in her old age. And this is the. vi. month to her, which was called barren,

Lk 1:37
for with God shall nothing be unpossible.

Lk 1:38
Mary said: behold the handmaiden of the Lord, be it unto me even as thou hast said. And the angel departed from her.

Lk 1:39
Mary arose in those days, and went into the mountains with haste into a city of jewrie,

Lk 1:40
and entered into the house of Zachary, and saluted Elizabeth:

Lk 1:41
And it fortuned, as Elizabeth heard the salutation of Mary, the babe sprang in her belly. And Elizabeth was filled with the holy ghost,

Lk 1:42
and cried with a loud voice, and said: Blessed art thou among the women, and blessed is the fruit of thy womb.

Lk 1:43
And whence happeneth this to me, that the mother of my Lord should come to me?

Lk 1:44
Lo, as soon as the voice of thy salutation sounded in mine ears, the babe sprang in my belly for joy.

Lk 1:45
And blessed art thou that believedst: For those things shall be performed which were told thee from the Lord.

Lk 1:46
And Mary said: My soul magnifieth the Lord.

Lk 1:47
And my spirit rejoiceth in God my saviour:

Lk 1:48
For he hath looked on the poor degree of his handmaiden. Behold now from hence forth shall all generations call me blessed.

Lk 1:49
For he that is mighty hath done to me great things, and blessed is his name.

Lk 1:50
And his mercy is always on them that fear him thorowout all generations.

Lk 1:51
He hath shewed strength with his arm, he hath scattered them that are proud in the imagination of their hearts.

Lk 1:52
He hath put Down the mighty from their seats, and hath exalted them of low degree.

Lk 1:53
He hath filled the hungry with good things: And hath sent away the rich empty.

Lk 1:54
He hath remembered mercy: and hath holpen his servant Israhel.

Lk 1:55
Even as he promised to our fathers, Abraham and to his seed for ever.

Lk 1:56
And Mary abode with her about a iij. months, And returned home again.

Lk 1:57
Elizabeth's time was come that she should be delivered, And she brought forth a son.

Lk 1:58
And her neighbours and her cousins heard tell how, the Lord had magnified his mercy upon her, and they rejoiced with her.

Lk 1:59
And it fortuned the eighth day: they came to circumcise the child: and called his name Zacari after the name of his father,

Lk 1:60
and his mother answered, and said: not so, but he shall be called Ihon.

Lk 1:61
And they said unto her: There is none of thy kin, that is named with this name.

Lk 1:62
And they made signs to his father, how he would have him called.

Lk 1:63
And he asked for writing tables and wrote saying: his name is Ihon. And they marvelled all.

Lk 1:64
And his mought was opened immediately, and his tongue, and he spake lauding God.

Lk 1:65
And fear came on all them that dwelt nye: And all these sayings were noised abroad throughout all the hill country of jewrie:

Lk 1:66
and all they that heard them laid them up in their hearts, saying: What manner child shall this be? And the hand of God was with him.

Lk 1:67
And his father Zacharias was filled with the holy ghost, and prophesied saying:

Lk 1:68
Blessed be the Lord God of Israhel, for he hath visited and redeemed his people.

Lk 1:69
And hath raised up an horn of salvation unto us, in the house of his servant David.

Lk 1:70
Even as he promised by the mouth of his holy prophets which were since the world began.

Lk 1:71
That we should be saved from our enemies: And from the hands of all that hate us:

Lk 1:72
To shew mercy towards our fathers, And to remember his holy promise.

Lk 1:73
That is to say the oath, which he sware to our father Abraham, for to give us.

Lk 1:74
That we delivered out of the hands of our enemies, might serve him without fear:

Lk 1:75
all the days of our life, in such holiness and righteousness that are accept before him.

Lk 1:76
And thou child, shalt be called the prophet of the highest, for thou shalt go before the face of the Lord, to prepare his ways:

Lk 1:77
And to give knowledge of health unto his people, for the remission of sins:

Lk 1:78
Through the tender mercy of our Lord, wherewith hath visited us the day spring from on high:

Lk 1:79
To give light to them that sat in darkness, and in shadow of death, and to guide our feet into the way of peace.

Lk 1:80
And the child increased and waxed strong in spirit, and was in wilderness, till the day came, when he should shew himself unto the Israhelites.

Lk 2:1
It followed in those days: that there went out a commandment from August the Emperor, that all the world should be valued.

Lk 2:2
This taxing was first executed when Syrenus was leftenant in Syria.

Lk 2:3
And every man went into his own shire town, there to be taxed.

Lk 2:4
And Ioseph also ascended from Galilee, out of a city called Nazareth, into jewry: into the city of David, which is called Bethlehem, because he was of the house and lineage of David

Lk 2:5
to be taxed with Mary his wedded wife, which was with child.

Lk 2:6
And it fortuned while they were there, her time was come that she should be delivered.

Lk 2:7
And she brought forth her first begotten son. And wrapped him in swaddling clothes, and laid him in a manger, because there was no room for them within, in the hostry.

Lk 2:8
And there were in the same region shepherds abiding in the field, and watching their flock by night.

Lk 2:9
And lo: the angel of the Lord stood hard by them, and the brightness of the Lord shone round about them, and they were sore afraid.

Lk 2:10
And the angel said unto them: Be not afraid: Behold I bring you tidings of great joy, that shall come to all the people:

Lk 2:11
for unto you is born this day in the city of David a saviour, which is Christ the Lord.

Lk 2:12
And take this for a sign: ye shall find the child swaddled, and laid in a manger.

Lk 2:13
And straight way there was with the angel a multitude of heavenly soldiers, lauding God, and saying:

Lk 2:14
Glory to God on high, and peace on the earth: and unto men rejoicing.

Lk 2:15
And it fortuned, as soon as the angels were gone away into heaven, the shepherds said one to another: let us go even unto Bethlehem, and see this thing that is happened, which the Lord hath shewed unto us.

Lk 2:16
And they came with haste, and found Mary and Ioseph, and the babe laid in a manger.

Lk 2:17
And when they had seen it, they published abroad the saying, which was told them of that child.

Lk 2:18
And all that heard it wondered, at those things which were told them of the shepherds.

Lk 2:19
But Mary kept all those sayings, and pondered them in her heart.

Lk 2:20
And the shepherds returned, praising and lauding God for all that they had heard and seen, even as it was told unto them.

Lk 2:21
And when the eighth day was come that the child should be circumcised, his name was called Iesus, which was named of the angel before he was conceived in the mother's womb.

Lk 2:22
And when the time of their purification (after the law of Moses) was come they brought him to Hierusalem, to present him to the Lord

Lk 2:23
(As it is written in the law of the Lord: every man child that first openeth the matrix, shall be called holy to the Lord)

Lk 2:24
and to offer (as it is said in the law of the Lord) a pair of turtle doves, or ij. young pigeons.

Lk 2:25
And behold there was a man in Hierusalem, whose name was Simeon. And the same man was just and feared God, and longed for the consolation of Israhel, and the holy ghost was in him.

Lk 2:26
And an answer was given him of the holy ghost, that he should not see death, before he had seen the Lord's Christ.

Lk 2:27
And he came by inspiration into the temple. And as the father and mother brought in the child Iesus, to do for him after the custom of the law.

Lk 2:28
Then took he him up in his arms and said:

Lk 2:29
Lord Now lettest thou thy servant depart in peace according to thy promise.

Lk 2:30
For mine eyes have seen the saviour sent from thee

Lk 2:31
Which thou hast prepared before the face of all people.

Lk 2:32
A light to lighten the gentiles, and the glory of thy people Israhel.

Lk 2:33
And his father and mother marvelled at those things, which were spoken of him:

Lk 2:34
And Simeon blessed them, and said unto Mary his mother: behold, this child shall be the fall, and resurrection of many in Israhel: And a sign which shall be spoken against.

Lk 2:35
And moreover the sword shall pierce the very heart of thee, that the thoughts of many hearts may be opened.

Lk 2:36
And there was Anna, a prophetess, the daughter of Phanuel of tribe of Aser. And she was of a great age, and had lived with an husband. vij. year from her virginity.

Lk 2:37
And this widow about iiij. score and iiij. year of age, which went never out of the temple, but served there with fasting and prayer night and day.

Lk 2:38
And she came forth that same hour, and praised God, and spake of him to all that looked for redemption in Hierusalem.

Lk 2:39
And as soon as they had performed all things according to the law of the Lord, they returned into Galile into their own city Nazareth.

Lk 2:40
And the child grew and waxed strong in spirit, and was full of wisdom, and the favour of God was with him.

Lk 2:41
And his father and mother went to Hierusalem every year at the feast of ester.

Lk 2:42
And when he was xij. years old, they went up to Hierusalem after the custom of the feast.

Lk 2:43
And when they had fulfilled the days, as they returned home, the child Iesus bode still in Hierusalem, unknowing to his father and mother.

Lk 2:44
For they supposed he had been in the company. They came a day's journey, and sought him among their kinsfolk and acquaintance,

Lk 2:45
and found him not They went back again to Hierusalem, and sought him.

Lk 2:46
And it fortuned after iij. days, they found him in the temple sitting in the midst of the doctors, both hearing them, and posing them.

Lk 2:47
And all that heard him marvelled at his wit and answers.

Lk 2:48
And when they saw him, they were astonied. And his mother said unto him: son why hast thou thus dealt with us? Behold thy father and I have sorowed and sought thee.

Lk 2:49
And he said unto them: how is it that ye sought me? wist ye not that I must go about my father's business?

Lk 2:50
And they understood not the saying that he spake to them.

Lk 2:51
And he went with them, and came to Nazareth, and was obedient to them. His mother kept all these things in her heart.

Lk 2:52
And Iesus increased in wisdom and age, and in favour with God and man.

Lk 3:1
In the fifteenth year of the reign of Tiberius the Emperor, Pontius Pilate being leftenant of Jewry, and Herod being Tetrarch of Galilee, and his brother Philip Tetrarch in Iturea, and in the region of Traconitis, and Lysanias the Tetrarch of Abyline:

Lk 3:2
When Anna and Cayphas were the high priests: The commandment of God was published unto Ihon the son of Zacharias in the wilderness.

Lk 3:3
And he came into all the coasts about Iordan, preaching the baptism of repentance for the remission of sins,

Lk 3:4
as it is written in the book of the sayings of Esayas the prophet, which sayeth: The voice of a crier in wilderness, prepare the way of the Lord, make his paths straight.

Lk 3:5
Every valley shall be filled, and every mountain and hill shall be brought low: And crooked things shall be made straight: and the rough ways shall be made smooth.

Lk 3:6
And all flesh shall see the saviour sent of God.

Lk 3:7
Then said he to the people, that were come to be baptised of him. O generation of vipers: who hath shewed the craft to fly from wrath to come?

Lk 3:8
