Bring forth due fruits of repentance, And begin not to say in yourselves, we have Abraham to our father. For I say unto you: God is able of these stones to raise up children unto Abraham.

Lk 3:9
Now also is the axe laid unto the root of the trees. Every tree therefore, which bringeth not forth good fruit, shall be hewn down, and cast into the fire.

Lk 3:10
And the people asked him, saying: What shall we do then.

Lk 3:11
He answered and said unto them: He that hath ij. coats, let him part with him that hath none: And he that hath meat, let him do likewise.

Lk 3:12
Then came there publicans to be baptised, and said unto him: Master, what shall we do?

Lk 3:13
He answered unto them: require no more than that, which is appointed unto you.

Lk 3:14
The soldiers likewise demanded of him, saying: and what shall we do? And he said to them: Do violence to no man: neither trouble any man wrongfully: And be content with your wages.

Lk 3:15
As the people were in a doubt, and all men disputed in their hearts of Ihon: Whether he were very Christ,

Lk 3:16
Ihon answered and said to them all: I baptise you with water, but a stronger then cometh, whose shoe latchet I am not worthy to unloose: he will baptise you with the holy ghost, and with fire,

Lk 3:17
which hath his fan in his hand, and will purge his floor, and will gather his corn into his barn: And the chaff will he burn with fire that never shall be quenched.

Lk 3:18
And many other things in his exhortation preached he unto the people.

Lk 3:19
Then Herod the Tetrach (when he was rebuked of him for Herodias his brother Philippe's wife, and for all the evils which Herod had done)

Lk 3:20
added this above all, and laid Ihon prison.

Lk 3:21
And it fortuned as all the people received baptism (And when Iesus was baptised and did pray) that heaven was opened,

Lk 3:22
and the holy ghost came down in a bodily shape like a dove upon him, And a voice came from heaven, saying: Thou art my dear son, In thee do I delight.

Lk 3:23
And Iesus himself was about thirty year of age when he began, being as men supposed the son of Ioseph: which Ioseph was the son of Heli:

Lk 3:24
which was the son of Mathat: which was the son of Levi: which was the son of Melchi: which was the son of Ianna: which was the son of Ioseph:

Lk 3:25
which was the son of Matatthias: which was the son of Amos: which was the son of Nahum: which was the son of Esli: which was the son of Nagge:

Lk 3:26
which was the son of Maath: which was the son of Matathias: which was the son of Semei: which was the son of Ioseph: which was the son of Iuda:

Lk 3:27
which was the son of Iohanna: which was the son of Rhesya: which was the son of Zorobabel: which was the son of Salathiel: which was the son of Neri:

Lk 3:28
which was the son of Melchi: which was the son of Addi: which was the son of Cosam:

Lk 3:29
which was the son of Helmadam: which was the son of Her: which was the son of Ieso: which was the son of Helieser: which was the son of Ioram: which was the son of Mattha: which was the son of Levi:

Lk 3:30
which was the son of Simeon: which was the son of Iuda: which was the son of Ioseph: which was the son of Ionam: which was the son of Heliacim:

Lk 3:31
which was the son of Melea: which was the son of Menam: which was the son of Matathan: which was the son of Nathan: which was the son of David:

Lk 3:32
which was the son of Iesse: which was the son of Obed: which was the son of Boos: which was the son of Salmon: which was the son of

Lk 3:33
Naason: which was the son of Aminadab: which was the son of Aram: which was the son of Esrom: which was the son of Phares: which was the son of Iuda:

Lk 3:34
which was the son of Iacob: which was the son of Ysaac: which was the son of Abraham: which was the son of Tharra: which was the son of Nachor:

Lk 3:35
which was the son of Saruch: which was the son of Ragau: which was the son of Phalec: which was the son of Heber: which was the son of Sala:

Lk 3:36
which was the son of Cainan: which was the son of Arphaxad: which was the son of Sem: which was the son of Noe: which was the son of Lameth:

Lk 3:37
which was the son of Mathusala: which was the son of Enoch: which was the son of Iareth: which was the son of Malalehel: which was the son of Cainan:

Lk 3:38
which was the son of Enos: which was the son of Seth: which was the son of Adam: which was the son of God.

Lk 4:1
Iesus then full of the holy ghost, returned from Iordan, and was carried of the spirit into a wilderness,

Lk 4:2
and was xl. days tempted of the devil. And in those days ate he nothing: And when they were ended, he afterward hungered.

Lk 4:3
And the devil said unto him: if thou be the son of God, command this stone that he be bread.

Lk 4:4
And Iesus answered him, saying: It is written: man shall not live by bread only, but by every word of God.

Lk 4:5
And the devil took him up into an high mountain, and shewed him all the kingdoms of the earth, even in the twinkling of an eye.

Lk 4:6
And the devil said unto him: all this power will I give thee every whit, and the glory of them (for that is delivered to me, and to whosoever I will I give it)

Lk 4:7
If thou therefore wilt worship me, they shall be all thine.

Lk 4:8
Iesus answered and said unto him: hence from me Satan. For it is written. Thou shalt honour thy Lord God, and him only serve.

Lk 4:9
And he carried him to Ierusalem, and set him on a pinnacle of the temple, and said unto him: If thou be the son of God, cast thyself down from hence.

Lk 4:10
For it is written, he shall give his angels charge over thee, to keep thee,

Lk 4:11
and with their hands they shall stay thee up, that thou hurt not thy foot against a stone.

Lk 4:12
Iesus answered and said unto him, it is said, thou shalt not tempt thy Lord God.

Lk 4:13
And as soon as the devil had ended all his temptations, he departed from him for a season.

Lk 4:14
And Iesus returned by the power of the spirit into Galile, and the fame of him went throweout all the region round about.

Lk 4:15
And he taught in their synagogues, and was commended of all men.

Lk 4:16
And he came to Nazareth where he was nursed, and as his custom was, went into the synagogue on the saboth days, and stood up for to read.

Lk 4:17
And there was delivered unto him the book of the prophet Esaias. And when he had opened the book, he found the place, where it was written:

Lk 4:18
The spirit of the Lord upon me, because he hath anointed me, To preach the gospell to the poor he hath sent me, And to heal which are troubled in their hearts: To preach deliverance to the captive, And sight to the blind, And freely to set at liberty them that are bruised,

Lk 4:19
And to preach the acceptable year of the Lord.

Lk 4:20
And he closed the book, and gave it again to the minister, and sat down. And the eyes of all that were in the synagogue, were fastened on him.

Lk 4:21
And he began to say unto them. This day is this scripture fulfilled in your ears.

Lk 4:22
And all they bare him witness, and wondered at the gracious words, which proceeded out of his mouth, and said: Is not this Ioseph's son?

Lk 4:23
And he said unto them: Ye may very well say unto me this proverb. Physician, heal thyself. Whatsoever we have heard done in Capernaum, do the same likewise in thine own country.

Lk 4:24
And he said: Verily I say unto you: No prophet is accepted in his own country.

Lk 4:25
But I tell you of a truth, Many widows were in Israhell in the days of Helyas, when heaven was shut three years and six months, when great famishment was throughout all the land,

Lk 4:26
And unto none of them was Helyas sent, save into Sarepta besides Sydon unto a woman that was a widow.

Lk 4:27
And many lepers were in Israhel in the time of Heliseus the prophet, and yet none of them was healed, saving Naaman of Siria.

Lk 4:28
And as many as were in the synagogue when they heard that, were filled with wrath

Lk 4:29
and rose up, and thrust him out of the city, and led him even unto the edge of the hill, whereon their city was built, to cast him down headlong.

Lk 4:30
But he went his way even thorow the midst of them:

Lk 4:31
and came into Capernaum a city of Galile, and there taught them on the saboth days.

Lk 4:32
And they were astonied at his doctrine: for his preaching was with power.

Lk 4:33
And in the synagogue there was a man, which had a foul spirit within him, and cried with a loud voice,

Lk 4:34
saying: let me alone, what hast thou to do with us, thou Iesus of Nazareth? Art thou come to destroy us? I know thee what thou art, thou art the holy man of God.

Lk 4:35
And Iesus rebuked him, saying: hold thy peace, and come out of him. And the devil threw him in the midst of them and came out of him, and hurt him not.

Lk 4:36
And fear came on them all, And they spake among themselves, saying: what manner a thing is this? For with authority and power he commandeth the foul spirits and they come out?

Lk 4:37
And the fame of him spread abroad throweout all places of the country round about.

Lk 4:38
And he rose up and came out of the synagogue, and entered into Simon's house. And Simon's motherinlaw was taken with a great fever, And they made intercession to him for her.

Lk 4:39
And he stood over her, and rebuked the fever: and it left her. And immediately she rose and ministered unto them.

Lk 4:40
When the son was down, all they that had sick, taken with divers diseases, brought them unto him: and he laid his hands on every one of them, and healed them.

Lk 4:41
And devils also came out of many of them, crying and saying: thou art Christ the son of God. And he rebuked them, and suffered them not to speak, for they knew that he was Christ.

Lk 4:42
As soon as it was day, he departed and went away into a desert place, and the people sought him and came to him, and kept him that he should not depart from them.

Lk 4:43
And he said unto them: I must to other cities also preach the word of God, for therefore am I sent.

Lk 4:44
And he preached in the synagogues of Galilee.

Lk 5:1
It came to pass as the people pressed upon him, to hear the word of God, that he stood by the lake of Genazareth:

Lk 5:2
and saw two ships stand by the lakeside, for the fishermen were gone out of them, and were washing their nets.

Lk 5:3
Iesus entered into one of the ships, which pertained to Simon, and prayed him, that he would carry him a little from the land. And he sat down and taught the people out of the ship.

Lk 5:4
When he had left speaking, he said unto Simon: Carry us into the deep, and let slip thy net to make a draught.

Lk 5:5
And Simon answered, and said to him: Master we have laboured all night, and have taken nothing. Yet now at thy word I will loose forth the net.

Lk 5:6
And when they had so done, they inclosed a great multitude of fishes. And the net brake:

Lk 5:7
and they made signs to their fellows which were in the other ship, that they should come and help them. And they came, and they filled both the ships, that they sunk again.

Lk 5:8
When Simon Peter saw that, he fell down at Iesus' knees saying: Lord go from me, for I am a sinful man.

Lk 5:9
For he was utterly astonied, and all that were with him at the draught of fish which they took:

Lk 5:10
and so was also Iames and Ihon the sons of Zebedei, which were partakers with Simon. And Iesus said unto Simon: fear not, from henceforth thou shalt catch men.

Lk 5:11
And they brought the ships to land, and forsook all, and followed him.

Lk 5:12
And it fortuned as he was in a certain city, and behold there was a man full of leprosy: and when he had spied Iesus, he fell on his face and besought him saying: Lord if thou wilt, thou canst make me clean.

Lk 5:13
And he stretched forth his hand, and touched him saying: I will, be thou clean. And immediately the leprosy departed from him.

Lk 5:14
And he warned him, that he should tell no man: but that he should go and shew himself to the priest, and offer for his cleansing according as Moses commandment was, for a witness unto them.

Lk 5:15
But his name spread the more abroad, and the people came together to hear, and to be healed of him, of infirmities.

Lk 5:16
And he kept himself apart in the wildernesses, and gave himself to prayer.

Lk 5:17
And it happened on a certain day, that he taught, and there sat the pharises, and doctors of law, which were come out of all the towns of Galile, Jewry, and Ierusalem, and the power of the Lord was to heal them.

Lk 5:18
And behold, men brought a man lying in his bed, which was taken with a palsy, and they sought means to bring him in, and to lay him before him.

Lk 5:19
And when they could not find by what way they might bring him in, because of the press, they went up on the top of the house, and let him down thorow the tiling, bed and all in the midst before Iesus.

Lk 5:20
When he saw their faith he said unto him: man thy sins are forgiven thee.

Lk 5:21
And the scribes, and the pharises, began to think saying: What fellow is this: which speaketh blasphemy? Who can forgive sins, but God only?

Lk 5:22
When Iesus perceived their thoughts, he answered and said unto them: What think ye in your hearts?

Lk 5:23
Whether is easier to say, thy sins are forgiven thee, or to say: Rise and walk?

Lk 5:24
That ye may know that the son of man hath power to forgive sins on earth, he said unto the sick of the palsy: I say to thee, arise, take up thy bed and go home to thy house.

Lk 5:25
And immediately he rose up before them all, and took up his bed whereon he lay, and departed to his own house praising God.

Lk 5:26
And they were ail amazed, and they lauded God, and were filled with fear, saying: We have seen strange things today.

Lk 5:27
And after that he went forth, and saw a publican, named Levi, sitting at the receipt of custom, and said unto him: follow me.

Lk 5:28
And he left all, rose up, and followed him.

Lk 5:29
And that same Levi made him a great feast at home in his own house. And there was a great company of publicans, and of other that sat at meat with him.

Lk 5:30
And the scribes and pharises murmured against his disciples, saying: Why eat ye and drink ye, with publicans and sinners?

Lk 5:31
Iesus answered and said unto them: They that are whole, need not of the physician: but they that are sick.

Lk 5:32
I came not to call the righteous to repentance: but the sinners.

Lk 5:33
They said unto him: Why do the disciples of Ihon fast often and pray: and the disciples of the pharises also: and thine eat and drink?

Lk 5:34
To whom he said: Can ye make the Children of the wedding fast, as long as the bridegroom is present with them?

Lk 5:35
The days will come, when the bridegroom shall be taken away from them, then shall they fast in those days.

Lk 5:36
He spake unto them in a similitude: No man putteth a piece of a new garment, into an old vesture: for if he do, then breaketh he the new and the piece that was taken out of the new, agreeth not with the old.

Lk 5:37
Also no man poureth new wine into old vessels, if he do, the new wine breaketh the vessels, and runneth out itself, and the vessels perish:

Lk 5:38
But new wine must be poured into new vessels, and both are preserved.

Lk 5:39
Also no man that drinketh old wine, straightway can away with new, for he sayeth: the old is pleasanter.

Lk 6:1
It happened on an after Sabbath, they went thorow the corn field, and his disciples plucked the ears of corn, and ate them, and rubbed them in their hands.

Lk 6:2
Certain of the pharises said unto them: Why do ye that which is not lawful to be done on the saboth days?

Lk 6:3
Iesus answered them and said: Have ye not read what David did, when he himself was an hungered, and they which were with him:

Lk 6:4
how he went into the house of God, and took and ate the loaves of hallowed bread, and gave also to them which were with him: which was not lawful to eat, but for the priests only.

Lk 6:5
And he said unto them: The son of man is Lord even of the saboth day.

Lk 6:6
And it fortuned in another saboth also, that he entered into the synagogue and taught. And there was a man, whose right hand was dried up.

Lk 6:7
The scribes, and pharises watched him, to see whether he would heal on the saboth day or not, that they might find an accusation against him.

Lk 6:8
But he knew their thoughts, and said to the man which had the withered hand: Rise up, and stand forth in the midst. He arose, and stepped forth.

Lk 6:9
Then said Iesus unto them: I will ask you a question: Whether is it lawful on the saboth days to do good, or to do evil? to save life or for to destroy it?

Lk 6:10
And he beheld them all in compass, and said unto the man: Stretch forth thy hand. He did so, and his hand was restored, and made as whole as the other.

Lk 6:11
And they were filled full of madness, and communed one with another, what they might do to Iesu.

Lk 6:12
It fortuned in those days, he went out into a mountain for to pray, and continued all night in prayer to God.

Lk 6:13
And as soon as it was day, he called his disciples, and of them he chose twelve, which also he called his apostles.

Lk 6:14
Simon, whom also he named Peter: and Andrew his brother, Iames and Ihon, Philip and Bartlemew,

Lk 6:15
Matthew and Thomas, Iames the son of Alpheus and Simon called Zelotes,

Lk 6:16
and Iudas Iames' son, and Iudas Iscariot, which same was the traitor.

Lk 6:17
And he came down with them and stood in the plain field with the company of his disciples, and a great multitude of people out of all parts of Iurie and Ierusalem, and from the sea coast of Tyre and Sidon, which came to hear him, and to be healed of their diseases,

Lk 6:18
and they also that were vexed with foul spirits, and they were healed.

Lk 6:19
And all the people pressed to touch him: for there went virtue out of him, and healed them all.

Lk 6:20
And he lifted up his eyes upon the disciples, and said: Blessed are ye poor: for yours is the kingdom of God.

Lk 6:21
Blessed are ye that hunger: for ye shall be satisfied. Blessed are ye that weep: for ye shall laugh.

Lk 6:22
Blessed are ye when men hate you, and thrust you out of their company, and rail on you, and abhor your name, as an evil thing, for the son of man's sake.

Lk 6:23
Rejoice ye then, and be glad: for behold your reward is great in heaven. After this manner their fathers entreated the prophets.

Lk 6:24
But woe be to you that are rich: for ye have therein your consolation.

Lk 6:25
Woe be to you that are full: for ye shall hunger. Woe be to you that now laugh: for ye shall wail, and weep.

Lk 6:26
Woe be to you when all men praise you: for so did their fathers to the false prophets.

Lk 6:27
But I say unto you which hear: Love your enemies. Do good to them which hate you.

Lk 6:28
Bless them that curse you. And pray for them which wrongfully trouble you.

Lk 6:29
And unto him that smiteth thee on the one cheek, offer also the other. And him that taketh away thy gown, forbid not to take thy coat also.

Lk 6:30
Give to every man that asketh of thee. And if any man that take away thy goods, ask them not again.

Lk 6:31
And as ye would that men should do to you: so do ye to them likewise.

Lk 6:32
If ye love them which love you: what thank are ye worthy of? seeing that the very sinners love their lovers.

Lk 6:33
And if ye do for them which do for you: what thank are ye worthy of? For the very sinners do even the same.

Lk 6:34
If ye lend to them of whom ye hope to receive: what thank shall ye have: for the very sinners, lend to sinners, to receive as much again.

Lk 6:35
Love ye your enemies, do good, and lend, looking for nothing again: and your reward shall be great, and ye shall be the children of the highest: for he is kind unto the unkind, and to the evil.

Lk 6:36
Be ye therefore merciful, as your father is merciful.

Lk 6:37
Judge not and ye shall not be judged. Condemn not: and ye shall not be condemned. Forgive, and ye shall be forgiven.

Lk 6:38
Give, and it shall be given unto you: good measure, pressed down, shaken together, and running over, shall men give into your bosoms. For with what measure ye mete, with the same shall men mete to you again.

Lk 6:39
And he put forth a similitude unto them: Can the blind lead the blind? Do they not both then fall into the ditch?

Lk 6:40
The disciple is not above his master. Every man shall be perfect, even as his master is.

Lk 6:41
Why seest thou a mote in thy brother's eye, and considerest not the beam that is in thine own eye?

Lk 6:42
Other how canst thou say to thy brother: Brother let me pull out the mote that is in thine eye: when thou perceivest not the beam that is in thine own eye? Hypocrite, cast out the beam out of thine own eye first, and then shalt thou see perfectly, to pull out the mote out of thy brother's eye.

Lk 6:43
It is not a good tree that bringeth forth evil fruit: Neither is that an evil tree, that bringeth forth good fruit.

Lk 6:44
For every tree is known by his fruit. Neither of thorns gather men figs, nor of bushes gather they grapes.

Lk 6:45
A good man out of the good treasure of his heart bringeth forth that which is good. And the evil man out of the evil treasure of his heart, bringeth forth that which is evil. For of the abundance of the heart, the mought speaketh.

Lk 6:46
Why call ye me Master, Master: and do not as I bid you?

Lk 6:47
whosoever cometh to me, and heareth my sayings, and doth the same, I will shew you to whom he is like.

Lk 6:48
He is like a man which built an house: which digged deep, and laid the foundation on a rock. When the waters arose, the flood beat upon that house, and could not move it. For it was grounded upon a rock.

Lk 6:49
But he that heareth and doth not, is like a man, that without foundation built an house upon the earth, against which, the flood beat: and it fell by and by. And the fall of that house was great.

Lk 7:1
When he had ended all his sayings in the audience of the people, he entered into Capernaum.

Lk 7:2
And the servant of a certain Centurion was sick, and ready to die, whom he made much of.

Lk 7:3
And when he heard of Iesu, he sent unto him the seniors of the jewes, beseeching him that he would come and heal his servant.

Lk 7:4
And they came to Iesus and besought him instantly, saying: He is worthy that thou shouldest do this for him.

Lk 7:5
For he loveth our nation, and hath built us a synagogue.

Lk 7:6
And Iesus went with them. And when he was not far from the house, the Centurion sent to him his friends, saying unto him: Lord trouble not thyself, for I am not worthy that thou shouldest enter into my house.

Lk 7:7
Wherefore I thought not myself worthy to come unto thee: but say the word and my servant shall be whole.

Lk 7:8
For I likewise am a man under power, and have under me soldiers, and I say unto one, go: and he goeth. And to another, come: and he cometh. And to my servant, do this: and he doeth it.

Lk 7:9
When Iesus heard this, he marvelled at him, and turned him about and said to the people that followed him: I say unto you, I have not found so great faith, no not in Israhel, certainly.

Lk 7:10
And they that were sent, turned back home again, and found the servant that was sick whole.

Lk 7:11
And it fortuned after that, he went into a city called Naym, and his disciples went with him, and a great number of people.

Lk 7:12
When he came nye to the gate of the city, behold, there was a dead man carried out, which was the only son of his mother, and she was a widow, and much people of the city was with her.

Lk 7:13
And the Lord saw her, and had compassion on her, and said unto her: weep not.

Lk 7:14
And went and touched the coffin, and they that bare him stood still. And he said: Young man, I say unto thee, arise.

Lk 7:15
And the dead sat up, and began to speak. And he delivered him to his mother.

Lk 7:16
And there came a fear on them all. And they glorified God saying: a great prophet is risen among us, and God hath visited his people.

Lk 7:17
And this rumor of him went forth throughout all Jewry, and thorowout all the regions which lie round about.

Lk 7:18
And unto Ihon shewed his disciples of all these things.

Lk 7:19
And Ihon called unto him two of his disciples, and sent them to Iesus saying: Art thou he that shall come: or shall we look for another?

Lk 7:20
When the men were come unto him, they said: Ihon baptist sent us unto thee saying: Art thou he that shall come: or shall we wait for another?

Lk 7:21
At that same time, he cured many of their infirmities and plagues, And of evil spirits, and unto many that were blind, he gave sight.

Lk 7:22
And he answered, and said unto them: Go your ways and shew Ihon, what things ye have heard and seen: how that the blind see, the halt go, the lepers are cleansed, the deaf hear, the dead arise: To the poor is the gospell preached,

Lk 7:23
and happy is he that falleth not, by reason of me.

Lk 7:24
When the messengers of Ihon were departed, he began to speak unto the people of Ihon: What went ye out for to see into the desert? went ye to see a reed shaken with the wind?

Lk 7:25
But what went ye out for to see? A man clothed in soft raiment? Behold they which are gorgeously apparelled, and live delicately, are in kings' courts.

Lk 7:26
But what went ye forth to see? A prophet? Yea I say to you, and more than a prophet.

Lk 7:27
This is he of whom it is written: Behold I send my messenger before thy face, to prepare thy way before thee.

Lk 7:28
I say unto you: a greater prophet than Ihon, among women's children, is there none. Nevertheless one that is less in the kingdom of God, is greater than he.

Lk 7:29
And all the people that heard, and the publicans justified God, which were baptised in the baptism of Ihon.

Lk 7:30
But the pharyses and scribes despised the counsel of God, against themselves, and were not baptised of him.

Lk 7:31
And the Lord said: Whereunto shall I liken the men of this generation, and what thing are they like?

Lk 7:32
They are like unto children sitting in the market place, and crying one to another, and saying: We have piped unto you, and ye have not danced: We have mourned to you, and ye have not wept.

Lk 7:33
For Ihon baptist came unto you neither eating bread, nor drinking wine, and ye say: he hath the devil.

Lk 7:34
The son of man is come and eateth and drinketh, and ye say: behold a man which is a glutton, and a drinker of wine, the friend of publicans and sinners.

Lk 7:35
And wisdom justified of all her children.

Lk 7:36
And one of the pharises desired him that he would eat with him. And he went into the pharyse's house, and sat down to meat.

Lk 7:37
And behold a woman in that city, which was a sinner, as soon as she knew that Iesus sat at meat in the pharyse's house, she brought an alabaster box of ointment,

Lk 7:38
and she stood at his feet behind him weeping, and began to wash his feet, with tears, and did wipe them with the hairs of her head, and kissed his feet, and anointed them with ointment.

Lk 7:39
When the pharise which bade him to his house, saw that, he spake within himself: saying: If this man were a prophet, he would surely have known who and what manner woman this is which toucheth him, for she is a sinner.

Lk 7:40
And Iesus answered, and said unto him: Simon I have somewhat to say unto thee. And he said: Master say on.

Lk 7:41
There was a certain lender, which had two debtors, the one ought five hundred pence, and the other fifty.

Lk 7:42
When they had nothing to pay, he forgave them both. Which of them tell me, will love him most?

Lk 7:43
Simon answered, and said: I suppose that he to whom he forgave most. And he said unto him: Thou hast truly judged.

Lk 7:44
And he turned to the woman, and said unto Simon: Seest thou this woman? I entered into thy house, and thou gavest me no water to my feet: but she hath washed my feet with tears, and wiped them with the hairs of her head.

Lk 7:45
Thou gavest me no kiss: but she, since the time I came in, hath not ceased to kiss my feet.

Lk 7:46
Mine head with oil thou didst not anoint: but she hath anointed my feet with ointment.

Lk 7:47
Wherefore I say unto thee: many sins are forgiven her, because she loved much. To whom less is forgiven, the same doeth less love.

Lk 7:48
And he said unto her thy sins are forgiven thee.

Lk 7:49
And they that sat at meat with him, began to say within themselves: Who is this which forgiveth sins also?

Lk 7:50
And he said to the woman: Thy faith hath saved thee, Go in peace.

Lk 8:1
And it fortuned after that, he himself went throughout cities and towns, preaching, and shewing the kingdom of God, and the twelve with him.

Lk 8:2
And also certain women, which were healed of evil spirits, and infirmities: Mary called Magdalen, out of whom went seven devils,

Lk 8:3
and Ioanna the wife of Chusa, Herode's steward, And Susanna, And many other: which ministered unto him of their substance.

Lk 8:4
When much people were gathered to gether, and were come to him out of the cities, he spake by a similitude:

Lk 8:5
A sower went out to sow his seed, and as he sowed, some fell by the way side, and it was trodden under feet, and the fowls of the air devoured it up.

Lk 8:6
And some fell on stone, and as soon as it was sprung up, it withered away, because it lacked moistness.

Lk 8:7
And some fell among thorns, and the thorns sprang up with it, and choked it.

Lk 8:8
And some fell on good ground, and sprang up and bare fruit, an hundred fold. And as he said these things, he cried: He that hath ears to hear, let him hear.

Lk 8:9
And his disciples asked him, saying: what manner similitude this should be.

Lk 8:10
And he said: unto you is it given to know the secrets of the kingdom of God: but to other in similitudes, that when they see, they should not see, and when they hear they should not understand.

Lk 8:11
The similitude is this. The seed is the word of God.

Lk 8:12
Those that are beside the way, are they that hear, and afterward cometh the devil, and taketh away the word out of their hearts, lest they should believe and be saved.

Lk 8:13
They on the stones, are they which when they hear the word receive it with joy. And these have no roots, which for a while believe, and in time of temptation go away.

Lk 8:14
That which fell among thorns, are they which hear, and go forth, and are choked with cares and riches, and voluptuous living, and bring forth no fruit.

Lk 8:15
That in the good ground, are they which with a good and pure heart, hear the word, and keep it, and bring forth fruit with patience.

Lk 8:16
No man lighteth a candle, and covereth it under a vessel, neither putteth it under the table: but setteth it on a candlestick, that they that enter in, may see light.

Lk 8:17
No thing is in secret, that shall not come abroad: Neither any thing hid, that shall not be known, and come to light.

Lk 8:18
Take heed therefore how ye hear. For whosoever hath, to him shall be given: And whosoever hath not, from him shall be taken, even that same which he supposeth that he hath.

Lk 8:19
Then came to him his mother and his brethren, and could not come at him for press.

Lk 8:20
And they told him saying: Thy mother and thy brethren, stand without, and would see thee.

Lk 8:21
He answered, and said unto them: my mother and my brethren are these which hear the word of God, and do it.

Lk 8:22
It chanced on a certain day that he went into a ship, and his disciples also, and he said unto them: Let us go over unto the other side of the lake. And they launched forth.

Lk 8:23
And as they sailed, he fell asleep, and there arose a storm of wind in the lake, and they were filled with water, and were in jeopardy.

Lk 8:24
And they went to him and awoke him, saying: Master, Master, we are lost. He arose and rebuked the wind, and the tempest of water, and they ceased, and it waxed calm.

Lk 8:25
And he said unto them: where is your faith? They feared and wondered, saying one to another: what fellow is this? for he commandeth both the winds and water, and they obey him?

Lk 8:26
And they sailed unto the region of the Gaderens, which is over against Galile.

Lk 8:27
As he went out of the ship to land, there met him a certain man out of the city, which had a devil long time, and ware no clothes, neither abode in any house: but among graves.

Lk 8:28
When he saw Iesus, he cried, and fell down before him, and with a loud voice said: What have I to do with thee Iesus the son of the God most highest? I beseech thee torment me not.

Lk 8:29
Then he commanded the foul spirit to come out of the man. For often times he caught him, and he was bound with chains, and kept with fetters: and he brake the bonds, and was carried of the fiend, into wilderness.

Lk 8:30
Iesus asked him saying: what is thy name? And he said: Legion, because many devils were entered into him.

Lk 8:31
And they besought him, that he would not command them to go out into the deep.

Lk 8:32
There was there by an herd of many swine, feeding on an hill, and they prayed him, that he would suffer them to enter into them. And he suffered them.

Lk 8:33
Then went the devils out of the man, and entered into the swine: And the herd took their course, and ran headlong into the lake, and were choked.

Lk 8:34
When the herdmen saw what had chanced, they fled, and told it in the city and in the villages.

Lk 8:35
And they came out to see what was done. And came to Iesus, and found the man, out of whom the devils were departed, sitting at the feet of Iesus clothed, and in his right mind, and they were afraid.

Lk 8:36
They also which saw it told them by what means he that was possessed of the devil, was healed.

Lk 8:37
And all the whole multitude of the Gaderens, besought him, that he would depart from them: for they were taken with great fear. And he gat him into the ship and returned back again.

Lk 8:38
Then the man out of whom the devils were departed, besought him, that he might be with him: But Iesus sent him away, saying:

Lk 8:39
Go home again into thine own house, and shew what things God hath done to thee. And he went his way, and preached thorowout all the city what things Iesus had done unto him.

Lk 8:40
It fortuned that when Iesus was come again, the people received him. For they all longed for him.

Lk 8:41
And behold there came a man named Iairus (and he was a ruler of the synagogue) and he fell down at Iesus' feet, and besought him that he would come into his house,

Lk 8:42
for he had but a daughter only, of twelve year of age, and she lay a dying. As he went the people thronged him.

Lk 8:43
And a woman having an issue of blood twelve year (which had spent all her substance among Physicians, neither could be helped of any)

Lk 8:44
came behind him, and touched the hem of his garment, and immediately her issue of blood staunched.

Lk 8:45
And Iesus said: Who is it that touched me? when every man denied, Peter and they that were with him, said: Master, the people thrust thee and vex thee: and thou sayest, who touched me?

Lk 8:46
And Iesus said: Somebody touched me. For I perceive that virtue is gone out of me.

Lk 8:47
When the woman saw, that she was not hid from him, she came trembling, and fell at his feet, and told him before all the people, for what cause she had touched him, and how she was healed immediately.

Lk 8:48
And he said unto her: Daughter be of good comfort. Thy faith hath made thee safe, go in peace.

Lk 8:49
While he yet spake, there came one from the rulers of the synagogi's house, which said to him: Thy daughter is dead, disease not the master.

Lk 8:50
When Iesus heard that, He answered to the maidens father saying: Fear not, believe only, and she shall be made whole.

Lk 8:51
And when he came to the house, he suffered no man to go in with him, save Peter, Iames and Ihon, and the father and the mother of the maiden.

Lk 8:52
Every body wept and sorrowed for her. And he said Weep not: for she is not dead, but sleepeth.

Lk 8:53
And they laughed him to scorn. For they knew that she was dead.

Lk 8:54
And he thrust them all out at the doors, and caught her by the hand, and cried saying: Maid arise.

Lk 8:55
And her spirit came again, and she rose straightway. And he commanded to give her meat.

Lk 8:56
And the father and the mother of her were astonied. But he warned that they should tell no man, what was done.

Lk 9:1
Then called he the xij. to gether, and gave them power, and authority, over all devils. And that they might heal diseases.

Lk 9:2
And he sent them to preach the kingdom of God, and to cure the sick.

Lk 9:3
And he said to them: Take no thing to succor you by the way: neither staff, nor scrip, neither bread neither money, neither have two coats.

Lk 9:4
And whatsoever house ye enter into there abide, and thence depart.

Lk 9:5
And whosoever will not receive you, when ye depart from that city, shake off the very dust from your feet, for a testimony against them.

Lk 9:6
They went forth, and went thorow the towns, preaching the gospel, and healing everywhere.

Lk 9:7
Herod the tetrarch heard of all that by him was done, and doubted because that it was said of some, that Ihon was risen again from death.

Lk 9:8
And of some that Helias had appeared. And of other that one of the old prophets was risen again.

Lk 9:9
And Herod said: Ihon have I beheaded: who is this of whom I hear such things? And he desired to see him.

Lk 9:10
And the Apostles returned, and told him all that they had done. And he took them and went aside into a solitary place, nye to a city called Bethsaida.

Lk 9:11
The people knew of it, and followed him. And he received them, and spake unto them of the kingdom of God. And healed them that had need to be healed.

Lk 9:12
The day began to wear away. Then came the twelve, and said unto him: send the people away, that they may go into the towns, and villages roundabout, and lodge, and get meat, for we are here in a place of wilderness.

Lk 9:13
Then said he unto them: Give ye them to eat. And they said: We have no more but five loaves and two fishes, except we should go and buy meat for all this people.

Lk 9:14
And they were about a five thousand men. He said unto his disciples: Cause them to sit down by fifties in a company.

Lk 9:15
And they did so, and made them all sit down.

Lk 9:16
He took the five loaves, and the two fishes, and looked up to heaven, and blessed them, and brake, and gave to his disciples, to set before the people.

Lk 9:17
And they all ate, and were satisfied. And there was taken up of that remained to them, twelve baskets full of broken meat.

Lk 9:18
It fortuned as he was alone praying, his disciples were with him, and he asked them saying: Who say the people that I am?

Lk 9:19
They answered and said: Ihon baptist. Some say Helias. And some say, one of the old prophets is risen again.

Lk 9:20
He said unto them: Who say ye that I am? Peter answered and said: thou art the Christ of God.

Lk 9:21
He warned and commanded them, that they should tell no man that thing,

Lk 9:22
saying: That the son of man must suffer many things, and be reproved of the seniors, and of the high priests and scribes, and be slain, and the third day rise again.

Lk 9:23
And he said to them all, if any man will come after me, let him deny himself, and take his cross on him daily, and follow me.

Lk 9:24
Whosoever will save his life, shall lose it. And whosoever shall lose his life, for my sake, the same shall save it.

Lk 9:25
For what shall it advantage a man, to win the whole world, if he lose himself: or run in damage of himself?

Lk 9:26
For whosoever is ashamed of me, and of my sayings: of him shall the son of man be ashamed, when he cometh in his own majesty, and in the majesty of his father, and of the holy angels.

Lk 9:27
I tell you of a surety: Some there are of them that here stand, which shall not taste of death till they see the kingdom of God.

Lk 9:28
And it followed about an viij. days after those sayings, he took Peter, Iames, and Ihon, and went up into a mountain to pray.

Lk 9:29
And as he prayed, the fashion of his countenance was changed, and his garment was white and shone.

Lk 9:30
And behold, two men talked with him, and they were Moses and Helias,

Lk 9:31
which appeared gloriously, and spake of his departing, which he should end at Ierusalem.

Lk 9:32
Peter and they that were with him, were heavy asleep. And when they woke, they saw his majesty, and two men standing with him.

Lk 9:33
And it chanced as they departed from him, Peter said unto Iesus: Master, it is good being here for us. Let us make three tabernacles, one for thee, and one for Moses, and one for Helias. And wist not what he said.

Lk 9:34
While he thus spake there came a cloud and shadowed them and they feared when they entered into the cloud.

Lk 9:35
And there came a voice out of the cloud saying: This is my dear son, hear him.

Lk 9:36
And as soon as the voice was past, Iesus was found alone. And they kept it close: and told no man in those days any of those things, which they had seen.

Lk 9:37
It chanced on the next day as they came down from the hill, much people came and met him.

Lk 9:38
And behold a man of the company cried out saying: Master, I beseech thee behold my son, for he is all that I have:

Lk 9:39
and see, a spirit taketh him, and suddenly he crieth, and he teareth him that he foameth again, and unethe departeth he from him, when he hath rent him:

Lk 9:40
And I have besought thy disciples to cast him out, and they could not.

Lk 9:41
Iesus answered, and said: O generation without faith, and crooked: how long shall I be with you? And shall suffer you? Bring thy son hither.

Lk 9:42
As he yet was a coming, the fiend rent him, and tare him. Iesus rebuked the unclean spirit, and healed the child, and delivered him to his father.

Lk 9:43
And they were all amazed at the mighty power of God. While they wondered every one at all things which he did: He said unto his disciples:

Lk 9:44
Let these sayings sink down into your ears. The time will come, when the son of man shall be delivered into the hands of men.

Lk 9:45
But they wist not what that word meant, and it was hid from them that they understood it not. And they feared to ask him of that saying.

Lk 9:46
Then there arose a disputation among them, who should be the greatest.

Lk 9:47
When Iesus perceived the thoughts of their hearts, he took a child, and set him hard by him,

Lk 9:48
and said unto them: Whosoever receiveth this child in my name, receiveth me. And whosoever receiveth me, receiveth him that sent me. For he that amongst you, is the least, the same shall be great.

Lk 9:49
Ihon answered and said: Master we saw one casting out devils in thy name, and we forbade him, because he followeth not with us.

Lk 9:50
And Iesus said unto him: forbid ye him not. For he that is not against you, is with you.

Lk 9:51
And it followed when the time was come that he should be received up and that he determined himself to go to Ierusalem:

Lk 9:52
and sent messengers before him. And they went, and entered into a city of the Samaritans to make ready for him.

Lk 9:53
And they would not receive him, because his face was as though he would go to Ierusalem.

Lk 9:54
When his disciples, Iames, and Ihon, saw that, they said: Lord, wilt thou that we command, that fire come down from heaven, and consume them, even as Helias did?

Lk 9:55
Iesus turned about, and rebuked them saying: ye wot not what manner spirit ye are of.

Lk 9:56
The son of man is not come to destroy men's lives, but to save them. And they went to another town.

Lk 9:57
It chanced as he went on their journey, a certain man said unto him: I will follow thee whithersoever thou go.

Lk 9:58
Iesus said unto him: foxes have holes, and birds of the air have nests: but the son of man hath not whereon to lay his head.

Lk 9:59
And he said unto another: follow me. And the same said: Lord suffer me first to go and bury my father.

Lk 9:60
Iesus said unto him. Let the dead, bury their dead: but go thou and preach the kingdom of God.

Lk 9:61
And another said: I will follow thee Lord: But let me first go bid them farewell, which are at home at my house.

Lk 9:62
Iesus said unto him: No man that putteth his hand to the plough, and looketh back, is apt to the kingdom of God.

Lk 10:1
After that, the Lord appointed other seventy also, and sent them, two and two, before his face, into every city, and place, whither he himself would come.

Lk 10:2
And said unto them: the harvest is great: but the laborers are few. Pray therefore the Lord of the harvest, to send forth laborers into his harvest.

Lk 10:3
Go your ways. Behold, I send you forth as lambs among wolves.

Lk 10:4
Bear no wallet, neither scrip, nor shoes, and salute no man by the way.

Lk 10:5
In whatsoever house ye enter in, first say: Peace be to this house.

Lk 10:6
And if the son of peace be there, your peace shall rest upon him, if not, it shall return to you again.

Lk 10:7
And in the same house tarry still eating and drinking, such as they have. For the laborer is worthy of his reward. Go not from house to house:

Lk 10:8
and into whatsoever city ye enter, if they receive you, eat whatsoever is set before you,

Lk 10:9
and heal the sick that are there, and say unto them: the kingdom of God is come nye upon you.

Lk 10:10
But into whatsoever city ye shall enter, if they receive you not, go your ways out into the streets of the same, and say:

Lk 10:11
even the very dust, which cleaveth on us of your city, we wipe off against you: Notwithstanding, mark this, that the kingdom of God was come nye upon you.

Lk 10:12
Yea and I say unto you: that it shall be easier in that day, for Sodom than for that city.

Lk 10:13
Woe be to thee Chorazin: woe be to thee Bethsaida. For if the miracles had been done in Tyre and Sidon, which have been done in you, they had a great while agone repented, sitting in hair and ashes.

Lk 10:14
Nevertheless it shall be easier for Tyre and Sidon, at the judgement, than for you.

Lk 10:15
And thou Capernaum which art exalted to heaven, shalt be thrust down to hell.

Lk 10:16
whosoever heareth you, heareth me: And whosoever despiseth you, despiseth me. And he that despiseth me, despiseth him that sent me.

Lk 10:17
The seventy returned again with joy saying: Lord even the very devils are subdued to us thorow thy name.

Lk 10:18
And he said unto them: I saw sathan, as it had been lightning, fall down from heaven.

Lk 10:19
Behold I give unto you power to tread on serpents, and scorpions, and upon all manner power of the enemy, and nothing shall hurt you.

Lk 10:20
Nevertheless, in this rejoice not, that the spirits are under your power: But rejoice because your names are written in heaven.

Lk 10:21
That same time rejoiced Iesus in the spirit, and said: I praise thee father Lord of heaven and earth, because thou hast hid these things from the wise and prudent, and hast opened them to the foolish. Even so father, for so pleased it thee.

Lk 10:22
All things are given me of my father. And no man knoweth who the son is, but the father: neither who the father is, save the son, and he to whom the son will shew him.

Lk 10:23
And he turned to his disciples, and said secretly: Happy are the eyes, which see that ye see.

Lk 10:24
For I tell you that many prophets and kings have desired to see those things which ye see, and have not seen them: And to hear those things which ye hear, and have not heard them:

Lk 10:25
And mark, A Certain Lawyer stood up, and tempted him saying: Master what shall I do, to inherit eternal life?

Lk 10:26
He said unto him: What is written in the law? How readest thou?

Lk 10:27
And he answered and said: Thou shalt love thy Lord God, with all thy heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy strength, and with all thy mind: and thy neighbor as thyself.

Lk 10:28
And he said unto him: Thou hast answered right. This do and thou shalt live.

Lk 10:29
He willing to justify himself, said unto Iesus: Who is then my neighbor?

Lk 10:30
Iesus answered and said: A certain man descended from Ierusalem into Ierico, And fell into the hands of thieves, which robbed him of his raiment and wounded him, and departed leaving him half dead.

Lk 10:31
And it chanced that there came a certain priest that same way, and saw him, and passed by.

Lk 10:32
And like wise a levite, when he was come nye to the place, went and looked on him, and passed by.

Lk 10:33
Then a certain Samaritan, as he journeyed, came nye unto him, and beheld him, and had compassion on him,

Lk 10:34
and came to him, and bound up his wounds, and poured in wine, and oil, and laid him on his beast, and brought him to a common hostry, and drest him.

Lk 10:35
And on the morrow when he departed, he took out two pence, and gave them to the host and said unto him: Take care of him, and whatsoever thou spendest above this, when I come again I will recompense thee.

Lk 10:36
Which now of these three, thinkest thou was neighbor unto him that fell into the thieves hands?

Lk 10:37
And he answered: he that shewed mercy on him. Then said Iesus unto him. Go and do thou likewise.

Lk 10:38
It fortuned as they went, that he entered into a certain town. And a certain woman named Martha, received him into her house.

Lk 10:39
And this woman had a sister called Mary, which sat at Iesus' feet, and heard Iesus preaching:

Lk 10:40
Martha was cumbered about much serving, and stood and said: Master, dost thou not care, that my sister hath left me to minister alone? Bid her therefore, that she help me.

Lk 10:41
And Iesus answered, and said unto her: Martha, Martha, thou art busied, and troublest thyself, about many things:

Lk 10:42
verily one is needful, Mary hath chosen her a good part, which shall not be taken away from her.

Lk 11:1
And it fortuned as he was praying in a certain place: when he ceased, one of his disciples said unto him: Master teach us to pray, As Ihon taught his disciples.

Lk 11:2
And he said unto them: When ye pray, say: Our father which art in heaven, hallowed by thy name. Let thy kingdom come. Thy will, be fulfilled, even in earth as it is in heaven.

Lk 11:3
Our daily bread give us this day.

Lk 11:4
And forgive us our sins: For even we forgive every man that trespasseth us, and lead us not into temptation, But deliver us from evil Amen.

Lk 11:5
And he said unto them: which of you shall have a friend and shall go to him at midnight, and say unto him: friend lend me four loaves

Lk 11:6
for a friend of mine is come out of the way to me, and I have nothing to set before him:

Lk 11:7
And he within should answer and say: Trouble me not, now is the door shut, and my servants are with me in the chamber, I cannot rise and give them to thee.

Lk 11:8
I say unto you: though he would not arise and give him, because he is his friend: Yet because of his importunity he would rise and give him as many as he needeth.

Lk 11:9
And I say unto you: ask, and it shall be given you. Seek, and ye shall find. Knock, and it shall be opened unto you.

Lk 11:10
For every one that asketh, receiveth: and he that seeketh, findeth: and to him that knocketh shall it be opened.

Lk 11:11
If the son shall ask bread of any of you which is his father: will he proffer him a stone? Or if he ask fish, will he give him a serpent?

Lk 11:12
Or if he ask an egg: will he proffer him a scorpion?

Lk 11:13
If ye then which are evil, know how to give good gifts unto your children? How much more shall your father celestial, give a good spirit to them, that desire it of him.

Lk 11:14
And he was a casting out a devil, which was dumb. And it followed when the devil was gone out, the dumb spake, and the people wondered.

Lk 11:15
Some of them said: he casteth out devils by the power of Belzebub, the chief of the devils.

Lk 11:16
And other tempted him seeking of him a sign from heaven.

Lk 11:17
He knew their thoughts, and said unto them: Every kingdom, at debate within itself shall be desolate: and one house shall fall upon another.

Lk 11:18
So if Satan be at variance within himself: how shall his kingdom endure? Be cause ye say that I cast out devils by the power of Belzebub?

Lk 11:19
If I by the power of Belzebub cast out devils: by whose power, do your children cast them out? Therefore shall they be your judges.

Lk 11:20
But if I with the finger of God cast out devils, no doubt, the kingdom of God is come upon you.

Lk 11:21
When a strong man armed watcheth his house: That he possesseth, is in peace.

Lk 11:22
But when a stronger than he cometh upon him, and overcometh him: he taketh from him, his harness, wherein he trusted, and divideth his goods.

Lk 11:23
He that is not with me is against me. And he that gathereth not with me scattereth.

Lk 11:24
When the unclean spirit is gone out of a man, he walketh through waterless places seeking rest. And when he findeth none, he sayeth: I will return again unto my house whence I came out.

Lk 11:25
And when he cometh, he findeth it swept and garnished.

Lk 11:26
Then goeth he and taketh seven other spirits with him worse than himself, and they enter in, and dwell there. And the end of that man, is worse than the beginning.

Lk 11:27
It fortuned as he thus spake, a certain woman of the company lifted up her voice, and said unto him: Happy is the womb that bare thee and the paps, which gave thee suck.

Lk 11:28
But he said: Happy are they that hear the word of God, and keep it.

Lk 11:29
When the people were gathered thick togeder: He began to say: This is an evil nation. They seek a sign, and there shall no sign be given them, but the sign of Ionas the prophet.

Lk 11:30
For as Ionas was a sign to the Ninivites, so shall the son of man be to this nation.

Lk 11:31
The queen of the south shall rise at the judgement, with the men of this generation, and condemn them. For she came from the end of the world, to hear the wisdom of Solomon: and behold a greater than Solomon is here.

Lk 11:32
The men of Nineveh shall rise at the judgement, with this generation, and shall condemn them: for they repented at the preaching of Ionas: And behold, a greater than Ionas is here.

Lk 11:33
No man lighteth a candle, and putteth it in a privy place, neither under a bushel: But on a candlestick, that they that come in, may see the light.

Lk 11:34
The light of thy body is the eye. Therefore, when thine eye is single: then is all thy body full of light. But if thine eye be evil: then shall all thy body also be full of darkness.

Lk 11:35
Take heed therefore that the light which is in thee, be not darkness.

Lk 11:36
For if all thy body shall be light, having no part dark: then shall all be full of light, even as when a candle doeth light thee with his brightness.

Lk 11:37
And as he spake, a certain pharise besought him to dine with him: and Iesus went in, and sat down to meat.

Lk 11:38
When the pharise saw that he marvelled that he had not first washed before dinner.

Lk 11:39
And the Lord said to him: Now do ye, O pharises, make clean the outside of the cup, and of the platter: but your inward parts are full of ravening and wickedness.

Lk 11:40
Ye fools did not he that made that which is without: make that which is within also?

Lk 11:41
Nevertheless ye give of that ye have, and behold all is clean to you.

Lk 11:42
But woe be to you pharises, for ye tithe the mint, and rue, and all manner herbs, and pass over judgement, and the love of God. These ought ye to have done, and not to have left the other undone.

Lk 11:43
Woe be to you pharises: for ye love the uppermost seats in the synagogues, and greetings in the markets.

Lk 11:44
Woe be to you scribes and pharises hypocrites, for ye are as graves which appear not, And men that walk over them, are not ware of them.

Lk 11:45
Then answered one of the lawyers, and said unto him: Master, thus saying, thou puttest us to rebuke also.

Lk 11:46
Then he said: Woe be to you also ye lawyers: for ye lade men with burdens grievous to be born, and ye yourselves touch not the packs with one of your fingers.

Lk 11:47
Woe be to you that build the sepulchers of the prophets: for your fathers killed them:

Lk 11:48
Truly ye bear witness, that ye allow the deeds of your fathers: for they killed them, and ye build their sepulchers.

Lk 11:49
Therefore said the wisdom of God: I will send them prophets and Apostles, and of them they shall slay and persecute:

Lk 11:50
That the blood of all prophets, which was shed from the beginning of the world, may be required of this generation,

Lk 11:51
from the blood of Abel unto the blood of Zacary, which perished between the altar and the temple. Verily I say unto you: it shall be required of this nation.

Lk 11:52
Woe be to you lawyers: for ye have taken away the key of knowledge, ye entered not in yourselves, and them that came in ye forbade.

Lk 11:53
When he thus spake unto them, the lawyers, and the pharises, began to wax busy about him and to stop his mouth with many questions,

Lk 11:54
Laying wait for him, and seeking to catch something of his mought, whereby they might accuse him.

Lk 12:1
As there gathered togedther an innumerable multitude of people (insomuch that they trod one another) he began to say unto his disciples: First of all beware of the leaven of the pharises, which is hypocrisy.

Lk 12:2
For there is nothing covered, that shall not be uncovered: neither hid, that shall not be known.

Lk 12:3
Wherefore whatsoever ye have spoken in darkness: that same shall be heard in light. And that which ye have spoken in the ear, even in secret places, shall be preached even on the top of the houses.

Lk 12:4
I say unto you my friends: fear ye not them that kill the body, and after that have nothing that he can more do.

Lk 12:5
I will shew you, whom ye shall fear. Fear him which after he hath killed, hath power to cast into hell. Yea I say unto you, him fear.

Lk 12:6
Are not five sparrows bought for two farthings? and none of them is forgotten of God.

Lk 12:7
Yea the very hairs of your heads are numbered. Fear not therefore: Ye are more of value, than many sparrows.

Lk 12:8
I say unto you: Whosoever confesseth me before men, even him shall the son of man confess also before the angels of God.

Lk 12:9
And he that denieth me before men: shall be denied before the angels of God.

Lk 12:10
And whosoever speaketh a word against the son of man it shall be forgiven him. But unto him that blasphemeth the holy ghost, it shall not be forgiven.

Lk 12:11
When they bring you unto their synagogues, and unto their rulers, and officers, take no thought how or what thing ye shall answer, or what ye shall speak.

Lk 12:12
For the holy ghost shall teach you in the same hour, what ye ought to say.

Lk 12:13
One of the company said unto him: Master, bid my brother divide the inheritance with me.

Lk 12:14
And he said unto him: Man, who made me a judge, or a divider over you?

Lk 12:15
Wherefore he said unto them: take heed, and beware of covetousness. For no man's life standeth in the abundance of the things which he possesseth.

Lk 12:16
And he put forth a similitude unto them saying: The lands of a certain man brought forth fruits plenteously,

Lk 12:17
and he thought in himself saying: what shall I do? because I have no room where to bestow my fruits?

Lk 12:18
And he said: This will I do. I will destroy my barns, and build greater, and therein will I gather all my fruits, and my goods:

Lk 12:19
and I will say to my soul: Soul thou hast much goods laid up in store for many years, take thine ease: eat, drink and be merry.

Lk 12:20
But God said unto him: Thou fool, this night will they fetch away thy soul again from thee. Then whose shall those things be which thou hast provided?

Lk 12:21
So is it with him that gathered riches, and is not rich in God.

Lk 12:22
And he spake unto his disciples: Therefore I say unto you: Take no thought for your life, what ye shall eat: Neither for your body, what ye shall put on.

Lk 12:23
The life is more than meat, and the body is more than raiment.

Lk 12:24
Mark well the ravens, for they neither sow, nor reap, which neither have storehouse nor barn, and yet God feedeth them. How much are ye better then the fowls.

Lk 12:25
Which of you with taking thought can add to his stature one cubit?

Lk 12:26
If ye then be not able to do that thing which is least: why take ye thought for the remnant?

Lk 12:27
Consider the lilies how they grow: They labor not: They spin not: and I say unto you, Solomon in all his royalty was not clothed like unto one of these.

Lk 12:28
If God then so clothe the grass which is to day in the fields, and tomorrow shall be cast into the furnace: how much more will he clothe you, o ye endued with little faith?

Lk 12:29
And ask not what ye shall eat, or what ye shall drink, neither climb ye up on high:

Lk 12:30
for all such things the heathen people of the world seek for. Your father knoweth that ye have need of such things.

Lk 12:31
Wherefore seek ye after the kingdom of heaven, and all these things shall be ministered unto you.

Lk 12:32
Fear not little flock, for it is your father's pleasure, to give you a kingdom.

Lk 12:33
Sell that ye have, and give alms. And make you bags, which wax not old, and treasure that faileth not in heaven, where no thief cometh, neither moth corrupteth.

Lk 12:34
For where your treasure is, There will your hearts be also.

Lk 12:35
Let your loins be girded about, and your lights burning,

Lk 12:36
and ye yourselves, like unto men, that watch for their master when he will return from a wedding: that as soon as he cometh and knocketh, they may open unto him.

Lk 12:37
Happy are those servants, which their Lord, when he cometh, shall find walking, Verily I say unto you, he will gird himself about, and make them sit down to meat, and walk by them, and minister unto them.

Lk 12:38
And if he come in the second watch, ye if he come in the third watch, and shall find them so, happy are those servants.

Lk 12:39
This shall ye understand, that if the good man of the house, had known what hour the thief would have come, he would surely have watched: and not have suffered his house to have been broken up.

Lk 12:40
Be ye prepared therefore for the son of man will come at an hour when ye think, not.

Lk 12:41
Then Peter said unto him: Master tellest thou this similitude unto us, or to all men?

Lk 12:42
And the Lord said: who is a faithful steward, and a discreet, whom his lord shall make ruler over his household, to give them their duetie of meat, at due season.

Lk 12:43
Happy is that servant, whom his master when he cometh shall find so doing.

Lk 12:44
Of a truth I say unto you: that he will make him ruler over all that he hath.

Lk 12:45
But and if the evil servant shall say in his heart: My master will defer his coming, and shall begin to smite the servants, and maidens, and to eat and drink, and to be drunken:

Lk 12:46
the lord of that servant will come in a day, when he thinketh not, and at an hour when he is not ware, and will divide him, and will give him his reward, with the unbelievers.

Lk 12:47
The servant that knew his master's will, and prepared not himself, neither did according to his will, shall be beaten with many stripes.

Lk 12:48
But he that knew not, and hath committed things worthy of stripes, shall be beaten with few stripes. For unto whom much is given: of him shall be much required. And to whom men much commit, the more of him will they ask.

Lk 12:49
I am come to send fire on earth: and what is my desire but that it were al ready kindled?

Lk 12:50
Notwithstanding I must be baptised with a baptism. And how am I pained till it be ended?

Lk 12:51
Suppose ye that I am come to send peace on earth? I tell you, nay: but rather debate.

Lk 12:52
For henceforth there shall be five in one house divided, three against two, and two against three.

Lk 12:53
The father shall be divided against the son, and the son against the father. The mother against the daughter, and the daughter against the mother. The motherinlaw against the daughterinlaw, and the daughter in law against the motherinlaw.

Lk 12:54
Then said he to the people: when ye see a cloud rise out of the west straightway ye say: we shall have a shower, and so it is.

Lk 12:55
And when ye se the south wind blow, ye say: we shall have heat, and it cometh to pass.

Lk 12:56
Hypocrites, ye can skill of the fashion of the earth, and of the sky: but what is the cause, that ye cannot skill of this time?

Lk 12:57
Yea and why judge ye not of yourselves, that which is rightwise?

Lk 12:58
While thou goest with thine adversary to the ruler: as thou art in the way, give diligence that thou mayest be delivered from him, least he bring thee to the judge, and the judge deliver thee to the jailer, and the jailer cast thee into prison.

Lk 12:59
I tell thee thou departest not thence, till thou have made good the utmost farthing.

Lk 13:1
There were present at the same season, that shewed him of the Galileans, whose blood Pilate mingled with their own sacrifice.

Lk 13:2
And Iesus answered, and said unto them: Suppose ye that these Galileans, were greater sinners then all the other Galileans because they suffered such punishment?

Lk 13:3
I tell you nay: but except ye repent, ye shall all likewise perish.

Lk 13:4
Or think ye that those xviij. upon whom the tower in Siloe fell and slew them, were sinners above all men that dwell in Ierusalem?

Lk 13:5
I tell you nay: But except ye repent, ye all shall likewise perish.

Lk 13:6
He put forth this similitude, A certain man had a fig tree in his vineyard, and he came and sought fruit thereon, and found none.

Lk 13:7
Then said he to the dresser of his vineyard: Behold this three year have I come and sought fruit in this fig tree, and find none, cut it down: why cumbereth it the ground?

Lk 13:8
And he answered and said unto him: Lord let it alone this year also, till I dig round about it, and dung it,

Lk 13:9
to see whether it will bear fruit: if not, then after that, cut it down.

Lk 13:10
He taught in one of their synagogues on the saboth days.

Lk 13:11
And behold there was a woman which had a spirit of infirmity xviij. years: and was bowed to gether, and could not well lift up herself.

Lk 13:12
When Iesus saw her, he called her to him, and said to her: woman, thou art delivered from thy disease.

Lk 13:13
And he laid his hands on her, and immediately she was made straight, and glorified God.

Lk 13:14
The ruler of the synagogue answered with indignation (because that Iesus had healed on the saboth day) And said unto the people: There are six days in the week, in which men ought to work, in them come and be healed, and not on the saboth day.

Lk 13:15
Then answered him the Lord and said: Hypocrite, doth not each one of you on the saboth day, loose his ox, or his ass, from the stall, and lead him to the water?

Lk 13:16
And ought not this daughter of Abraham, be loosed from this bond on the saboth day, whom Sathan hath bounde lo, xviij. years?

Lk 13:17
And when he thus said, all his adversaries were ashamed, and all the people rejoiced on all the excellent deeds, that were done by him.

Lk 13:18
Then said he: What is the kingdom of God like? or whereto shall I compare it?

Lk 13:19
It is like a grain of mustard seed, which a man took and sowed in his garden: and it grew, and waxed a great tree, and the fowls of the air built in the branches of it.

Lk 13:20
And again he said: whereunto shall I liken the kingdom of , God?

Lk 13:21
It is like leaven, which a woman took, and hid in three bushels of flour, till all was thorow leavened.

Lk 13:22
And he went thorow cities and towns teaching, and took his journey towards Ierusalem.

Lk 13:23
Then said one unto him: Lord, are there few that shall be saved? And he said unto them:

Lk 13:24
strive with your selves to enter in at the strait gate: For many I say unto you, will seek to enter in, and shall not be able.

Lk 13:25
When the goodman of the house is risen up, and hath shut fast the door, and ye begin to stand without, and to knock at the door saying: Lord, Lord, open unto us: and he shall answer and say unto you: I know not whence ye are.

Lk 13:26
Then shall ye begin to say: We have eaten, and drunk in thy presence, and thou hast taught in our streets.

Lk 13:27
And he shall say: I tell you, I know you not whence ye are: depart from me all ye workers of iniquity.

Lk 13:28
There shall be weeping, and gnashing of teeth: when ye shall see Abraham, and Isaac, and Iacob, and all the prophets in the kingdom of God, and yourselves thrust out a doors.

Lk 13:29
And they shall come from the east, and from the west, and from the north, and from the south, and shall rest in the kingdom of God.

Lk 13:30
And behold, there are last, which shall be first: And there are first which shall be last.

Lk 13:31
The same day there came certain of the pharises, and said unto him: Get thee out of the way, and depart hence: for Herod will kill thee.

Lk 13:32
And he said unto them: Go ye and tell that fox, behold I cast out devils, and heal the people to day and tomorrow, and the third day I make an end.

Lk 13:33
Nevertheless, I must walk today and tomorrow, and the day following: For it cannot be, that a prophet perish any other where, save at Ierusalem.

Lk 13:34
O Ierusalem, Ierusalem, which killest prophets, and stonest them that are sent to thee: how often would I have gathered thy children together, as the hen her nest under her wings, but thou wouldest not.

Lk 13:35
Behold your habitation shall be left unto you desolate. For I tell you, ye shall not see me until the time come that ye shall say, blessed is he that cometh in the name of the Lord.

Lk 14:1
And it chanced that he went into the house of one of the chief pharises to eat bread, on a saboth day: and they watched him.

Lk 14:2
And behold there was a man before him, which had the dropsy.

Lk 14:3
And Iesus answered and spake unto the lawyers and pharises, saying: is it lawful to heal on the saboth day?

Lk 14:4
And they held their peace. He took the man and healed him, and let him go:

Lk 14:5
And answered them saying: which of you shall have an ass, or an ox, fallen into a pit, and will not straightway pull him out on the saboth day?

Lk 14:6
And they could not answer him again to that.

Lk 14:7
He put forth a similitude to the guests, when he marked how they pressed to the highest rooms, and said unto them:

Lk 14:8
When thou art bidden to a wedding of any man, sit not down in the highest room, lest a more honorable man than thou be bidden of him,

Lk 14:9
and he that bade both him and thee, come and say to thee: give this man room. And thou then begin with shame to take the lowest room.

Lk 14:10
But rather when thou art bidden, go and sit in the lowest room, that when he that bade thee cometh, he may say unto thee: friend sit up higher. Then shalt thou have praise in the presence of them that sit at meat with thee.

Lk 14:11
For whosoever exalteth himself, shall be brought low. And he that humbleth himself, shall be exalted.

Lk 14:12
Then said he also to him that had desired to him to dinner: When thou makest a dinner, or a supper: call not thy friends, nor thy brethren, neither thy kinsmen, nor yet rich neighbours: lest they bid thee again, and make thee recompense.

Lk 14:13
But when thou makest a feast, call the poor, the maimed, the lame, and the blind,

Lk 14:14
and thou shalt be happy: For they cannot recompense thee. But thou shalt be recompensed at the resurrection of the just men.

Lk 14:15
When one of them that sat at meat also heard that, he said unto him: happy is he that eateth bread in the kingdom of God.

Lk 14:16
Then said he to him: A certain man ordained a great supper, and bade many,

Lk 14:17
and sent his servant at supper time, to say to them that were bidden, come: for all things are now ready.

Lk 14:18
And they all at once began to make excuse. The first said unto him: I have bought a farm, and I must needs go and see it, I pray thee have me excused.

Lk 14:19
And another said: I have bought five yoke of oxen, and I must go to prove them, I pray thee have me excused.

Lk 14:20
The third said: I have married a wife, and therefore I cannot come.

Lk 14:21
And the servant went again, and brought his master word thereof. Then was the good man of the house displeased, and said to his servant: Go out quickly into the streets and quarters of the city, and bring in hither the poor, and the maimed, and the halt, and the blind.

Lk 14:22
And the servant said: lord it is done as thou commandedst, and yet there is room.

Lk 14:23
And the lord said to the servant: Go out into the highways and hedges, and compel them to come in, that my house may be filled.

Lk 14:24
For I say unto you, that none of those men which were bidden, shall taste of my supper.

Lk 14:25
There went a great company with him, and he turned and said unto them:

Lk 14:26
If a man come to me, and hate not his father and mother, and wife, and children, and brethren, and sisters, moreover and his own life, he cannot be my disciple.

Lk 14:27
And whosoever bear not his cross, and come after me cannot be my disciple.

Lk 14:28
Which of you is he that is disposed to build a tower, and sitteth not down before and counteth the cost: Whether he have sufficient to perform it?

Lk 14:29
lest after he hath laid the foundation, and is not able to perform it, all that behold it, begin to mock him

Lk 14:30
saying: This man began to build, and was not able to make an end.

Lk 14:31
What king goeth to make battle against another king, and sitteth not down first, and casteth in his mind, whether he be able with ten thousand to meet him that cometh against him with twenty thousand,

Lk 14:32
or else while the other is yet a great way off, he will send ambassadors, and desire peace.

Lk 14:33
So likewise, none of you that forsaketh not all that he hath, can be my disciple.

Lk 14:34
Salt is good, but if salt be corrupt, what shall be seasoned therewith?

Lk 14:35
It is neither good for the land, nor yet for the dunghill, men cast it out at the doors. He that hath ears to hear, let him hear.

Lk 15:1
Then resorted unto him all the publicans and sinners, for to hear him.

Lk 15:2
And the pharises, and scribes grudged saying: He received to his company sinners, and eateth with them.

Lk 15:3
Then put he forth this similitude to them saying:

Lk 15:4
What man of you having an hundred sheep, if he lose one of them doth not leave ninety and nine in the wilderness, and go after him which is lost, until he find him?

Lk 15:5
And when he hath found him, he putteth him on his shoulders with joy:

Lk 15:6
And as soon as he cometh home he calleth together his lovers, and neighbours saying unto them: rejoice with me for I have found my sheep which was lost.

Lk 15:7
I say unto you, that likewise joy shall be in heaven over one sinner that repenteth, more than over ninety and nine just persons, which need no repentance.

Lk 15:8
Other what woman having x. grotes, if she lose one, doth not light a candle, and sweep the house, and seek diligently, till she find it?

Lk 15:9
And when she hath found it she calleth her lovers, and her neighbours saying: Rejoice with me, for I have found the grote which I had lost.

Lk 15:10
Likewise I say unto you, joy shall be in the presence of the angels of God over one sinner that repenteth.

Lk 15:11
And he said: a certain man had two sons,

Lk 15:12
and the younger of them said to his father: father give me my part of the goods that to me belongeth. And he divided unto them his substance.

Lk 15:13
And not long after, the younger son gathered all that he had together, and took his journey into a far country, and there he wasted his goods with riotous living.

Lk 15:14
And when he had spent all that he had, there rose a great dearth thorowout all that same land. And he began to lack.

Lk 15:15
And he went, and clave to a citizen of that same country, which sent him to his field, to keep his swine.

Lk 15:16
And he would fain have filled his belly with the cods, that the swine ate: and no man gave him.

Lk 15:17
Then he came to himself and said: how many hired servants at my father's have bread enough, and I die for hunger.

Lk 15:18
I will arise, and go to my father, and will say unto him: father, I have sinned against heaven and before thee,

Lk 15:19
now am I not worthy to be called thy son, make me as one of thy hired servants.

Lk 15:20
And he arose, and came to his father. When he was yet a great way off, his father saw him, and had compassion, and ran unto him, and fell on his neck, and kissed him.

Lk 15:21
And the son said unto him: father I have sinned against heaven, and in thy sight, neither am I worthy henceforth to be called thy son.

Lk 15:22
Then said the father to his servants: bring forth that best garment, and put it on him, and put a ring on his hand, and shoes on his feet.

Lk 15:23
And bring hither that fatted calf, and kill him, and let us eat and be merry:

Lk 15:24
for this my son was dead, and is alive again. He was lost, and is now found. And they began to make good chear.

Lk 15:25
The elder brother was in the field, and when he came and drew nye to the house, he heard minstrelsy, and dancing,

Lk 15:26
and called one of his servants, and asked what those things meant.

Lk 15:27
He said unto him: thy brother is come, and thy father had killed the fatted calf, because he hath received him safe and sound.

Lk 15:28
And he was angry, and would not go in. Then came his father out, and entreated him,

Lk 15:29
he answered and said to his father: Lo these many years have I done thee service, neither brake at any time thy commandment, and yet gavest thou me never so much as a kid to make merry with my lovers:

Lk 15:30
but as soon as this thy son was come, which hath devoured thy goods with harlots, thou hast for his pleasure killed the fatted calf.

Lk 15:31
And he said unto him: Son, thou wast ever with me, and all that I have is thine:

Lk 15:32
it was meet that we should make merry and be glad: for this thy brother was dead, and is alive again: and was lost, and is found.

Lk 16:1
