These all continued with one accord, in prayer, and supplication with the women, and Mary the mother of Iesu. And with his brethren.

Acts 1:15
And in those days Peter stood up in the midst of the disciples and said (The number of names were about an hundred and twenty)

Acts 1:16
Ye men and brethren, this scripture must needs be fulfilled which the holy ghost thorow the mouth of David spake before of Iudas, which was guide to them that took Iesus.

Acts 1:17
For he was now numbered with us and obtained fellowship in this ministration.

Acts 1:18
And the same hath now possessed a plot of ground with the reward of iniquity. And when he was hanged, burst asunder in the midst, and all his bowels gushed out.

Acts 1:19
And it is known unto all the inhabiters of Ierusalem. Insomuch that that field is called in their mother tongue, Acheldema, that is to say the blood field.

Acts 1:20
It is written in the book of psalms: His habitation be void, and no man be dwelling therein: and his bisshoprycke let another take.

Acts 1:21
Wherefore of these men which have companied with us (all the time that the Lord Iesus went out and in among us,

Acts 1:22
beginning at the baptism of Ihon unto that same day that he was taken up from us) must one be ordained to be a witness with us of his resurrection.

Acts 1:23
And they appointed two, Ioseph called Barsabas (whose surname was Iustus) and Matthias.

Acts 1:24
And they prayed saying: Thou Lord which knowest the hearts of all men, shew whether thou hast chosen of these two,

Acts 1:25
that the one may take the room of this ministration, and apostleship from the which Iudas by transgression fell, that he might go to his own place.

Acts 1:26
And they gave forth their lots, and the lot fell on Mathias. And he was counted with the eleven apostles.

Acts 2:1
When the fiftieth day was come, they were all with one accord gathered together in one place.

Acts 2:2
And suddenly there came a sound from heaven as it had been the coming of a mighty wind, and it filled all the house where they sat.

Acts 2:3
And there appeared unto them cloven tongues, as they had been fire, and it sat upon each of them:

Acts 2:4
and they were all filled with the holy ghost, and began to speak with other tongues, even as the spirit gave them utterance.

Acts 2:5
There were dwelling at Ierusalem iewes, devout men, which were of all nations under heaven.

Acts 2:6
When this was noised about, the multitude came to gether and were astonied, because that every man heard them speak his own tongue.

Acts 2:7
They wondered all, and marvelled saying among themselves: Look, are not all these which speak of Galile?

Acts 2:8
And how hear we every man his own tongue wherein we were born?

Acts 2:9
Parthians, Medes, and Elamites and the inhabiters of Mesopotamia, of Jury, Capadocia, Ponthus, and of Asia,

Acts 2:10
Phrigia, Pamphlia, and of Egypt, and of the parts of Libia, which is beside Syrene, And strangers of Rome,

Acts 2:11
Jewes and Proselites, Greeks and Arabians: We have heard them speak with our own tongues the great works of God.

Acts 2:12
They were all amazed, and wondered saying one to another: what meaneth this?

Acts 2:13
Other mocked them saying: They are full of new wine.

Acts 2:14
Peter stepped forth with the eleven, and lift up his voice, and said unto them: Ye men of Jewry, and all ye that inhabit Ierusalem: be this known unto you, and with your ears hear my words.

Acts 2:15
These are not drunken, as ye wene: For it is yet but the third hour of the day:

Acts 2:16
but this is that which was spoken by the prophet Ioel:

Acts 2:17
It shall be in the last days (saith God) of my spirit I will pour out upon all flesh. And your sons, and your daughters shall prophesy, your young men shall see visions. And your old men shall dream dreams.

Acts 2:18
And on my servants, and on my hand maidens I will pour out of my spirit in those days, And they shall prophesy.

Acts 2:19
And I will shew wonders in heaven above, and tokens in the earth beneath, blood and fire, and the vapour of smoke.

Acts 2:20
The sun shall be turned into darkness, and the moon into blood, before that great, and notable day of the Lord come.

Acts 2:21
And the time shall come that whosoever shall call on the name of the Lord, shall be saved.

Acts 2:22
Ye men of Israhel, hear these words. Iesus of Nazareth, a man approved of God among you with miracles and wonders, and signs which God did by him in the midst of you, as ye yourselves know:

Acts 2:23
him have ye taken by the hands of unrighteous persons, after he was delivered by the determinate counsel and foreknowledge of God, and have crucified and slain him,

Acts 2:24
whom God hath raised up and lowsed the sorrows of death, because it was impossible that he should be holden of it.

Acts 2:25
David speaketh of him: Aforehand, saw I God always before me: For he is on my right hand, that I should not be moved.

Acts 2:26
Therefore did my heart rejoice, and my tongue was glad. Moreover also, my flesh shall rest in hope

Acts 2:27
because thou shalt not leave my soul in hell, neither shalt suffer thy saint to see corruption.

Acts 2:28
Thou hast shewed me the ways of life, Thou shalt make me full of joy with thy countenance.

Acts 2:29
Men and brethren, let me freely speak unto you of the patriarch David: For he is both dead and buried, and his sepulchre remaineth with us unto his day.

Acts 2:30
Therefore since he was a prophet, and knew that God had sworn with an oath to him, that the fruit of his loins should sit on his seat:

Acts 2:31
He saw before, and spake of the resurrection of Christ, that his soul should not be left in hell: neither his flesh should see corruption.

Acts 2:32
This Iesus hath God raised up, whereof we all are witnesses.

Acts 2:33
Since now that he by the right hand of God exalted is, and hath received of the father the promise of the holy ghost, he hath shed forth that which ye now see and hear.

Acts 2:34
For David is not ascended into heaven, but he said: The Lord said to my Lord sit on my right hand,

Acts 2:35
until I make thy foes, thy foot stool.

Acts 2:36
So therefore let all the house of Israhel know for a surety, that God hath made the same Iesus whom ye have crucified, Lord and Christ.

Acts 2:37
When they heard this, they were pricked in their hearts, and said unto Peter, and unto the other apostles: Ye men and brethren, what shall we do?

Acts 2:38
Peter said unto them: Repent and be baptised every one of you in the name of Iesus Christ, For the remission of sins, and ye shall receive the gift of the holy ghost.

Acts 2:39
For the promise was made unto you, and to your children, and to all that are afar, even as many as our Lord God shall call.

Acts 2:40
And with many other words bare he witness, and exhorted them saying: Save yourselves from this untoward generation.

Acts 2:41
They that gladly received his preaching were baptised, And the same day, there were added unto them about a three thousand souls.

Acts 2:42
And they continued in the Apostles' doctrine and fellowship, and in breaking of bread, and in prayer.

Acts 2:43
And fear came over every soul. And many wonders and signs were shewed by the apostles.

Acts 2:44
And all that believed gathered then together, and had all things common.

Acts 2:45
And sold their possessions and goods, and departed them to all men, as every man had need.

Acts 2:46
And they continued daily with one accord in the temple, and brake bread in every house, and ate their meat together with gladness, and singleness of heart praising God,

Acts 2:47
and had favour with all the people, and the Lord added to the congregation daily them that should be saved.

Acts 3:1
Peter and Ihon went up together into the temple at the ninth hour of prayer:

Acts 3:2
And there was a certain man halt from his mother's womb, whom they brought and laid at the gate of the temple called beautiful, to ask his alms of them that entered into the temple.

Acts 3:3
When he saw Peter and Ihon, that they would into the temple, he desired to receive an alms,

Acts 3:4
Peter fastened his eyes on him with Ihon and said: look on us,

Acts 3:5
and he gave heed unto them, trusting to receive something of them.

Acts 3:6
Then said Peter: Silver and gold have I none, such as I have give I thee. In the name of Iesus Christ of Nazareth, rise up and walk.

Acts 3:7
And he took him by the right hand, and lifted him up. And immediately his feet and anklebones received strength,

Acts 3:8
and he sprang, stood, and also walked, and entered with them into the temple walking, and leaping, and lauding God.

Acts 3:9
And all the people saw him walk and laud God.

Acts 3:10
And they knew him, that it was he which sat and begged at the beautiful gate of the temple. And they wondered, and were sore astonied at that which had happened unto him.

Acts 3:11
As the halt which was healed held Peter and Ihon, all the people ran amazed unto them in Solomon's hall.

Acts 3:12
When Peter saw that, he answered unto the people: Ye men of Israhell, why marvel ye at this? Or why look ye so steadfastly on us, as though by our own power, or holiness we had made this man go?

Acts 3:13
God of Abraham, Isaac, and Iacob, the God of our fathers hath glorified his son Iesus, whom ye betrayed, and denied in the presence of Pilate, when he had judged him to be lowsed:

Acts 3:14
but ye denied the holy and just, and desired that he should give you a murderer,

Acts 3:15
and killed the Lord of life whom God hath raised from death, of the which we are witnesses:

Acts 3:16
And his name thorow the faith of his name hath made this man sound whom ye see and know. And the faith which is by him, hath to this man given this health, in the presence of you all.

Acts 3:17
And now brethren I wot well that thorow ignorance ye have done it, as did also your heads.

Acts 3:18
But God which shewed before by the mouth of all his prophets that Christ should suffer, hath thuswise fulfilled it.

Acts 3:19
Repent ye therefore and turn that your sins may be done away when the time of comfort cometh, which we shall have of the presence of the Lord,

Acts 3:20
and when God shall send him, which before was preached unto you,

Acts 3:21
that is to wit Iesus Christ, which must heaven receive until the time that all things be restored again, which God hath spoken by the mouth of all his holy prophets since the world began.

Acts 3:22
For Moses said unto the fathers: A prophet shall your Lord God raise up unto you, one of your brethren, like unto me, him shall ye hear in all things whatsoever he shall say unto you.

Acts 3:23
For the time will come, that every soul which shall not hear that same prophet, shall be exiled from the people.

Acts 3:24
Also all the prophets from Samuel, and thenceforth, as many as have spoken, have in likewise told of these days.

Acts 3:25
Ye are the children of the prophets, and to you pertaineth the testament that God hath made unto our fathers saying to Abraham: Even in thy seed shall all the kindreds of the earth be blessed.

Acts 3:26
First unto you hath God raised up his son Iesus, and him he hath sent to bless you, that every one of you should turn from his wickedness.

Acts 4:1
As they spake unto the people, the priests and the ruler of the temple, and the saduces came upon them,

Acts 4:2
taking grievously that they taught the people and preached in the name of Iesus the resurrection from death.

Acts 4:3
And they laid hands on them, and put them in hold until the next day. For it was now eventide.

Acts 4:4
Many of them which heard the words believed, and the number of the men was about five thousand.

Acts 4:5
It chanced on the morrow that their rulers, and seniors, and scribes,

Acts 4:6
as Annas the chief priest, and Caiaphas, and Ihon and Alexander, and as many as were of the kindred of the high priest, were gathered together at Ierusalem,

Acts 4:7
and set them in the midst, and asked by what power, or in what name have ye done this sirs?

Acts 4:8
Then Peter full of the holy ghost said unto them. Ye rulers of the people, and seniors of Israhel,

Acts 4:9
if we this day are examined of the good deed done to the sick man by what means he is made whole:

Acts 4:10
be it known unto you all, and to all the people of Israhel, that in the name of Iesus Christ of Nazareth, whom ye crucified, and whom God raised from death again, this man standeth here present before you whole.

Acts 4:11
This is the stone cast aside of you builders which is set in the chief place of the corner.

Acts 4:12
Neither is there health in any other. Nor yet also is there any other name given to men wherein we must be saved.

Acts 4:13
When they saw the boldness of Peter and Ihon, And knew that they were unlearned men and lay people, they marvelled, and they knew them, that they were with Iesu:

Acts 4:14
Seeing also the man which was healed standing with them, they could not say against it,

Acts 4:15
but commanded them to go aside out of the council, And communed among themselves

Acts 4:16
saying: what shall we do to these men? For a manifest sign is done by them, and is openly known to all them that dwell in Ierusalem, and we cannot deny it:

Acts 4:17
But that it be noised no farther among the people, let us threaten and charge them that they speak henceforth to no man in this name.

Acts 4:18
And they called them, and commanded them that in no wise they should speak or teach in the name of Iesu.

Acts 4:19
But Peter and Ihon answered unto them and said: whether it be right in the sight of God to obey you more than God judge ye.

Acts 4:20
For we cannot but speak that which we have seen and heard.

Acts 4:21
So threatened they them and let them go, And found no thing how to punish them, because of the people: For all men lauded God for the miracle which was done.

Acts 4:22
For the man was above forty year old, on whom this miracle of healing was shewed.

Acts 4:23
As soon as they were let go they came to their fellows, and shewed all that the high priests and seniors had said.

Acts 4:24
When they heard that, with one mind they lift up their voices to God and said: Lord, thou art God which hast made heaven and earth, the sea and all that in them is,

Acts 4:25
which by the mouth of thy servant David hast said: Why did the heathen grudge, and the people imagine vain things.

Acts 4:26
The kings of the earth stood up and the rulers came together against the Lord, And against his Christ.

Acts 4:27
For of a truth against thy holy child Iesus, whom thou hast anointed, both Herod and also Pontius Pilate with the gentiles, and the people of Israhel, gathered themselves to gether

Acts 4:28
for to do whatsoever thy hand and thy counsel determined before to be done.

Acts 4:29
And now Lord behold their threatenings, and grant unto thy servants with all confidence to speak thy word.

Acts 4:30
So that thou stretch forth thy hand that healing, and signs, and wonders be done by the name of thy holy child Iesus.

Acts 4:31
And as soon as they had prayed, the place moved where they were assembled together, and they were all filled with the holy ghost, and they spake the word of God boldly.

Acts 4:32
The multitude of them that believed, were of one heart, And of one soul. Also none of them said, that any thing of those which he possessed was his own: But had all things common.

Acts 4:33
And with great power gave the Apostles witness of the resurrection of the Lord Iesu. And great grace was with them all.

Acts 4:34
Neither was there any among them that lacked. For as many as were possessors of lands or houses, sold them and brought the price of the things that were sold,

Acts 4:35
and laid it down at the Apostles' feet. And distribution was made unto every man according as he had need.

Acts 4:36
And Ioses which was also called of the Apostles Barnabas (that is to say the son of consolation, being a Levite, and of the country of Cipers)

Acts 4:37
had land, and sold it, and laid the price down at the Apostles' feet.

Acts 5:1
A certain man named Ananias with Saphira his wife sold a possession,

Acts 5:2
and kept away part of the price (his wife also being of counsel) and brought a certain part, and laid it down at the apostles' feet.

Acts 5:3
Then said Peter: Ananias how is it that Satan hath filled thine heart, that thou shouldest lie unto the holy ghost, and keep away part of the price of thy livelihood:

Acts 5:4
Pertained it not unto thee only? And after it was sold, was not the price in thine own power? How is it that thou hast conceived this thing in thine heart? Thou hast not lied unto men, but unto God.

Acts 5:5
When Ananias heard these words, he fell down and gave up the ghost. And great fear came on all them that these things heard.

Acts 5:6
And the young men rose up, and put him apart, and carried him out, and buried him.

Acts 5:7
It fortuned as it were about the space of iij. hours after, that his wife came in ignorant of that which was done.

Acts 5:8
Peter said unto her: Tell me, sold ye the land for so much? And she said: ye for so much.

Acts 5:9
Peter said unto her: why have ye agreed to gether, to tempt the spirit of the Lord? Lo, the feet of them which have buried thy husband are at the door, and shall carry thee out,

Acts 5:10
Then she fell down straightway at his feet and yielded up the ghost. The young men came in and found her dead, and carried her out and buried her by her husband.

Acts 5:11
And great fear came on all the congregation. And on as many as heard it.

Acts 5:12
By the hands of the Apostles were many signs and wonders shewed among the people. And they were all together with one accord in Solomon's hall.

Acts 5:13
And of other durst no man join himself to them: but the people magnified them.

Acts 5:14
The number of them that believed in the Lord both of men and women grew more and more

Acts 5:15
insomuch that they brought their sick into the streets, and laid them on beds and pallets, that at the leastway the shadow of Peter when he came by, might shadow some of them.

Acts 5:16
There came also a multitude out of the cities round about unto Ierusalem, bringing with them sick and them which were vexed with unclean spirits. And they were healed every one.

Acts 5:17
The chief priest rose up and they that were with him (which is the sect of the saduces) and were full of indignation,

Acts 5:18
and laid hands on the apostles, and put them in the common prison:

Acts 5:19
but the angel of the Lord by night opened the prison door, and brought them forth, and said:

Acts 5:20
go step forth, and speak in the temple to the people all the words of this life.

Acts 5:21
When they heard that, they entered into the temple early in the morning and taught. The chief priest came and they that were with him and called a council together, and all the seniors of the children of Israhel, and sent to the prison to fetch them.

Acts 5:22
When the ministers came and found them not in the prison, they came again and told

Acts 5:23
saying: The prison found we shut with all diligence, and the keepers standing without before the doors: but when we had opened we found no man within.

Acts 5:24
When the chief priest of all and the ruler of the temple, and the high priests heard these things, they doubted of them, whereunto this would grow.

Acts 5:25
Then came one and shewed them: Lo the men that ye put in prison stand in the temple, and preach to the people.

Acts 5:26
Then went the ruler of the temple with ministers, and brought them without violence. For they feared the people lest they should have been stoned.

Acts 5:27
And when they had brought them, they set them before the council. And the chief priest asked them

Acts 5:28
saying: did not we straitly command you that ye should not teach in this name? and behold ye have filled Ierusalem with your doctrine, and ye intend to bring this man's blood upon us.

Acts 5:29
Peter and the other Apostles answered, and said: We ought more to obey God than men.

Acts 5:30
The God of our fathers raised up Iesus, whom ye slew and hanged on tree.

Acts 5:31
Him being a ruler and a saviour hath God exalted with his right hand, for to give repentance to Israhell and forgiveness of sins.

Acts 5:32
And we are his records as concerning these things: and also the holy ghost, whom God hath given to them that obey him.

Acts 5:33
When they heard that they clave asunder, and sought means to slay them.

Acts 5:34
Then stood there up one in the council, a pharise named Gamaliel, a doctor of law, had in authority among the people and commanded to put the Apostles aside a little space,

Acts 5:35
and said unto them: Men of Israhell take heed to yourselves what ye intend to do as touching these men.

Acts 5:36
Before these days rose up one Theudas boasting himself, to whom resorted a number of men, about a four hundred, which was slain, and they all which believed him were scattered abroad, and brought to nought.

Acts 5:37
After this man arose there up one Iudas of Galile, in the time when tribute began, and drew away much people after him. He also perished: and all even as many as harkened to him are scattered a broad.

Acts 5:38
And now I say unto you: refrain yourselves from these men, let them alone: For if this counsel or work be of men, it will come to nought:

Acts 5:39
but and if it be of God, ye cannot destroy it, lest haply ye be found to strive against God.

Acts 5:40
And to him they agreed, and called the apostles, and beat them, and commanded that they should not speak in the name of Iesu, and let them go.

Acts 5:41
And they departed from the council rejoicing that they were counted worthy to suffer rebuke for his name.

Acts 5:42
And daily in the temple, and in every house they ceased not, teaching and preaching Iesus Christ.

Acts 6:1
In those days as the number of the disciples grew, there arose a grudge among the greeks against the ebrues, because their widows were despised in the daily ministration.

Acts 6:2
Then the twelve called the multitude of the disciples to gether and said: it is not meet that we should leave the word of God and serve at the tables,

Acts 6:3
wherefore brethren look ye out among you seven men of honest report, and full of the holy ghost and wisdom, which we may appoint to this needful business:

Acts 6:4
but we will give ourselves continually to prayer, and to the ministration of the word.

Acts 6:5
And the saying pleased the whole multitude well. And they chose Stephen a man full of faith, and of the holy ghost, and Philip, and Prochorus, and Nichanor, and Timon, and Permenas, and Nicholas a proselite of Antioch,

Acts 6:6
which they set before the apostles, and they prayed and laid their hands on them.

Acts 6:7
And the word of God increased, and the number of the disciples multiplied in Ierusalem greatly. And a great company of the priests were obedient to the faith.

Acts 6:8
Stephen full of faith and power did great wonders, and miracles among the people.

Acts 6:9
Then there arose certain of the Synagogue, which are called libertines, and Sirenens, and Alexandrians, and Cilicilians, and Asians, and disputed with Steven.

Acts 6:10
And they could not resist the wisdom, and the spirit, with which he spake.

Acts 6:11
Then sent they in men which said: we have heard him speak blasphemous words against Moses, and against God,

Acts 6:12
and they moved the people, and the seniors, and the scribes: and they came upon him and caught him, and brought him to the council,

Acts 6:13
and brought forth false witnesses which said: This man ceaseth not to speak blasphemous words against this holy place and the law,

Acts 6:14
for we heard him say: This Iesus of Nazareth shall destroy this place, and shall change the ordinances which Moses gave unto us.

Acts 6:15
And all that sat in the council looked steadfastly on him, and saw his face as it had been the face of an angel.

Acts 7:1
Then said the chief priest: is it even so?

Acts 7:2
And he said: ye men, brethren, and fathers, hearken to. The God of glory appeared unto our father Abraham while he was yet in Mesopotamia, before he dwelt in Charran,

Acts 7:3
and said unto him: come out of thy country, and from thy kindred, and come into the land which I shall shew unto thee.

Acts 7:4
Then came he out of the land of Caldey, and dwelt in Charran. And after that as soon as his father was dead, he brought him into this land, wherein ye now dwell,

Acts 7:5
and he gave him none inheritance in it, no not one foot of ground. And promised that he would give it to him and to his seed after him, when as yet he had no child.

Acts 7:6
God verily spake on this wise, thy seed shall be a dweller in a strange land, and they shall put them in bondage, and entreat them evil .iiij. C. years.

Acts 7:7
And the nation to whom they shall be in bondage, will I judge (said God) and after that shall they come forth, and serve me in this place.

Acts 7:8
And gave him the testament of circumcision, and he begat Isaac, and circumcised him the viij. day, and Isaac begat Iacob, and Iacob the twelve patriarchs.

Acts 7:9
And the patriarchs having indignation sold Ioseph into Egypt, and God was with him,

Acts 7:10
and delivered him out of all his adversities, and gave him favour and wisdom in the sight of Pharao king of Egypt, And Pharao made him governor over Egypt, and over all his household.

Acts 7:11
Then came there a dearth over all the land of Egypt, and Canaan, and great affliction, that our fathers found no sustenance.

Acts 7:12
When Iacob heard that there was corn in Egypt, he sent our fathers first,

Acts 7:13
and when he had sent them the second time, Ioseph was known of his brethren, and Ioseph's kindred was made known unto Pharao.

Acts 7:14
Then sent Ioseph and caused his father to be brought and all his kin, three score and xv. souls.

Acts 7:15
And Iacob descended into Egypt, and died both he and our fathers,

Acts 7:16
and were translated into Sichem, and were put in the sepulchre that Abraham bought for money of the sons of Emor, at Sichem.

Acts 7:17
When the time of the promise drew nye (which God had promised with an oath to Abraham) the people grew and multiplied in Egypt

Acts 7:18
till another king arose which knew not of Ioseph.

Acts 7:19
The same dealt subtly with our kindred, and evil intreated our fathers, and made them to cast out their children, that they should not remain alive.

Acts 7:20
The same time was Moses born, and was a proper child in the sight of God, which was nourished up in his father's house three months.

Acts 7:21
When he was cast out Pharaoh's daughter took him up, and nourished him up for her own son.

Acts 7:22
And Moses was learned in all manner wisdom of the Egyptians, and was mighty in deeds and in words.

Acts 7:23
When he was full forty year old, it came into his heart to visit his brethren, the children of Israhel.

Acts 7:24
And when he saw one of them suffer wrong, he defended him, and avenged his quarrel that had the harm done to him, and smote the Egyptian.

Acts 7:25
For he supposed his brethren would have understood how that God by his hands should give them health: but they understood not.

Acts 7:26
And the next day he shewed himself unto them as they strove, and would have set them at one again saying: Sirs ye are brethren why hurt ye one another?

Acts 7:27
But he that did his neighbour wrong, thrust him away saying: Who made thee a ruler and a judge among us?

Acts 7:28
What wilt thou kill me, as thou didst the Egyptian yesterday?

Acts 7:29
Then fled Moses at that word, and was a stranger in the land of Madian, Where he begat two sons.

Acts 7:30
When xl. years were expired, there appeared to him in the wilderness of mount Sina the angel of the Lord in a flame of fire in a bush.

Acts 7:31
When Moses saw it he wondered at the sight, and as he drew near to behold it. And the voice of the Lord came unto him:

Acts 7:32
I am the God of thy fathers, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac and the God of Iacob. Moses trembled and durst not behold.

Acts 7:33
Then said the Lord to him put off thy shoes from thy feet, for the place where thou standest is holy ground.

Acts 7:34
I have perfectly seen the affliction of my people which is in Egypt, and I have heard their groaning, and am come down to deliver them. And now come and I will send thee into Egypt.

Acts 7:35
The same Moses whom they forsook saying: who made the a ruler and a judge: God sent both a ruler and a deliverer, by the hands of the angel which appeared to him in the bush.

Acts 7:36
This man brought them out shewing wonders and signs in Egypt, and in the reed sea, and in the wilderness xl. years.

Acts 7:37
This is that Moses which said unto the children of Israhell: A prophet shall your Lord God raise up unto you of your brethren like unto me, him shall ye hear.

Acts 7:38
This is he that was in the congregation, in the wilderness with the angel which spake to him in the mount Sina, and with our fathers. This man received the word of life to give unto us,

Acts 7:39
to whom our fathers would not obey: But cast it from them, and in their hearts turned back again into Egypt,

Acts 7:40
saying unto Aaron: Make us goddes to go before us. For we wot not what is become of this Moses that brought us out of the land of Egypt.

Acts 7:41
And they made a calf in those days, and offered sacrifice unto the image, and rejoiced in the works of their own hands.

Acts 7:42
Then God turned himself, and gave them up, that they should worship the stars of the sky, as it is written in the book of the prophets: O ye of the house of Israhell: have ye given unto me offerings or sacrifice, by the space of xl. years in the wilderness?

Acts 7:43
And ye took unto you the tabernacle of Moloch, and the star of your god Remphan, figures which ye made to worship them. And I will translate you beyond Babylon.

Acts 7:44
Our fathers had the tabernacle of testimony in the wilderness, as he had appointed them speaking unto Moses, that he should make it according to the fashion that he had seen,

Acts 7:45
which tabernacle our fathers received, and brought it in with Iosue into the possession of the gentiles, which gentiles God drave out before the face of our fathers unto the time of David,

Acts 7:46
which found favour before God, and desired that he might find a tabernacle for the God of Iacob.

Acts 7:47
And Solomon built him an house.

Acts 7:48
But he that is highest of all dwelleth not in temples made with hands, as saith the prophet:

Acts 7:49
Heaven is my seat, and earth is my foot stool, what house will ye build for me saith the Lord? or what resting place?

Acts 7:50
hath not my hand made all these things?

Acts 7:51
Ye stiffnecked and of uncircumcised hearts and ears: ye have allways resisted the holy ghost: as your fathers did, so do ye.

Acts 7:52
Which of the prophets have not your fathers persecuted? And they have slain them, which shewed before of the coming of that Just, whom ye have betrayed and murdered.

Acts 7:53
And ye also have received a law by the ordinance of angels, and have not kept it.

Acts 7:54
When they heard these things, their hearts clave asunder, and they gnashed on him with their teeth.

Acts 7:55
He being full of the holy ghost looked up with his eyes into heaven and saw the majesty of God, and Iesus standing on the right hand of God,

Acts 7:56
and said: lo, I see the heavens open, and the son of man stand on the right hand of God.

Acts 7:57
Then they gave a shout with a loud voice, and stopped their ears and all ran upon him at once,

Acts 7:58
and cast him out of the city, and stoned him. And the witnesses laid down their clothes at a young man's feet named Saul.

Acts 7:59
And they stoned Steven calling on and saying: Lord Iesu receive my spirit.

Acts 7:60
And he kneeled down and cried with a loud voice: Lord impute not this sin unto them, For they wote not what they do. And when he had thus spoken he fell asleep.

Acts 8:1
Saul had pleasure in his death. At that time there was a great persecution against the congregation which was at Ierusalem, and they were all scattered abroad thorowout the regions of Jury and Samaria, except the apostles.

Acts 8:2
Then devout men dressed Steven, and made great lamentation over him.

Acts 8:3
Saul made havoc of the congregation entering into every house, and drew out both man and woman, and thrust them into prison.

Acts 8:4
They that were scattered abroad went every where preaching the word.

Acts 8:5
Then came Philip into a city of Samaria, and preached Christ unto them.

Acts 8:6
And the people gave heed unto those things which Philip spake with one accord, in that they heard and saw the miracles which he did.

Acts 8:7
For unclean spirits crying with loud voice, came out of many which were possessed of them. Many taken with palsies, and many that halted were healed.

Acts 8:8
And there was great joy in that city.

Acts 8:9
And there was a certain man called Simon, which beforetime in the same city, used witchcraft and bewitched the people, saying that he was a man that could do great things.

Acts 8:10
Whom they regarded, from the least to the greatest saying: this is that power of God, which is called great.

Acts 8:11
Him they set much by, because of long time with sorcery he had deluded their wits.

Acts 8:12
As soon as they believed Philip's preaching of the kingdom of God and of the name of Iesu Christ, they were baptised both men and women.

Acts 8:13
Then Simon himself believed and was baptised. And continued with Philip, and wondered beholding the miracles and signs, which were shewed.

Acts 8:14
When the Apostles which were at Ierusalem heard say that Samaria had received the word of God: they sent unto them Peter and Ihon,

Acts 8:15
which when they were come, prayed for them, that they might receive the holy ghost.

Acts 8:16
For as yet he was come on none of them: But they were baptised only in the name of Christ Iesu.

Acts 8:17
Then laid they their hands on them, and they received the holy ghost.

Acts 8:18
When Simon saw that thorow laying on of the Apostles' hands on them, the holy ghost was given: he offered them money saying:

Acts 8:19
Give me also this power, that on whomsoever I lay hands, he may receive the holy ghost.

Acts 8:20
Then said Peter unto him: Perish thou and thy money together. For thou wenest that the gift of God may be obtained with money?

Acts 8:21
thou hast neither part nor fellowship in this business. For thy heart is not right in the sight of God.

Acts 8:22
Repent therefore of this thy wickedness, and pray God that the thought of thine heart may be forgiven thee.

Acts 8:23
For I perceive that thou art full of bitter gall, and wrapped in iniquity.

Acts 8:24
Then answered Simon and said: Pray ye to the Lord for me that none of these things which ye have spoken fall on me.

Acts 8:25
And they when they had testified, and preached the word of the Lord returned to Ierusalem and preached the gospel in many cities of the Samaritans.

Acts 8:26
Then the angel of the Lord spake unto Philip saying: Arise and go towards midday unto the way which leadeth from Ierusalem unto Gaza, which is in the desert.

Acts 8:27
He arose and went on, and behold a man of Ethiopia which was gelded, and of great authority with Candace queen of the Ethiophians, which had the rule of all her treasure, came to Ierusalem for to pray.

Acts 8:28
As he returned home again sitting in his chariot he read Esay the prophet.

Acts 8:29
The spirit said unto Philip: Go near and join thyself to yonder chariot.

Acts 8:30
Philip ran to him, and heard him read Esay the prophet and said: Understandest thou what thou readest?

Acts 8:31
And he said: how can I, except I had a guide? And he desired Philip that he would come up and sit with him.

Acts 8:32
The tenor of the scripture which he read was this. He was led as a sheep to be slain: And like a lamb dumb before his shearer, so opened he not his mouth,

Acts 8:33
in that he submitted himself, his judgement was exalted: who shall declare his generation? for his life is taken from the earth.

Acts 8:34
The gelded man answered Philip and said: I pray thee of whom speaketh the prophet this? of himself? or of some other man?

Acts 8:35
Philip opened his mouth, and began at the same scripture, and preached unto him Iesus.

Acts 8:36
And as they went on their way, they came unto a certain water, and the gelded man said: See here is water, what shall let me to be baptised?

Acts 8:37
Philip said unto him: If thou believe with all thine heart, thou mayst. He answered saying: I believe that Iesus Christ is the son of God.

Acts 8:38
And commanded the chariot to stand still. And they went down both into the water: both Philip and also the gelded man. And he baptised him.

Acts 8:39
As soon as they were come out of the water the spirit of the Lord caught away Philip. And the gelded man saw him no more. And he went on his way rejoicing:

Acts 8:40
but Philip was found at Azotus. And he walked thorow out the country preaching in their cities, till he came to Cesarea.

Acts 9:1
Saul yet breathing out threatenings and slaughter against the disciples of the Lord, went unto the high priest,

Acts 9:2
and desired of him letters to Damascon, to the synagogues: that if he found any of this way whether they were men or women, he might bring them bound unto Ierusalem.

Acts 9:3
As he went on his journey, it fortuned that he drew nye to Damascon, and suddenly there shined round about him a light from heaven.

Acts 9:4
And he fell to the earth, and heard a voice saying to him: Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou me?

Acts 9:5
And he said what art thou Lord? The Lord said, I am Iesus whom thou persecutest, it shall be hard for thee to kick against the prick.

Acts 9:6
He both trembling and astonied said: Lord what wilt thou have me to do? And the Lord said unto him: Arise and go into the city, and it shall be told thee what thou shalt do.

Acts 9:7
The men which accompanied him on his way stood amazed, for they heard a voice, but saw no man.

Acts 9:8
Saul arose from the earth, And when he had opened his eyes he saw no man. Then led they him by the hand, and brought him into damascon.

Acts 9:9
And he was iij. days without sight, and neither ate nor drank.

Acts 9:10
There was a certain disciple at Damascon named Ananias, to him said the Lord in a vision: Ananias. And he said: I am here Lord.

Acts 9:11
And the Lord said to him: arise and go into the street which is called straight, and seek in the house of Iudas after one called Saul of the city of Tharsus. For behold he prayeth,

Acts 9:12
And hath seen in a vision a man named Ananias coming in unto him, And putting his hands on him, that he might receive his sight.

Acts 9:13
Ananias answered: Lord I have heard by many of this man, how much hurt he hath done to thy saints at Ierusalem:

Acts 9:14
and in this place he hath authority of the high priests to bind all that call on thy name.

Acts 9:15
The Lord said unto him: Go thy ways: for he is a chosen vessel unto me, to bear my name before the gentiles, and kings and the children of Israhel:

Acts 9:16
For I will shew him how great things he must suffer for my name's sake.

Acts 9:17
Ananias went his way and entered into the house and put his hands on him and said: brother Saul, the Lord that appeared unto thee in the way as thou camest, hath sent me, that thou mightest receive thy sight and be filled with the holy ghost.

Acts 9:18
And immediately there fell from his eyes as it had been scales and he received his sight, and arose and was baptised.

Acts 9:19
And received meat and was comforted. Then was Saul a certain days with the disciples which were at Damascon.

Acts 9:20
And straightway he preached Christ in the Synagogues how that he was the son of God.

Acts 9:21
All that heard him were amazed and said: is not this he that spoiled them which called on this name in Ierusalem? And came hither for the intent that he should bring them bound unto the high priests?

Acts 9:22
Saul increased in strength, And confounded the jews which dwelt at Damascon affirming that this was very Christ.

Acts 9:23
After a good while, the jews took counsel to gether among themselves to kill him.

Acts 9:24
But their layings wait were known of Saul. And they watched at the gates day and night to kill him.

Acts 9:25
Then the disciples took him by night, and put him thorow the wall and let him down in a basket.

Acts 9:26
When Saul came to Ierusalem he assayed to couple himself with the disciples, and they were all afraid of him and believed not that he was a disciple.

Acts 9:27
But Barnabas took him and brought him to the apostles and told them how he had seen the Lord in the way and had spoken with him: and how he had done boldly at Damascon in the name of Iesu,

Acts 9:28
And he had his conversation with them at Ierusalem,

Acts 9:29
and quit himself boldly in the name of the Lord Iesu. And he spake and disputed with the greeks and they went about to slay him.

Acts 9:30
When the brethren knew of that, they brought him to Cesarea, and sent him forth to Tharsus.

Acts 9:31
Then had the congregations rest thorowout all jewry and Galile and Samary, and were edified, and walked in the fear of the Lord, And multiplied by the comfort of the holy ghost.

Acts 9:32
It chanced that as Peter walked throughout all quarters, he came to the saints which dwelt at Lydda.

Acts 9:33
And there he found a certain man named Eneas, which had kept his bed viij. years sick of the palsy.

Acts 9:34
Then said Peter unto him: Eneas, the Lord Iesus Christ make thee whole: Arise and make thy bed. And he arose immediately.

Acts 9:35
And all that dwelt at Lydda and Assaron, saw him, and turned to the Lord.

Acts 9:36
There was at Ioppa a certain woman (which was a disciple named Tabitha, which by interpretation is called Dorcas) she was full of good works and alms deeds, which she did.

Acts 9:37
It chanced in those days that she was sick and died. When they had washed her and laid her in a chamber:

Acts 9:38
Because Lydda was nye to Ioppa, and the disciples had heard that Peter was there, they sent unto him, desiring him that he would not be grieved to come unto them.

Acts 9:39
Peter arose and came with them: when he was come, they brought him into the chamber, and all the widows stood round about him weeping and shewing the coats and garments which Dorcas made while she was with them.

Acts 9:40
Peter put them all forth and kneeled down and prayed and turned him to the body, and said: Tabitha, arise. She opened her eyes, and when she saw Peter she sat up.

Acts 9:41
And he gave her his hand and lift her up, and called the saints and widows and shewed her alive.

Acts 9:42
And it was known throweout all Ioppa, and many believed on the Lord.

Acts 9:43
And it fortuned that he tarried many days in Ioppa with one Simon a tanner.

Acts 10:1
There was a certain man in Cesarea called Cornelius, a captain of the soldiers of Italy,

Acts 10:2
a devout man, and one that feared God with all his household, which gave much alms to the people, and prayed God always.

Acts 10:3
The same man saw in a vision evidently about the ninth hour of the day the angel of God coming in unto him, and saying unto him: Cornelius,

Acts 10:4
when he looked on him, he was afraid, and said: what is it Lord? He said unto him: Thy prayers and thy alms are come up into remembrance in the presence of God.

Acts 10:5
And now send men to Ioppa, and call for one Simon named also Peter.

Acts 10:6
He lodgeth with one Simon a tanner, whose house is by the seaside. He shall tell thee, what thou oughtest to do.

Acts 10:7
When the angel which spake unto Cornelius was departed, he called two of his household, and a devout soldier of them that waited on him,

Acts 10:8
to whom he told all the matter, and sent them to Ioppa.

Acts 10:9
On the morrow as they went on their journey and drew nye unto the city, Peter went up into the uppermost part of the house to pray, about the vj. hour.

Acts 10:10
Then waxed he an hungered, and would have eaten. while they made ready for him. He fell into a trance,

Acts 10:11
and saw heaven opened, and a certain vessel come down unto him, as it had been a great sheet, knit at the iiij. corners, and was let down to the earth,

Acts 10:12
wherein were all manner of iiij. footed beasts of the earth and vermin and worms, and fouls of the air.

Acts 10:13
And a voice spake unto him from heaven: Rise Peter Kill and eat.

Acts 10:14
Peter said: God forbid Lord, for I have never eaten any thing that is common or unclean.

Acts 10:15
And the voice spake unto him again the second time: What God hath cleansed that make thou not common.

Acts 10:16
This was done thrice, And the vessel was received up again into heaven.

Acts 10:17
While Peter mused in himself what this vision which he had seen meant, behold, the men which were sent from Cornelius, had made inquirance for Simon's house, and stood before the door.

Acts 10:18
And called out one and asked whether Simon which was also called Peter, were lodged there.

Acts 10:19
While Peter thought on this vision, the spirit said unto him: Lo, men seek thee: arise therefore, get thee down,

Acts 10:20
and go with them, and doubt not. For I have sent them.

Acts 10:21
Peter went down to the men which were sent unto him from Cornelius, and said: Lo, I am he, whom ye seek, what is the cause wherefore ye are come?

Acts 10:22
They said unto him: Cornelius the captain a just man, and one that feareth God, and of good report among all the people of the jews was warned by an holy angel, to send for thee in to his house, and to hear words of thee.

Acts 10:23
Then called he them in, and lodged them. On the morrow Peter went with them, and certain brethren from Ioppa accompanied him.

Acts 10:24
And the third day entered they into Cesaria. Cornelius waited for them, and had called to gether his kinsmen, and special friends.

Acts 10:25
And as it chanced Peter to come in, Cornelius met him, and fell down at his feet, and worshipped him.

Acts 10:26
Peter took him up, saying: Even I myself am a man.

Acts 10:27
And as he talked with him he came in, and found many that were come to gether.

Acts 10:28
And he said unto them: Ye do know how that it is an unlawful thing for a man that is a jew to company or come unto an alien: But God hath shewed me that I should not call any man common or unclean:

Acts 10:29
therefore came I unto you without scruple, as soon as I was sent for. I ask therefore: for what intent have ye sent for me?

Acts 10:30
And Cornelius said: This day now. iiij. days I fasted, and at the ninth hour I prayed in my house, and behold, a man stood before me in bright clothing,

Acts 10:31
and said: Cornelius, thy prayer is heard, and thine alms deeds are had in remembrance in the sight of God.

Acts 10:32
Send therefore to Ioppa, and call for Simon which is also called Peter. He is lodged in the house of one Simon a tanner by the seaside, the which as soon as he is come, shall speak unto thee.

Acts 10:33
Then sent I for thee immediately, and thou hast well done for to come. Now are we all here, present before God to hear all things that are commanded unto thee of God.

Acts 10:34
Peter opened his mought and said: Of a truth I perceive, that God is not partial,

Acts 10:35
but in all people he that feareth him and worketh righteousness, is accepted with him.

Acts 10:36
Ye know the preaching that God sent unto the children of Israhell, preaching peace by Iesus Christe (which is Lord over all things.)

Acts 10:37
which preaching was published thorowout all Jewery, and began in Galile, after the baptism preached by Ihon,

Acts 10:38
After that God had anointed Iesus of Nazareth with the holy ghost, and with power, he went about doing good, and healing all that were oppressed with devils, for God was with him.

Acts 10:39
And we are witnesses of all things which he did in the land of the jewes and at Ierusalem, whom they slew, and hung on tree.

Acts 10:40
Him God raised up the third day, and shewed him openly,

Acts 10:41
not to all the people, but unto us witnesses chosen before of God, which ate and drank with him, after he arose from death.

Acts 10:42
And he commanded us to preach unto the people and testify, that it is he that is ordained of God a judge of quick and dead.

Acts 10:43
To him giveth all the prophets witness, that throwe his name shall receive remission of sins all that believe in him.

Acts 10:44
While Peter yet spake these words, the holy ghost fell on all them which heard his preaching.

Acts 10:45
And they of the circumcision which believed were astonied, as many as came with Peter, because that on the gentiles also was shed out the gift of the holy ghost.

Acts 10:46
For they heard them speak with tongues, and magnify God. Then answered Peter:

Acts 10:47
can any man forbid water that these should not be baptised, which have received the holy ghost as well as we?

Acts 10:48
And he commanded them to be baptised in the name of the Lord. Then prayed they him, to tarry a few days.

Acts 11:1
It came to the ears of the Apostles and the brethren which were in jewry, that the heathen also had received the word of God.

Acts 11:2
When Peter was come up to Ierusalem, they of the circumcision disputed with him, saying:

Acts 11:3
Thou wentest in unto men uncircumcised, and atest with them.

Acts 11:4
Peter began and expounded the thing in order to them saying:

Acts 11:5
I was in the city of Ioppa praying, and in a trance I saw a vision, A certain vessel descend, as it had been a large linen cloth, let down from heaven by the four corners, And it came to me:

Acts 11:6
into the which when I had fastened mine eyes I considered and saw fourfooted beasts of the earth, and vermin and worms, and fowls of the air.

Acts 11:7
I heard also a voice saying unto me: Arise Peter, slay and eat.

Acts 11:8
And I said: God forbid Lord, for nothing common or unclean hath at any time entered into my mought.

Acts 11:9
The voice answered me again from heaven count not thou those things common, which God hath cleansed.

Acts 11:10
And this was done three times. And all were taken up again into heaven.

Acts 11:11
And behold immediately were there three men come unto the house where I was, sent from Cesarea unto me.

Acts 11:12
And the spirit said unto me, that I should go with them, without doubting. Moreover the six brethren accompanied me. And we entered into the man's house.

Acts 11:13
And he shewed us, how he had seen an angel in his house, which stood and said to him: Send men to Ioppa, and call for Simon, named also Peter

Acts 11:14
he shall tell thee words, whereby both thou and all thine house shall be saved.

Acts 11:15
And as I began to preach, the holy ghost fell on them, as he did on us at the beginning.

Acts 11:16
Then came to my remembrance the words of the Lord, how he said: Ihon baptised with water, but ye shall be baptised with the holy ghost.

Acts 11:17
Forasmuch then as God gave them like gifts, as he did unto us, when we believed on the Lord Iesus Christ: what was I that I should have withstood God?

Acts 11:18
when they heard this, they held their peace and glorified God, saying: Then hath God also to the Gentiles granted repentance unto life.

Acts 11:19
They which were scattered abroad thorow the affliction that arose about Steven, walked thorow out till they came unto Phenice and Cypers and Antioche, preaching the word to no man, but unto the jews only.

Acts 11:20
Some of them were men of Cypers and of Syrene, which when they were come into Antioch, spake unto the greeks, and preached the Lord Iesus.

Acts 11:21
And the hand of the Lord was with them, and a great number believed and turned unto the Lord.

Acts 11:22
Tidings of this came unto the ears of the congregation, which was in Ierusalem, And they sent forth Barnabas that he should go unto Antioche.

Acts 11:23
Which when he was come, and had seen the grace of the Lord, was glad, and exhorted them all, that with purpose of heart they would continually cleave unto the Lord.

Acts 11:24
For he was a perfect man, and full of the holy ghost and of faith. And much people was added unto the Lord.

Acts 11:25
Then departed Barnabas to Tarsus, for to seek Saul,

Acts 11:26
and when he had found him, he brought him unto Antioche. And it chanced that a whole year they had their conversation with the congregation there, and taught much people insomuch that the disciples of Antioche were the first that were called Christen.

Acts 11:27
In those days came prophets from Ierusalem unto Antioche.

Acts 11:28
There stood up one of them named Agabus, and signified by the spirit, that there should be great dearth throughout all the world, which came to pass in the Emperor Claudius days.

Acts 11:29
Then the disciples every man according to his ability, purposed to send succour unto the brethren which dwelt in jewry,

Acts 11:30
which thing they also did, and sent it to the seniors, by the hands of Barnabas and Saul.

Acts 12:1
In that time Herod the king layed hands on certain of the congregation, to vex them.

Acts 12:2
And he killed Iames the brother of Ihon with a sword:

Acts 12:3
and because he saw that it pleased the jews, he proceeded further, to take Peter also. Then were the days of unleavened bread,

Acts 12:4
and when he had caught him, he put him in prison, and delivered him to iiij. quaternions of soldiers to be kept, intending after ester to bring him forth to the people.

Acts 12:5
Then was Peter kept in prison. But prayer was made without ceasing of the congregation unto God for him.

Acts 12:6
When Herod would have brought him out unto the people, the same night slept Peter between ij. soldiers, bound with two chains, And the keepers before the door kept the prison.

Acts 12:7
And behold the angel of the Lord was there present, and a light shined in the lodge. And he smote Peter on the side, and stirred him up saying: arise up quickly. And the chains fell off from his hands.

Acts 12:8
And the angel said unto him: gird thyself and bind on thy sandals, And so he did. And he said unto him: cast on thy mantle about thee, and follow me.

Acts 12:9
And he came out and followed him, and wist not, that it was truth which was done by the angel, but thought he had seen a vision.

Acts 12:10
When they were past the first and the second watch, they came unto the iron gate, that leadeth unto the city, which opened to them by his own accord. And they went out and passed thorow one street, and by and by the angel departed from him.

Acts 12:11
And when Peter was come to himself, he said: now I know of a surety, that the Lord hath sent his angel, and hath delivered me from the hand of Herod, and from all the waiting for of the people of the jewes.

Acts 12:12
And as he considered the thing, he came to the house of Mary the mother of one Ihon, which was called Mark also, where many were gathered together in prayer.

Acts 12:13
As Peter knocked at the entry door, a damsel came forth to hearken, named Rhoda.

Acts 12:14
And when she knew Peter's voice, she opened not the entry for gladness, but ran in and told how Peter stood before the entry.

Acts 12:15
And they said unto her: thou art mad. And she bare them down that it was even so. Then said they: it is his angel.

Acts 12:16
Peter continued knocking: When they had opened the door, and saw him, they were astonied.

Acts 12:17
He beckoned unto them with his hand to hold their peace, and told them by what means the Lord had brought him out of the prison. And said: go shew this unto Iames and to the brethren. And he departed and went into another place.

Acts 12:18
As soon as it was day there was no little ado among the soldiers, what was become of Peter.

Acts 12:19
When Herod had called for him, and found him not, he examined the keepers, and commanded to depart. And he descended from Jewry to Cesarea, and there abode.

Acts 12:20
Herod was displeased with them of Tyre and Sidon. And they came all at once, and made intercession unto Blastus the king's chamberlain, and desired peace, because their country was nourished by the king's land.

Acts 12:21
Upon a day appointed, the king arrayed him in royal apparel, and set him in his seat, and made an oration unto them.

Acts 12:22
And the people gave a shout, saying: It is the voice of a God and not of a man.

Acts 12:23
And immediately the angel of the Lord smote him, because he gave not God the honour, and he was eaten of worms, and gave up the ghost.

Acts 12:24
The word of God grew and multiplied.

Acts 12:25
And Barnabas and Saul returned to Ierusalem, and fulfilled their office, and took with them Ihon, which was also called Marcus.

Acts 13:1
There were at Antioche, in the congregation, prophets and doctors, as Barnabas and Simeonb called Nyger, And Lucius of Cerene, and Manahen Herod the tetrarkes nursefellow, and Saul.

Acts 13:2
As they served God, and fasted, The holy ghost said: separate me Barnabas and Saul, for the work whereunto I have called them.

Acts 13:3
Then fasted they and prayed, and put their hands on them, and let them go.

Acts 13:4
And they after they were sent of the holy ghost, came unto Seleutia, and from thence they sailed to Cyprus.

Acts 13:5
And when they were come to Solamine, they shewed the word of God in the synagogues, unto the jewes. And they had Ihon to their minister.

Acts 13:6
When they had gone over all the Isle unto the city of Paphos, they found a certain sorcerer, a false prophet which was a iewe,

Acts 13:7
named Bariesu, which was with the ruler of the country one Sergius Paulus a prudent man. The same ruler called unto him Barnabas and Saul, and desired to hear the word of God.

Acts 13:8
The sorcerer Elemas (for so was his name by interpretation) withstood them, and sought to turn away the ruler from the faith.

Acts 13:9
Then Saul which also is called Paul being full of the holy ghost, set his eyes on him, and said:

Acts 13:10
O full of all subtlety and deceitfulness the child of the devil, and the enemy of all righteousness thou ceasest not to pervert the straight ways of the Lord.

Acts 13:11
And now behold the hand of the Lord is upon thee, and thou shalt be blind and not see the sun for a season. And immediately fell on him a mist and a darkness, And he went about seeking, them that should lead him by the hand.

Acts 13:12
Then the ruler when he saw what had happened, believed, and wondered at the doctrine of the Lord.

Acts 13:13
When Paul and they that were with him, had shipped from Paphus, they came to Perga a city of Pamphilia. There departed Ihon from them, and returned to Ierusalem.

Acts 13:14
But they wandered thorow the countries, from Perga to Antioche a city of the country of Pisidia, and went into the synagoge on the saboth day, and sat down.

Acts 13:15
After the lecture of the law and the prophets, the rulers of the synagogue sent unto them saying: Ye men and brethren, if ye have any sermon to exhort the people, say on.

Acts 13:16
Paul stood up and beckoned with his hand and said: Men of Israhel, and ye that fear God, give audience.

Acts 13:17
The God of this people chose our fathers, and exalted the people when they dwelt as strangers in the land of Egypt, and with a mighty arm brought them out of it,

Acts 13:18
and about the time of .xl. years, suffered he their manners in the wilderness.

Acts 13:19
And he destroyed vij. nations in the land of Canaan, and divided their land to them by Lott.

Acts 13:20
And afterward he gave unto them judges about the space of. iiij.C. and l. years unto the time of Samuel the prophet.

Acts 13:21
And after that they desired a king, and God gave unto them Saul the son of Cis, a man of the tribe of Benjamin, by the space of xl. years.

Acts 13:22
And after he had put him down, he set up David to be their king, to whom he gave witness, saying: I have found David the son of Iesse, a man after mine own heart, he shall fulfil all my will.

Acts 13:23
Of this man's seed hath God (according to his promise) brought forth to the people of Israel a saviour, one Iesus,

Acts 13:24
when Ihon had first preached before his coming the baptism of repentance to Israhel.

Acts 13:25
When Ihon had fulfilled his course, he said: Whom ye think that I am? the same am I not, but behold there cometh one after me, whose shoes of his feet I am not worthy to lowse.

Acts 13:26
Ye men and brethren, children of the generation off Abraham, and whosoever among you feareth God, to you is this word of health sent.

Acts 13:27
The inhabiters of Ierusalem, and their rulers because they knew him not, nor yet the voices of the prophets which are read every saboth day, have fulfilled them in condemning him.

Acts 13:28
And when they found no cause of death in him, yet desired they Pilate to kill him.

Acts 13:29
And when they had fulfilled all that were written of him, they took him down from the tree and put him in a sepulchre:

Acts 13:30
But God raised him again from death,

Acts 13:31
and he was seen many days of them, which came with him from Galile to Ierusalem which are his witnesses unto the people.

Acts 13:32
And we declare unto you, how that the promise made unto the fathers,

Acts 13:33
god hath now fulfilled unto us the children, in that he raised up Iesus again, even as it is written in the first psalm: Thou art my son, this same day begat I thee.

Acts 13:34
As concerning that he so raised him up from death, now no more to return to corruption, he said on this wise: The holy promises made to David I will keep faithfully.

Acts 13:35
Wherefore he saith also in another place: Thou shalt not suffer thy Saincte to see corruption.

Acts 13:36
For David after he had in his time fulfilled the will of God, he slept, and was laid with his fathers, and saw corruption.

Acts 13:37
But he whom God raised again, saw no corruption.

Acts 13:38
Be it known unto you therefore ye men and brethren, that thorow this man is preached unto you the forgiveness of sins,

Acts 13:39
And by him are all that believe justified from all things from the which ye could not be justified by the law of Moses.

Acts 13:40
Beware therefore lest that fall on you, which is spoken of in the prophets:

Acts 13:41
Behold ye despisers, and wonder, and perish ye: for I do a work in your days, which ye shall not believe, if a man would declare it you.

Acts 13:42
When the jews were gone out of the Synagogue, the gentiles besought them that they would preach the word of god to them between the saboth days.

Acts 13:43
When the congregation was broken up, many of the jews and virtuous proselites followed Paul and Barnabas, which spake to them and exhorted them to continue in the grace of God.

Acts 13:44
And the next saboth day came Almost the whole city to gether to hear the word of God.

Acts 13:45
When the jews saw the people, they were full of indignation and spake against those things which were spoken of Paul, They spake against it, and dispraised it, rayling on it.

Acts 13:46
Then Paul and Barnabas waxed bold, and said: it was meet that the word of God should first have been preached to you. But seeing ye put it from you, and think yourselves unworthy of everlasting life, lo, we turn to the gentiles.

Acts 13:47
For so hath the Lord commanded us: I have made thee a light to the gentiles, that thou be health unto the end of the world.

Acts 13:48
The gentiles heard, and were glad and glorified the word of the Lord, and believed even as many as were ordained unto eternal life.

Acts 13:49
And the word of the Lord was published thorowout all the region.

Acts 13:50
But the jews moved the worshipful and honorable women, and the chief men of the city. And raised persecution against Paul and Barnabas, and expelled them out of their coasts.

Acts 13:51
But they shook off the dust off their feet against them, and came unto Iconium.

Acts 13:52
And the disciples were filled with joy and with the holy ghost.

Acts 14:1
It fortuned in Iconium that they went both to gether into the Sinagogue of the jewes, and so spake, that a great multitude both of the jewes and also of the greeks believed.

Acts 14:2
But the unbelieving jews, stirred up and unquieted the minds of the gentiles against the brethren.

Acts 14:3
Long time abode they there and quit themselves boldly with the help of the Lord, the which gave testimony unto the word of his grace, And caused signs and wonders to be done by their hands.

Acts 14:4
The people of city were divided: and part held with the jews, and part with the apostles.

Acts 14:5
When there was a fault made both of the gentiles and also of the jewes with their rulers, to put them to shame and to stone them,

Acts 14:6
they were ware of it, and fled unto Lystra and Derba, cities of Licaonia, and unto the region that lieth round about,

Acts 14:7
and there preached the gospell.

Acts 14:8
And there sat a certain man at Lystra weak in his feet, being halt from his mother's womb, and never walked.

Acts 14:9
The same heard Paul preach, which beheld him and perceived that he had faith to be whole,

Acts 14:10
and said with a loud voice: stand upright on thy feet. And he started up, and walked.

Acts 14:11
When the people saw what Paul had done, they lift up their voices, saying in the speech of Lycaonia: Goddes are come down to us in the likeness of men.

Acts 14:12
And they called Barnabas, Iupiter, and Paul Mercurius, because he was the preacher.

Acts 14:13
Then Iupiter's priest, which dwelt before their city, brought oxen and garlands unto the church porch, and would have done sacrifice with the people.

Acts 14:14
When the apostles, Barnabas and Paul heard that, they rent their clothes, and ran in among the people, crying

Acts 14:15
and saying: sirs, why do ye this? We are mortal men like unto you, and preach unto you, that ye should turn from these vanities unto the living God, which made heaven and earth and the sea and all that in them is,

Acts 14:16
the which in times past suffered all nations to walk in their own ways.

Acts 14:17
Nevertheless he left not himself without witness, in that he shewed his benefits, in giving us rain from heaven and fruitful seasons, filling our hearts with food and gladness.

Acts 14:18
And with these sayings, scarce refrained they the people, that they had not done sacrifice unto them.

Acts 14:19
Thither came certain jews from Antioche and Iconium, and obtained the peoples' consent and stoned Paul, and drew him out of the city, supposing he had been dead.

Acts 14:20
As the disciples stood round about him, he arose up and came into the city. And the next day he departed with Barnabas to Derba.

Acts 14:21
After they had preached to that city, and taught many, they returned again to Lystra, and to Iconium and Antioche,

Acts 14:22
and strengthened the disciples souls, exhorting them to continue in the faith, affirming that we must throwe much adversity enter into the kingdom of God.

Acts 14:23
And when they had ordained them seniors by election in every congregation, after they had prayed and fasted, they commended them to God on whom they believed.

Acts 14:24
And they went over all Pisidia and came into Pamphilia,

Acts 14:25
and when they had preached the word of God in Perga, they descended into Attalia,

Acts 14:26
and thence departed by ship to Antioche, from whence they were delivered unto the grace of God, to the work which they had fulfilled.

Acts 14:27
When they were come and had gathered the congregation together, they rehearsed all that God had done by them, and how he had opened the door of faith unto the Gentiles.

Acts 14:28
And there they abode long time with the disciples.

Acts 15:1
And there came certain from jewrie and taught the brethren: except ye be circumcised after the manner of Moses ye cannot be saved.

Acts 15:2
Then arose there dissension and disputing not a little unto Paul and Barnabas against them. And they determined that Paul and Barnabas and certain other of them should ascend to Ierusalem unto the apostles and seniors about this question.

Acts 15:3
After they were brought on their way by the congregation, they passed over Phenices and Samaria, declaring the conversation of the Gentiles, and they brought great joy unto all the brethren.

Acts 15:4
When they were come to Ierusalem they were received of the congregation and of the apostles and seniors. And they declared what things God had done by them.

Acts 15:5
Then arose there up certain of the sect of the pharises, which did believe saying that it was needful to circumcise them and to enjoin them to keep the law of Moses.

Acts 15:6
The apostles and seniors came together to reason of this matter.

Acts 15:7
When there was much disputing, Peter rose up and said unto them: Ye men and brethren, ye know how that a good while ago, God chose among us that the Gentiles by my mouth should hear the word of the gospell and believe.

Acts 15:8
And God which knoweth the heart, bare them witness, and gave unto them the holy ghost, even as he did unto us,

Acts 15:9
And he put no difference between them and us, and with faith purified their hearts.

Acts 15:10
Now therefore why tempt ye God, that ye would put a yoke on the disciples necks which neither our fathers nor we were able to bear:

Acts 15:11
But we believe that thorow the grace of the Lord Iesu Christ we shall be saved as they do.

Acts 15:12
Then all the multitude was peaced and gave audience to Barnabas and Paul which told what signs and wonders God had shewed among the gentiles by them.

Acts 15:13
As soon as they held their peace, Iames answered saying: Men and brethren hearken unto me,

Acts 15:14
Simeon told how God at the beginning did visit the gentiles, and received of them people unto his name.

Acts 15:15
And to this agreeth the words of the prophets, as it is written:

Acts 15:16
After this I will return, and will build again the tabernacle of David which is fallen down, and that which is fallen in decay of it will I build again and I will set it up,

Acts 15:17
that the residue of men might seek after the Lord, and also the Gentiles upon whom my name is called saith the Lord, which doth all these things:

Acts 15:18
known unto God are all his works from the beginning of the world.

Acts 15:19
Wherefore my sentence is, that we trouble not them which of the gentiles are turned to God:

Acts 15:20
but that we write unto them, that they abstain themselves from filthiness of images, from fornication, from strangled, and from blood.

Acts 15:21
For Moses of old time in every city hath them that preach him, and he is read in the synagogues every saboth day.

Acts 15:22
Then pleased it the apostles and seniors with the whole congregation to send chosen men of their own company to Antioche with Paul and Barnabas. They sent Iudas called also Barsabas and Silas which were chief men among the brethren

Acts 15:23
and gave them letters in their hands after this manner. The apostles, seniors and brethren send greetings unto the brethren which are of the gentiles in Antioch, Syria and Cilicia.

Acts 15:24
Forasmuch as we have heard that certain which departed from us, have troubled you with words, and cumbered your minds saying: Ye must be circumcised and keep the law, to whom we gave no such commandment.

Acts 15:25
It seemed therefore to us a good thing, when we were come together with one accord, to send chosen men unto you, with our beloved Barnabas and Paul,

Acts 15:26
men that have jeoparded their lives, for the name of our Lord Iesus Christ.

Acts 15:27
We have sent therefore Iudas and Sylas, which shall also tell you the same things by mouth.

Acts 15:28
For it seemed good to the holy ghost and to us, to put no grievous thing to you more than these necessary things,

Acts 15:29
that is to say, that ye abstain from things offered unto images, from blood, from strangled and fornication. From which if ye keep yourselves, ye shall do well. So fare ye well.

Acts 15:30
When they were departed, they came to Antioche and gathered the multitude together and delivered the pistel.

Acts 15:31
When they had read it, they rejoiced of that consolation.

Acts 15:32
Iudas and Silas being prophets, exhorted the people with much preaching, and strengthened them.

Acts 15:33
After they had tarried there a certain space, they were let go in peace of the brethren unto the apostles.

Acts 15:34
Notwithstanding it pleased Sylas to abide there still.

Acts 15:35
Paul and Barnabas continued in Antioche teaching, and preaching the word of the Lord with other many.

Acts 15:36
But after a certain space Paul said unto Barnabas: Let us go again and visit our brethren in every city, where we have shewed the word of the Lord, and see how they do.

Acts 15:37
Barnabas gave counsel, to take with them Ihon called also Marke:

Acts 15:38
But Paul thought it not meet to take him unto their company which departed from them at Pamphilia, and went not with them to the worke.

Acts 15:39
So sharp was the dissension between them, that they departed asunder one from the other. And Barnabas took Mark and sailed unto Cypers.

Acts 15:40
Paul chose Sylas and departed delivered of the brethren unto the grace of God.

Acts 15:41
And he went thorow all Cyria and Cilicia, stablishing the congregations.

Acts 16:1
Then came he to Derba and Listra. And behold a certain disciple was there named Timotheus, a woman's son which was a jewess and believed, but his father was a greek.

Acts 16:2
Of whom reported well, the brethren of Listra and of Iconium.

Acts 16:3
Paul would that he should go forth with him, and took and circumcised him because of the jewes which were in those quarters, for they knew all that his father was a greek.

Acts 16:4
As they went thorow the cities, they delivered them the decrees for to keep, ordained of the apostles and seniors which were at Ierusalem.

Acts 16:5
So were the congregations stablished in the faith, and increased in number daily.

Acts 16:6
When they had gone thorowout Phrigia and the region of Galatia, and were forbidden of the holy ghost to preach the word in Asia,

Acts 16:7
they came to Misia, and sought to go into Bethinia, and the spirit suffered them not.

Acts 16:8
When they went over Misia, and came down to Troada

Acts 16:9
and a vision appeared to Paul in the night. There stood a man of Macedonia and prayed him saying: Come into Macedonia and help us.

Acts 16:10
After he had seen the vision immediately we prepared to go into Macedonia certified that the Lord had called us for to preach the gospell unto them.

Acts 16:11
Then loosed we forth from Troada, and with a straight course came we to Samothracia, and the next day to Neapolim,

Acts 16:12
and from thence to Philippos, which is the chiefest city in the parts of Macedonia and a free city. We were in that city abiding a certain days.

Acts 16:13
And on the saboth days we went out of the city besides a river where men were wont to pray, and we sat down and spake unto the women which thither resorted.

Acts 16:14
And a certain woman named Lidia, a seller of purple, of the city of Thyatira which worshipped God, gave us audience, whose heart God opened that she attended unto those things which Paul spake.

Acts 16:15
When she was baptised, and her household, she besought us saying: If ye think that I believe on the Lord come into my house, and abide there. And she constrained us.

Acts 16:16
It fortuned as we went to prayer, a certain damsel possessed with a spirit that prophesied met us, which brought her master and masters much vantage with prophesying.

Acts 16:17
The same followed Paul and us saying: These men are the servants of the most high God, which shew unto us the way of health.

Acts 16:18
And this did she many days. But Paul not content turned about and said to the spirit: I command thee in the name of Iesu Christ that thou come out of her. And he came out the same hour.

Acts 16:19
When her master and mastress saw that the hope of their gains was gone, they caught Paul and Silas, and brought them into the market place unto the rulers,

Acts 16:20
and delivered them to the officers saying: These men trouble our city, which are jews

Acts 16:21
and shew new decrees, which are not lawful for us to receive, neither to observe seeing we are romans.

Acts 16:22
And the people ran on them, and the officers rent their clothes, and commanded them to be beaten with rods,

Acts 16:23
and when they had beaten them sore, they cast them into prison commanding the jailer to keep them surely.

Acts 16:24
Which when he had received such commandment thrust them into the inner prison, and made their feet fast in the stocks.

Acts 16:25
At midnight Paul and Silas prayed, and lauded God. And the prisoners heard them.

Acts 16:26
Suddenly there was a great earthquake, so that the foundation of the prison was shaken, and by and by all the doors opened, and every man's bonds were lowsed.

Acts 16:27
When the keeper of the prison waked out of his sleep, and saw the prison doors open, he drew out his sword and would have killed himself, supposing the prisoners had been fled.

Acts 16:28
Paul cried with a loud voice saying: Do thyself no harm, for we are all here.

Acts 16:29
He called for a light and sprang in, and came trembling, and fell down before Paul and Silas,

Acts 16:30
and brought them out and said, Sirs what must I do to be saved?

Acts 16:31
And they said: believe on the Lord Iesus, and thou shalt be saved and thy household.

Acts 16:32
And they preached unto him the word of the Lord, and to all that were in his house.

Acts 16:33
And he took them the same hour of the night and washed their wounds, and was baptised with all that belonged unto him straight way.

Acts 16:34
When he had brought them into his house, he set meat before them, and joyed that he with all his household believed on God.

Acts 16:35
And when it was day the officers sent the ministers saying: Let those men go.

Acts 16:36
The keeper of the prison told this saying to Paul: the officers have sent word to loose you. Now therefore get you hence and go in peace.

Acts 16:37
