Then said Paul unto them: They have beaten us openly uncondemned, for all that we are Romans, and have cast us into prison: and now would they send us away privily? Nay not so, but let them come themselves and fetch us out.

Acts 16:38
The ministers told these words unto the officers and they feared when they heard that they were Romans,

Acts 16:39
and came and besought them, and brought them out, and desired them to depart out of the city.

Acts 16:40
They went out of the prison and entered into the house of Lidia, and when they had seen the brethren, they comforted them and departed.

Acts 17:1
As they made their journey thorow Amphipolis, and Apolonia, they came to Thessalonica where was a synagogue of the jewes.

Acts 17:2
Paul as his manner was went in unto them, and three saboth days declared out of the scripture unto them,

Acts 17:3
opening and alleging that Christ must needs have suffered and risen again from death. And that this Iesus was Christ, whom (said he) I preach to you.

Acts 17:4
And some of them believed and came and companied with Paul and Silas. Also of the honorable greeks a great multitude, and of the chief women, not a few.

Acts 17:5
The jewes which believed not having indignation took unto them evil men which were vagabonds, and gathered a company, and set all the city on a roar, and made assault unto the house of Iason, and sought to bring them out to the people.

Acts 17:6
and when they found them not, they drew Iason and certain brethren unto the heads of the city crying: These that trouble the world are come hither also,

Acts 17:7
which Iason hath received privily. And these all do contrary to the ordinations of Cesar, affirming another king, one Iesus.

Acts 17:8
And they troubled the people and the officers of the city when they heard these things.

Acts 17:9
And when they were sufficiently answered of Iason, and of the other they let them go.

Acts 17:10
The brethren immediately sent away Paul, and Silas by night unto Berrea. When they were come thither they entered into the Synagogue of the jews.

Acts 17:11
These were the noblest among them of Thessalonia, which received the word with all diligence of mind, and searched the scriptures daily whether those things were even so.

Acts 17:12
And many of them believed, and of worshipful women which were greeks, and of men not a few.

Acts 17:13
When the jews of Thessalonia had knowledge that the word of God was preached of Paul at Berrea, they came thither and moved the people,

Acts 17:14
and then by and by the brethren sent away Paul to go unto the sea: but Silas and Timotheus abode there still.

Acts 17:15
They that guided Paul brought him unto Athens, and received a commandment unto Silas and Timotheus for to come to him at once. And came their way.

Acts 17:16
While Paul waited for them at Athens, his spirit was moved in him to see the city given to worshipping of images.

Acts 17:17
Then he disputed in the synagogue with the jews, and with the devout persons, And in the market daily with them that came unto him.

Acts 17:18
Certain Philosophers of the Epicures, and of the Stoyckes disputed with him. And some there were which said: what will this babbler say. Other said: he seemeth to be a tidings bringer of new devils, because he preached unto them Iesus, and the resurrection,

Acts 17:19
and they took him, and brought him into Marce street saying: may we not know what is this new doctrine whereof thou speakest.

Acts 17:20
For thou bringest strange tidings to our ears. We would know therefore what these things mean.

Acts 17:21
For all the Athenians and strangers which were there gave themselves to nothing else, but either to tell or to hear new tidings.

Acts 17:22
Paul stood in the midst of Marce street and said, ye men of Athens, I perceive that in all things ye are somewhat superstitious.

Acts 17:23
For as I passed by and beheld the manner how ye worship your goddes, I found an altar wherein was written: unto the unknown God. Whom ye then ignorantly worship, him shew I unto you:

Acts 17:24
God that made the world, and all that are in it, seeing that he is Lord of heaven and earth, he dwelleth not in temples made with hands

Acts 17:25
neither is worshipped with men's hands, as though he needed of any thing. Forasmuch as he giveth to all men life and breath every where,

Acts 17:26
and hath made of one blood all nations of men, for to dwell on all the face of the earth. And hath assigned times appointed before, And the ends of their inhabitation,

Acts 17:27
that they should seek God, if they might feel and find him, though he be not far from every one of us.

Acts 17:28
For in him we live, move, and have our being, as certain of your own poets said. For we are also his generation.

Acts 17:29
Forasmuch then as we are the generation of God, we ought not to think that the godhead is like unto gold, silver, or stone, graven by craft and imagination of man.

Acts 17:30
And the time of this ignorance God regarded not: but now he biddeth all men everywhere repent,

Acts 17:31
because he hath appointed a day, in the which he will judge the world according to righteousness, by that man, whom he hath appointed, and hath given faith to all men, after that he had raised him from death.

Acts 17:32
When they heard of the resurrection from death, some mocked, and other said: we will hear thee again of this matter.

Acts 17:33
So Paul departed from among them.

Acts 17:34
Certain men clave unto Paul and believed, among the which was Dionysius a senator, and a woman named Damaris, and other with them.

Acts 18:1
After that, Paul departed from Athens, and came to Corinthum,

Acts 18:2
and found a certain jew named Aquila, born in Ponthus, lately come from Italy with his wife Priscilla (because that the Emperor Claudius had commanded all jewes to depart from Rome) and he drew unto them.

Acts 18:3
And because he was of the same craft he abode with them and wrought (their craft was to make tents.)

Acts 18:4
and he preached in the synagogue every saboth day, And exhorted the jewes and the gentiles.

Acts 18:5
When Silas and Timotheus were come from Macedonia Paul was pained by the spirit, as he testified to the jewes that Iesus was Christ.

Acts 18:6
When they said contrary and blasphemed, he shook his raiment and said unto them: your blood upon your own heads. For henceforth I go unto the gentiles,

Acts 18:7
and he departed thence, and entered into a certain man's house named Iustus which worshipped God, whose house joined hard to the synagogue.

Acts 18:8
One Crispus a ruler of the synagogue believed on the Lord with all his household. And many of the Corinthians gave audience and believed, and were baptised.

Acts 18:9
Then spake the Lord to Paul in the night by a vision: be not afraid, but speak, and hold not thy peace:

Acts 18:10
for I am with thee, and no man shall invade thee that shall hurt thee. For I have much people in this city.

Acts 18:11
And he rested there a year and six months, and taught them the word of God.

Acts 18:12
When Gallio was ruler of the country of Acaia. The jewes made insurrection with one accord against Paul, and brought him to the judge's seat,

Acts 18:13
saying: This man teacheth to worship God contrary to the law.

Acts 18:14
And as Paul was about to open his mouth Gallio said unto the jews: if it were a matter of wrong, or an evil deed (o ye jews) reason would that I should hear you:

Acts 18:15
but if it be a question of words, or of names, or of your law, look ye to it yourselves. For I will be no judge in such matters,

Acts 18:16
and he drave them from his seat.

Acts 18:17
Then took all the greeks Sosthenes a ruler of the Synagogue and smote him before the judge's seat. And Gallio cared for none of those things.

Acts 18:18
Paul after this, tarried there yet a good while, and then took his leave of the brethren, and sailed thence into Ciria, Priscilla and Aquila accompanying him after that he shore his head in Cenchrea. For he had a vow.

Acts 18:19
And he came to Ephesus and left them there: but he himself entered into the Synagogue, and reasoned with the jewes.

Acts 18:20
When they desired him to tarry longer time with them, he consented not,

Acts 18:21
but bade them fare well saying: I must needs at this feast that cometh be in Ierusalem: but I will return again unto you if God will.

Acts 18:22
And departed from Ephesus and came unto Cesarea: and ascended and saluted the congregation,

Acts 18:23
and departed unto Antioche, and when he had tarried there a while, he departed, and went over all the country of Galatacia and Phrigia by order, strengthening all the disciples.

Acts 18:24
And a certain iewe named Apollos, born at Alexandria came to Ephesus. An eloquent man, and mighty in the scriptures.

Acts 18:25
The same was informed in the way of the Lord, and he spake fervently in the spirit, and taught diligently the things of the Lord, and knew but the baptism of Ihon only.

Acts 18:26
And the same began to speak boldly in the Synagogue. When Priscilla and Aquila had heard him: they took him unto them, And expounded unto him the way of God more perfectly.

Acts 18:27
When he was disposed to go into Acaia, the brethren exhorted him thereto, and wrote unto the disciples that they should receive him. After he was come thither he helped them much, which had believed thorow grace.

Acts 18:28
And mightily he overcame the jews openly shewing by the scriptures that Iesus was Christ.

Acts 19:1
It fortuned, while Apollos was at Corinthum, that Paul passed over the upper coasts, and came to Ephesus, and found certain disciples

Acts 19:2
and said unto them: have ye received the holy ghost after ye believed? And they said unto him: No, neither have we heard if there be any holy ghost or no.

Acts 19:3
And he said unto them: wherewith were ye then baptised? And they said: with Ihon's baptism.

Acts 19:4
Then said Paul: Ihon verily baptised with the baptism of repentance, saying unto the people that they should believe on him, which should come after him. That is on Christ Iesus.

Acts 19:5
When they heard that, they were baptised in the name of the Lord Iesu,

Acts 19:6
and when Paul laid his hands upon them, the holy ghost came on them. And they spake with tongues and prophesied,

Acts 19:7
All the men were about xij.

Acts 19:8
And he went into the synagogue, and behaved himself boldly for the space of three months, disputing, and giving them exhortations of the kingdom of God.

Acts 19:9
When divers waxed hard hearted, and believed not, but spake evil of the way of the Lord before the multitude: he departed from them, And severed the disciples away, And taught daily in the school of one called Tirannus.

Acts 19:10
And this continued by the space of two years: So that all they which dwelt in Asia heard the word of the Lord Iesu, both jewes and greeks.

Acts 19:11
And God wrought not small miracles by the hands of Paul.

Acts 19:12
So that from his body were brought unto the sick, napkins or partlets, and the diseases and evil spirits departed from them.

Acts 19:13
Certain of the vagabond jewes exorcists, took upon them to call over them which had evil spirits the name of the Lord Iesus saying: We adjure you by Iesu whom Paul preacheth.

Acts 19:14
There were seven sons of one Sceva a ruler of the synagogue which did so:

Acts 19:15
and the evil spirit answered and said: Iesus I know, and Paul I know: but who are ye?

Acts 19:16
And the man in whom the wicked devil was, ran on them, and overcame them, and prevailed against them, so that they fled out of the house naked and wounded.

Acts 19:17
This was known to all the jewes and greeks also, which dwelt at Ephesus, and fear came on them all. And they magnified the name of the Lord Iesus.

Acts 19:18
And many that believed came, and confessed and shewed their works.

Acts 19:19
Many of them which used curious crafts, brought their books and burned them before all men, and they counted the price of them, and found it fifty thousand silverlings.

Acts 19:20
So mightily grew the word of God, and prevailed.

Acts 19:21
After these things were ended Paul purposed in the spirit, to pass over Macedonia and Acaia, and to go to Ierusalem saying: After I have been there I must also see Rome.

Acts 19:22
So sent he into Macedonia two of them that ministered unto him: Timotheus and Erastus: but he himself remained in Asia. For a season.

Acts 19:23
The same time there arose no little a do about that way.

Acts 19:24
For a certain man named Demetrius, a goldsmith, which made silver shrines for Diana, was not a little beneficial unto the craftsmen:

Acts 19:25
which he called together with the workmen of like occupation, and said: Sirs ye know that by this craft we have vantage.

Acts 19:26
Moreover ye see and hear that not alone at Ephesus: but almost thorow out all Asia, this Paul entiseth, and turned away much people saying: that they be not goddes which are made with hands:

Acts 19:27
so that not only this our craft cometh into peril to be set at nought: but that also the temple of great Diana should be despised. And her majesty should be destroyed, which all Asia, and the world worshippeth.

Acts 19:28
When they heard these sayings, they were full of wrath, and cried out saying: Great is Diana of the Ephesians.

Acts 19:29
And all the city was on a roar, and they rushed into the common hall with one assent, and caught Gaius, and Aristarcus, men of Macedonia, Paul's companions.

Acts 19:30
When Paul would have entered in unto the people, the disciples suffered him not.

Acts 19:31
Certain also of the chief of Asia which were his friends, sent unto him, desiring him that he would not press into the common hall.

Acts 19:32
Some cried one thing, and some another and the congregation was all out of quiet, and the more part knew not wherefore they were come together.

Acts 19:33
Some of the company drew forth Alexander (the jewes thrusting him forwards) Alexander beckoned with the hand, and would have given the people an answer.

Acts 19:34
When they knew that he was a iewe, there arose a shout almost for the space of two hours of all men crying, great is Diana of the Ephesians.

Acts 19:35
When the town clerk had ceased the people he said: ye men of Ephesus: what man is it that knoweth not how that the city of the Ephesians is a worshipper of the great goddess Diana, and of the image which came from heaven.

Acts 19:36
Seeing then that no man saith here against, ye ought to be content, and to do nothing rashly,

Acts 19:37
For ye have brought hither these men, which are neither robbers of churches, nor yet despisers of your goddess.

Acts 19:38
Wherefore if Demetrius and the craftsmen which are with him, have any saying to any man, the law is open, and there are rulers, let them accuse one another.

Acts 19:39
If ye go about any other thing, it may be determined in a lawful congregation.

Acts 19:40
For we are in jeopardy to be accused of this day's business. For as much as there is no cause whereby we may give a reckoning of this concourse of people.

Acts 19:41
And when he had thus spoken, he let the congregation depart.

Acts 20:1
After the rage was ceased, Paul called the disciples unto him, and took his leave of them, and departed for to go into Macedonia.

Acts 20:2
And when he had gone over those parts, and given them large exhortations, he came into Greece.

Acts 20:3
And there abode. iij. months. When the jewes laid wait for him as he was about to sail into Syria, He purposed to return through Macedonia.

Acts 20:4
There accompanied him into Asia Sopater of Berrea: And of Thessalonia Aristarcus and Secundus, and Gaius of Derba, and Timotheus: Out of Asia Tychicus, and Trophimos.

Acts 20:5
These went before, and tarried us at Troas.

Acts 20:6
We sailed away from Philippos after the ester holidays, and came unto them to Troas in five days, where we abode seven days.

Acts 20:7
On a saboth day the disciples came to gedger for to break bread, and Paul preached unto them (ready to depart on the morrow) and continued the preaching unto midnight.

Acts 20:8
There were many lights in the chamber where we were gathered together,

Acts 20:9
and there sat in a window a certain young man named Eutichus, fallen into a deep sleep. And as Paul declared he was the more overcome with sleep, and fell down from the third loft, and was taken up dead.

Acts 20:10
Paul went down and fell on him, and embraced him, and said: Make nothing ado. For his life is in him.

Acts 20:11
When he was come up again, he brake bread, and tasted, and communed a long while even till the morning, and so departed.

Acts 20:12
They brought the young man alive, and were not a little comforted.

Acts 20:13
Then took we shipping, and departed unto Asson, there to receive Paul. For so had he appointed, and would himself go by land.

Acts 20:14
When he was come to us unto Asson, we took him in, and came to Mittilenes.

Acts 20:15
And sailed thence, and came the next day over against Chios. And the day following we arrived at Samos, and tarried at Trogilon. The next day we came to Mileton.

Acts 20:16
For Paul had determined to leave Ephesus as they sailed, because he would not spend the time in Asia. For he hasted to be (if he were possible) at Ierusalem at the day of Pentecost.

Acts 20:17
From Mileton he sent to Ephesus, and called the seniors of the congregation.

Acts 20:18
When they were come to him, he said to them: Ye know from the first day that I came unto Asia, after what manner I have been with you at all seasons,

Acts 20:19
serving God with all humbleness of mind, and with many tears, and temptations, which happened unto me by the layings wait of the jewes,

Acts 20:20
and how I kept back nothing that might be for your profit: but that I have shewed you, and taught you openly and at home in your houses,

Acts 20:21
witnessing both to the jewes, and also to the greeks, the repentance toward God, and faith toward our Lord Iesu.

Acts 20:22
And now behold I go bound in the spirit unto Ierusalem, and know not what shall come of me there,

Acts 20:23
but that the holy ghost witnesseth in every city saying: that bonds and trouble abide me:

Acts 20:24
but none of those things move me. Neither is my life dear unto myself, that I might fulfil my course with joy, and the ministration which I have received of the Lord Iesu to testify the gospell of the grace of God.

Acts 20:25
And now behold, I am sure that henceforth ye all (thorow whom I have gone preaching the kingdom of God) shall see my face no more.

Acts 20:26
Wherefore I take you to record this same day, that I am pure from the blood of all men.

Acts 20:27
For I have kept nothing back: but have shewed you all the counsel of God.

Acts 20:28
Take heed therefore unto yourselves, and to all the flock, whereof the holy ghost hath made you overseers, to rule the congregation of God, which he hath purchased with his blood.

Acts 20:29
For I am sure of this, that after my departing shall grievous wolves enter in among you, which will not spare the flock.

Acts 20:30
And of your own selves shall men arise speaking perverse things, to draw disciples after them.

Acts 20:31
Therefore awake and remember, that by the space of iij. years I ceased not to warn every one of you, both night and day with tears.

Acts 20:32
And now dear brethren I commend you to God and to the word of his grace, which is able to build further, and to give you an inheritance among all them which are sanctified.

Acts 20:33
I have desired no man's silver, gold, or vesture.

Acts 20:34
Ye know well that these hands have ministered unto my necessities, and to them that were with me.

Acts 20:35
I have shewed you all things, how that so laboring ye ought to receive the weak, and to remember the words of the Lord Iesu, how that he said: It is more blessed to give, than to receive.

Acts 20:36
When he had thus spoken, he kneeled down, and prayed with them all.

Acts 20:37
And they wept all abundantly, and fell on Paul's neck, and kissed him

Acts 20:38
sorrowing, most of all, for the words, which he spake, that they should see his face no more. And they accompanied him unto the ship.

Acts 21:1
And it chanced that as soon as we had launched forth, and were departed from them, we came with a straight course unto Choon, and the day following unto the Rhodes, and from thence unto Patara.

Acts 21:2
And we found a ship ready to sail unto Phenices, and went aboard and set forth.

Acts 21:3
Then appeared unto us Cyprus, and we left it on the left hand, and sailed unto Syria, and came unto Tyre. For there the ship unladed her burden.

Acts 21:4
And when we had found brethren, we tarried there. vij. days. And they told Paul thorow the spirit, that he should not go up to Ierusalem.

Acts 21:5
And when the days were ended we departed, and went our ways, and they all brought us on our way, with their wives and children, till we were come out of the city. And we kneeled down in the shore and prayed.

Acts 21:6
And when we had taken our leave one of another, we took ship, and they returned home again.

Acts 21:7
When we had full ended the course, from Tyre, we arrived at Ptholomaida, and saluted the brethren, and abode with them one day.

Acts 21:8
The next day, we that were of Paulus company, came unto Cesarea. And we entered into the house of Philip the evangelist, which was one of the seven, and abode with him.

Acts 21:9
The same man had four daughters virgins, which did prophesy.

Acts 21:10
And as we tarried there a good many days, there came a certain prophet from jewry, named Agabus.

Acts 21:11
When he was come unto us, he took Paul's girdle, and bound his hands and feet and said: Thus saith the holy ghost: So shall the jewes at Ierusalem, bind the man that owneth this girdle, and shall deliver him into the hands of the gentiles.

Acts 21:12
When we heard this, both we and other of the same place, besought him, that he would not go up to Ierusalem.

Acts 21:13
Then Paul answered, and said: What do ye weeping, and breaking mine heart? I am ready not to be bound only, but also to die at Ierusalem for the name of the Lord Iesu.

Acts 21:14
When we could not turn his mind, we ceased saying: The will of the Lord be fulfilled.

Acts 21:15
After those days we made ourselves ready, and went up to Ierusalem.

Acts 21:16
There went with us also certain of his disciples of Cesarea, and brought with them one Mnason of Cyprus, an olde disciple, with whom we should lodge.

Acts 21:17
And when we were come to Ierusalem, the brethren received us gladly.

Acts 21:18
On the morrow Paul went in with us unto Iames. And all the seniors came together.

Acts 21:19
And when he had saluted them, he told by order, what things God had wrought among the gentiles by his ministration.

Acts 21:20
When they heard it, they glorified the Lord, and said unto him: Thou seest brother, how many thousand jewes there are which believe, and they are all zealous over the law.

Acts 21:21
And they are informed of thee that thou teachest all the jewes which are among the gentiles to forsake Moses, and sayest that they ought not to circumcise their children, neither to live after the customs.

Acts 21:22
What is it therefore? The multitude must needs come together. For they shall hear that thou art come.

Acts 21:23
Do therefore this that we say to thee. We have iiij. men, which have a vow on them.

Acts 21:24
Them take and purify thyself with them, and do cost on them, that they may shave their heads and all shall know that those things which they have heard of thee are nothing: but that thou thyself also walkest and keepest the law.

Acts 21:25
As touching the gentiles which believe we have written and concluded, that they observe no such things: but that they keep themselves from things offered to idols, from blood, from strangled, and from fornication.

Acts 21:26
Then the next day Paul took the men and purified himself with them, and entered into the temple, declaring the fulfilling of the days of purification, until that an oblation should be offered for every one of them.

Acts 21:27
And as the seven days should have been ended, the jewes which were of Asia when they saw him in the temple, they moved all the people and laid hands on him crying:

Acts 21:28
Men of Israhell help. This is the man that teacheth all men everywhere against the people, and the law, and this place. Moreover also he hath brought greeks into the temple, and hath polluted this holy place.

Acts 21:29
For they saw one Trophimus an Ephesian with him in the city. Him they supposed Paul had brought into the temple.

Acts 21:30
And all the city was moved, and the people swarmed together. And they took Paul, and drew him out of the temple, and forthwith the doors were shut to.

Acts 21:31
As they went about to kill him, tidings came unto the high captain of the soldiers, that all Ierusalem was moved.

Acts 21:32
Which immediately took soldiers and undercaptains, and ran down unto them. When they saw the uppercaptain and the soldiers, They left smiting of Paul.

Acts 21:33
Then the captain came near and took him, and commanded him to be bound with two chains, and demanded what he was, and what he had done.

Acts 21:34
One cried this, another that, among the people. And when he could not know the certainty, for the rage: He commanded him to be carried into the castle.

Acts 21:35
When he came unto a grece, it fortuned that he was borne of the soldiers for the violence of the people.

Acts 21:36
The multitude of the people followed after crying: away with him.

Acts 21:37
And as Paul should have been carried into the castle, He said unto the high captain: May I speak unto thee? Which said: Canst thou speak greek?

Acts 21:38
Art not thou that Egyptian which before these days, made an uproar, and led out into the wilderness iiij. thousand men that were murderers?

Acts 21:39
Paul said: I am a man which am a iewe of Tharsus a city in Cicill, a citizen of no vile city, I beseech thee suffer me to licence,

Acts 21:40
Paul stood on the steps, and beckoned with the hand unto the people, and there was made a great silence. And he spake unto them in Hebrew saying:

Acts 22:1
Ye men, brethren, and fathers, hear mine answer which I make unto you.

Acts 22:2
When they heard that he spake Hebrew unto them, they kept the more silence.

Acts 22:3
And he said: I am verily a man which am a iewe, born in Tharsus, a city in Cicill, nevertheless yet brought up in this city, at the feet of Gamaliel, and informed diligently in the law of the fathers, and was fervent minded to Godward, as ye all are this same day,

Acts 22:4
and I persecuted this way unto the death binding, and delivering into prison both men and women,

Acts 22:5
as the chief priest doth bear me witness, and all the seniors: of whom also I received letters unto the brethren, and went to Damascon to bring them which were there bound unto Ierusalem for to be punished.

Acts 22:6
And it fortuned that as I made my journey, and was come nye unto Damascon, about noon, suddenly there shone from heaven a great light round about me,

Acts 22:7
and I fell unto the earth, and heard a voice saying unto me. Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou me?

Acts 22:8
And I answered: what art thou Lord? and he said unto me? I am Iesus of Nazareth, whom thou persecutest.

Acts 22:9
And they that were with me saw verily a light and were afraid: but they heard not the voice of him that spake with me.

Acts 22:10
And I said: what shall I do Lord? And the Lord said unto me: Arise and go into Damascon and there it shall be told thee of all things which are appointed for thee to do.

Acts 22:11
And when I saw nothing for the brightness of that light, I was led by the hand of them that were with me, and came into Damascon.

Acts 22:12
One Ananias a perfect man, and as pertaining to the law having good report of all the jewes which there dwelt,

Acts 22:13
came unto me, and stood and said unto me: Brother Saul receive thy sight. And that same hour I received my sight and saw him.

Acts 22:14
And he said unto me, the God of our fathers hath ordained thee before, that thou shouldest know his will, and shouldest see that which is rightful, and shouldest hear the voice of his mought:

Acts 22:15
for thou shalt be his witness unto all men of those things which thou hast seen and heard.

Acts 22:16
And now: why tarriest thou? Arise and be baptised, and wash away thy sins, in calling on the name of the Lord.

Acts 22:17
And it fortuned, when I was come again to Ierusalem and prayed in the temple, that I was in a trance,

Acts 22:18
And saw him saying unto me: Make haste, and get thee quickly out of Ierusalem: for they will not receive the witness that thou bearest of me.

Acts 22:19
And I said: Lord they know that I prisoned, and beat in every synagogue them that believed on thee.

Acts 22:20
And when the blood of thy witness Stephen was shed, I also stood by, and consented unto his death and kept the raiment of them that slew him.

Acts 22:21
And he said unto me: depart for I will send thee afar hence unto the gentiles.

Acts 22:22
They gave him audience unto this word, and lifted up their voices and said: away with such a fellow from the earth: it is pity that he should live.

Acts 22:23
And they cried and cast off their clothes, and threw dust into the air.

Acts 22:24
The captain bade him to be brought into the castle, and commanded him to be scourged, and to be examined, that he might know wherefore they cried on him.

Acts 22:25
And as they bound him with thongs, Paul said unto an undercaptain: Is it lawful for you to scourge a Roman uncondemned?

Acts 22:26
When the centurion heard that, he went to the uppercaptain, and told him saying: What intendest thou to do? This man is a Roman.

Acts 22:27
The uppercaptain came to him, and said: Tell me, art thou a Roman? He said: Yea

Acts 22:28
And the captain answered: With much money obtained I this freedom. And Paul said: I was freeborn.

Acts 22:29
Then straightway departed from him they which should have examined him. And the captain also was afraid, after he knew that he was a Roman: because he had bound him.

Acts 22:30
On the morrow he lowsed him from his bonds desiring to know the certainty for what cause he was accused of the jewes, and commanded the high priests and all the council to come together, and brought Paul, and set him before them.

Acts 23:1
Paul beheld the council and said: Men and brethren, I have lived in all good conscience before God until this day.

Acts 23:2
The high priest Ananias commanded them that stood by, to smite him on the mought.

Acts 23:3
Then said Paul to him: God shall smite thee thou painted wall. Sittest thou and judgest me after the law: and commandest me to be smitten contrary to the law?

Acts 23:4
And they that stood by said: Revilest thou Godde's high priest?

Acts 23:5
Then said Paul: I wist not brethren, that he was the high priest. For it is written thou shalt not speak evil to the ruler of thy people.

Acts 23:6
When Paul perceived that the one part were saduces, and the other pharyses: He cried out in the council. Men and brethren I am a pharisaye, the son of a pharisaye. Of hope, and of resurrection from death I am judged.

Acts 23:7
And when he had so said, there arose a debate between the pharises and the saduces, and the multitude was divided.

Acts 23:8
For the saduces say that there is no resurrection, neither angel, nor spirit. But the pharyses grant both.

Acts 23:9
And there arose a great cry, and the scribes which were of the pharyses' part strove saying: We find none evil in this man. Though a spirit, or an angel hath appeared to him, let us not strive against God.

Acts 23:10
And when there arose great debate, the captain fearing lest Paul should have been plucked asunder of them, commanded the soldiers to go down, and to take him from among them, and to bring him into the castle.

Acts 23:11
The night following God stood by him and said: Be of good cheer Paul: For as thou hast testified of me in Ierusalem, so must thou bear witness at Rome.

Acts 23:12
When day was come, certain of the jewes gathered themselves togeder, and made a vow saying: that they would neither eat nor drink till they had killed Paul.

Acts 23:13
They were about .xl. which had made this conspiration.

Acts 23:14
And they came to the chief priest and seniors, and said: we have bound ourselves with a vow, that we will eat nothing until we have slain Paul.

Acts 23:15
Now therefore give ye knowledge to the upper captain, and to the council that he bring him forth unto us tomorrow, as though we would know some thing more perfectly of him. But we (or ever he come near) are ready in the mean season to kill him.

Acts 23:16
When Paul's sister's son heard of their laying await, he went and entered into the castle, and told Paul.

Acts 23:17
And Paul called one of the under captains unto him, and said: Bring this young man unto the captain: for he hath a certain thing to shew him.

Acts 23:18
And he took him, and led him to the high captain, and said: Paul the prisoner called me unto him and prayed me to bring this young man unto thee, which hath a certain matter to shew thee.

Acts 23:19
The high captain took him by the hand, and went apart with him out of the way: and asked him: what hast thou to say unto me?

Acts 23:20
And he said: the jewes are determined to desire thee that thou wouldest bring forth Paul tomorrow into the council, as though they would enquire somewhat of him more perfectly.

Acts 23:21
But follow not their minds: for there lay await for him of them, more than xl. men, which have bound themselves with a vow, that they will neither eat nor drink till they have killed him. And now are they ready, and look for thy promise.

Acts 23:22
The upper captain let the young man depart and charged him: See thou tell no man that thou hast told me this.

Acts 23:23
And he called unto him two under captains, saying: make ready two hundred soldiers to go to Cesarea, and horsemen threescore and ten. And spearmen two hundred, at the third hour of the night.

Acts 23:24
And deliver them beasts that they may put Paul on, and bring him safe unto Felix the high debite,

Acts 23:25
and wrote a letter in this manner.

Acts 23:26
Claudius Lisias unto the most mighty ruler Felix sendeth greetings.

Acts 23:27
This man was taken of the jewes, and should have been killed of them: Then came I with soldiers, and rescued him, and perceived that he was a Roman.

Acts 23:28
And when I would have known the cause, wherefore they accused him, I brought him forth into their council.

Acts 23:29
There perceived I that he was accused of questions of their law: but was not guilty of any thing worthy of death, or of bonds.

Acts 23:30
Afterward when it was shewed me how that the jews laid wait for the man, I sent him straight way to thee, and gave commandment to his accusers, if they had ought against him, to tell it unto thee: fare well.

Acts 23:31
The soldiers as it was commanded them, took Paul and brought him by night to Antipatras.

Acts 23:32
On the morrow they left horsemen to go with him, and returned unto the castle.

Acts 23:33
When they came to Cesarea, they delivered the pistel to the debite, and presented Paul before him.

Acts 23:34
When the debite had read the letter, he asked of what country he was. And when he understood that he was of Cicill,

Acts 23:35
I will hear thee (said he) when thine accusers are come also: And commanded him to be kept in Herode's palace.

Acts 24:1
After v. days, Ananias the high priest descended, with seniors, and with a certain orator named Tartullus, and enformed the ruler against Paul.

Acts 24:2
When Paul was called forth, Tartullus began to accuse him saying: Seeing that we live in great quietness by the means of thee and that many good things are done unto this nation thorow thy providence:

Acts 24:3
that allow we ever and in all places, most mighty Felix with all thanks.

Acts 24:4
Notwithstanding, lest I be not tedious unto thee, I pray thee that thou wouldest hear us of thy courtesy a few words.

Acts 24:5
We have found this man a pestilent fellow, and a mover of debate among all the jewes thorow out the world, And a maintainer of the sect of the Nazarens:

Acts 24:6
Which also hath enforced to pollute the temple, whom we took and would have judged according to our law:

Acts 24:7
but the high captain Lisias came upon us, and with great violence took him out of our hands,

Acts 24:8
commanding his accusers to come unto thee, of whom thou mayest (if thou wilt enquire) know the certain of all these things where of we accuse him.

Acts 24:9
The jewes likewise affirmed, saying that it was even so.

Acts 24:10
Then Paul (after that the ruler himself had beckoned unto him that he should speak) answered: I shall with a more quiet mind answer for myself, forasmuch as I understand that thou hast been of many years a judge unto this people,

Acts 24:11
because that thou mayest know that there are yet but xij. days since I went up to Ierusalem for to pray.

Acts 24:12
And that they neither found me in the temple disputing with any man, either raising up the people, neither in the synagogues nor in the city.

Acts 24:13
Neither can they prove the things whereof they accuse me.

Acts 24:14
But this I confess unto thee, that after that way (which they call heresy) so worship I the God of my fathers, believing all things which are written in the law and the prophets,

Acts 24:15
and have hope towards God, that the same resurrection from death (which they themselves look for also) shall be both of just and unjust.

Acts 24:16
And therefore study I to have a clear conscience toward God, and toward man also.

Acts 24:17
Many years ago I came and brought alms to my people and offerings,

Acts 24:18
in the which they found me purified in the temple, neither with multitude, nor yet with unquietness.

Acts 24:19
There were certain jewes out of Asia which ought to be here present before thee, and accuse me, if they had ought against me:

Acts 24:20
or else let these same here say, if they have found any evildoing in me, while I stand here in the council,

Acts 24:21
except it be for this one voice, that I cried standing among them of the resurrection from death am I judged of you this day.

Acts 24:22
When Felix heard that he deferred them, for he knew very well of that way and said: when Lisias the captain is come, I will know the utmost of your matters.

Acts 24:23
And he commanded an undercaptain to keep Paul, and that he should have rest, and that he should forbid none of his acquaintance to minister unto him, or to come unto him.

Acts 24:24
After a certain days came Felix, and his wife Drusilla which was a jewess, and called forth Paul, and heard him of the faith which is toward Christ.

Acts 24:25
And as he preached of Justice, temperance, and Judgement to come, Felix trembled, and answered: thou hast done enough at this time, depart, when I have a convenient time, I will send for thee.

Acts 24:26
He hoped also that money should have been given him of Paul that he might loose him, wherefore he called him the oftener, and communed with him.

Acts 24:27
After two year came Festus Porcius into Felix room, and Felix willing to shew the jewes a pleasure left Paul in prison bound.

Acts 25:1
When Festus was come into the province, after three days, he ascended from Cesarea unto Ierusalem.

Acts 25:2
Then enformed him the high priests, and the chief of the jews against Paul. And they entreated him,

Acts 25:3
and desired favour against him that he would send for him to Ierusalem, and laid wait for him in the way to kill him.

Acts 25:4
Festus answered that Paul should be kept at Cesarea: but that he himself would shortly depart thither.

Acts 25:5
Let them therefore (said he) which among you are able to do it come down with us and accuse him, if there be any fault in the man.

Acts 25:6
When he had tarried there more then ten days he departed unto Cesarea, and the next day sat down in the judgement seat, and commanded Paul to be brought.

Acts 25:7
When he was come the jewes which were come from Ierusalem, came about him and laid many and grievous complaints against Paul, which they could not prove

Acts 25:8
as long as he answered for himself, that he had neither against the law of the jewes, neither against the temple, nor yet against Cesar offended any thing at all.

Acts 25:9
Festus willing to do the jewes a pleasure, answered Paul, and said: Wilt thou go to Ierusalem, and there be judged of these things before me?

Acts 25:10
Then said Paul: I stand at Cesar's judgement seat, where I ought to be judged. To the jewes have I no harm done, as thou verily well knowest.

Acts 25:11
If I have hurt them, or committed any thing worthy of death, I refuse not to die. If none of these things are, where of they accuse me, no man ought to deliver me to them. I appeal unto Cesar.

Acts 25:12
Then spake Festus with deliberation, and answered: Thou hast appealed unto Cesar: unto Cesar shalt thou go.

Acts 25:13
After a certain days king Agrippa and Bernice came unto Cesarea to salute Festus.

Acts 25:14
And when they had been there a good season, Festus rehearsed Paul's cause unto the king saying: There is a certain man left in prison of Felix

Acts 25:15
about whom when I came to Ierusalem the high priests, and seniors of the jewes enformed me, and desired to have judgement against him.

Acts 25:16
To whom I answered: It is not the manner of the Romans to deliver any man that he should perish, before that he which is accused, have the accusers before him, and have license to answer for himself, as pertaining to the crime whereof he is accused:

Acts 25:17
when they were come hither, without delay on the morrow I sat to give judgement, and commanded the man to be brought forth.

Acts 25:18
Against whom when the accusers stood up, they brought none accusation of such things as I supposed:

Acts 25:19
But had certain questions against him of their own superstition, and of one Iesus which was dead. whom Paul affirmed to be alive.

Acts 25:20
Because I doubted of the questions, I asked him whither he would go to Ierusalem, and there be judged of these matters.

Acts 25:21
Then when Paul had appealed to be kept unto the knowledge of Cesar. I commanded him to be kept till I might send him to Cesar.

Acts 25:22
Agrippa said unto Festus: I would also hear the man myself. Tomorrow (said he) thou shalt hear him.

Acts 25:23
On the morrow when Agrippa was come and Bernice with great pomp, and were entered into the council house with the captains and chief men of the city, at Festus' commandment Paul was brought forth,

Acts 25:24
and Festus said: King Agrippa, and all men which are here present with us: Ye see this man about whom all the multitude of jewes have been with me, both at Ierusalem and also here, crying that he ought not to live any longer.

Acts 25:25
Yet found I nothing worthy of death that he had committed. Nevertheless seeing that he hath appealed to Cesar, I have determined to send him.

Acts 25:26
Of whom I have no certain thing to write unto my lord. Wherefore I have brought him unto you, and specially unto thee, king Agrippa, that after examination had, I might have somewhat to write.

Acts 25:27
For me thinketh it unreasonable for to send a prisoner, and not to shew the causes, which are laid against him.

Acts 26:1
Agrippa said unto Paul: Thou art permitted to speak for thyself. Then Paul stretched forth his hand, and answered for himself:

Acts 26:2
I think myself happy King Agrippa, because I shall answer this day before thee of all the things whereof I am accused of the jewes,

Acts 26:3
namely because thou art expert in all customs, and questions, which are among the jewes. Wherefore I beseech thee to hear me patiently.

Acts 26:4
My living of a child, which was at the first among mine own nation at Ierusalem know all the jewes

Acts 26:5
which knew me from the beginning, if they would testify it. For after the most straitest sect of our lay, lived I a pharisaye

Acts 26:6
and now I stand and am judged for the hope of the promise made of God unto our fathers

Acts 26:7
unto which promise, our xij. tribes instantly serving God day and night, hope to come. For which hope's sake, king Agrippa am I accused of the jewes.

Acts 26:8
Why should it be thought a thing incredible unto you, if God raise again the dead?

Acts 26:9
I also verily thought in myself, that I ought to do many contrary things, clean against the name of Iesus of Nazareth:

Acts 26:10
which things I also did in Ierusalem. And many of the saints shut I in prison, moreover I received authority of the high priests: And when they were put to death I gave the sentence.

Acts 26:11
And I punished them oft in every synagogue, and compelled them to blaspheme: and was yet more mad upon them, even unto strange cities.

Acts 26:12
About the which things as I went to Damascon with authority, and commission from the high priests,

Acts 26:13
even at mid day (king Agrippa) I saw in the way a light from heaven, above the brightness of the sun, shine round about me and them, which journeyed with me.

Acts 26:14
When we were all fallen to the earth, I heard a voice speaking unto me, and saying in the Hebrew tongue: Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou me? It is hard for thee to kick against the prick.

Acts 26:15
And I said: Who art thou Lord? And he said: I am Iesus whom thou persecutest:

Acts 26:16
But rise and stand up on thy feet. For I have appeared unto thee for this purpose, to make thee a minister, and a witness both of those things which thou hast seen, and of those things in thee which I will appear unto thee,

Acts 26:17
delivering thee from the people, and from the gentiles, unto thee which now I send thee,

Acts 26:18
to open their eyes that they might turn from darkness unto light, and from the power of Satan unto God, that they may receive forgiveness of sins, and inheritance among them which are sanctified by faith in me.

Acts 26:19
Wherefore king Agrippa, I was not disobedient unto the heavenly vision:

Acts 26:20
but shewed first unto them of Damascon, and at Ierusalem, and thorowout all the coasts of Jewry, and to the gentiles, that they should repent, and turn to God, and do the right works of repentance.

Acts 26:21
For this cause the jewes caught me in the temple, and went about to kill me.

Acts 26:22
Nevertheless I obtained help of God, and stood unto this day witnessing both to small and to great, saying none other things, than those which the prophets and Moses did say should come,

Acts 26:23
that Christ should suffer, and that he should be the first that should rise from death, and should shew light unto the people, and to the gentiles.

Acts 26:24
As he thus answered for himself: Festus said with a loud voice: Paul, thou art besides thyself. Much learning hath made thee mad.

Acts 26:25
And Paul said: I am not mad most dear Festus: but speak the words of truth and soberness.

Acts 26:26
The king knoweth of these things, before whom I speak freely: neither think I that any of these things are hidden from him. For this thing was not done in a corner.

Acts 26:27
King Agrippa believest thou the prophets? I wot well thou believest.

Acts 26:28
Agrippa said unto Paul: Somewhat thou bringest me in mind for to become christen.

Acts 26:29
And Paul said: I would to God that not only thou: but also all that hear me today, were not somewhat only, but altogether such as I am except these bonds.

Acts 26:30
And when he had thus spoken, the king rose up, and the debite, and Bernice, and they that sat with them.

Acts 26:31
And when they were gone apart, they talked between themselves saying: This man doth nothing worthy of death, nor of bonds.

Acts 26:32
Then said Agrippa unto Festus: This man might have been lowsed if he had not appealed unto Cesar.

Acts 27:1
When it was concluded that we should sail into Italy, they delivered Paul and certain other prisoners unto one named Iulius, an undercaptain of Cesar's soldiers.

Acts 27:2
And we entered into a ship of Adramicium, and lowsed from land, appointed to sail by the coasts of Asia, one Aristarcus out of Macedonia, of the country of Thessalia, being with us.

Acts 27:3
The next day came we to Sidon, and Iulius courteously entreated Paul, and gave him liberty to go unto his friends, and to refresh himself.

Acts 27:4
And from thence launched we and sailed hard by Cypers, because the winds were contrary.

Acts 27:5
Then sailed we over the sea of Cicill, and Pamphylia, and came to Myra a city in Lycia.

Acts 27:6
And there the undercaptain found a ship of Alexandry ready to sail into Italy, and put us therein,

Acts 27:7
and when we had sailed slowly many days, and scarce were come over against Gnydon (because the wind withstood us) we sailed hard by the coast of Candy, over against Salmo,

Acts 27:8
and with much work sailed beyond it, and came unto a place called Goode port. Nye whereunto was a city called Lasea.

Acts 27:9
When much time was spent and sailing was now jeopardous, because also that we had overlong fasted, Paul put them in remembrance,

Acts 27:10
and said unto them: Sirs I perceive that this voyage will be with hurt and damage, not of the lading and ship only: but also of our lives.

Acts 27:11
But the undercaptain believed the governor, and the master, better than those things which were spoken of Paul.

Acts 27:12
And because the haven was not commodious to winter in, many took counsel to depart thence, if by any means they might attain to Phenices and there to winter, which haven pertaineth to Candy, and serveth to the southwest, and northwest wind.

Acts 27:13
When the south wind blew, they supposing to obtain their purpose lowsed unto Asson, and sailed past all Candy.

Acts 27:14
But anon after there arose (against their purpose) a flaw of wind out of the northeast.

Acts 27:15
When the ship was caught, and could not resist the wind, we let her go and drave with the weather.

Acts 27:16
We came unto an isle named Clauda, And had much work to come by a boat,

Acts 27:17
which they took up, and used help undergirding the ship, fearing lest we should have fallen into Syrtes, and we let down a vessel and so were carried.

Acts 27:18
The next day when we were tossed with an exceeding tempest, they lightened the ship,

Acts 27:19
and the third day we cast out with our own hands the tackling of the ship.

Acts 27:20
When at the last neither sun nor star in many days appeared, And no small tempest lay upon us, all hope that we should be saved, was taken away.

Acts 27:21
Then after long abstinence Paul stood forth in the midst of them and said: Sirs ye should have heard me, and not have departed from Candy, neither to have brought unto us this harm and loss.

Acts 27:22
And now I exhort you to be of goad cheer, for there shall be no loss of any man's life among you: But of the ship only.

Acts 27:23
For there stood by me this night the angel of God whose I am, and whom I serve,

Acts 27:24
saying: fear not Paul, for thou must be brought before Cesar. And lo, God hath given unto thee all that are in the ship with thee,

Acts 27:25
wherefore sirs be of good cheer, for I believe God that so it shall be even as it was told me,

Acts 27:26
and we must be cast into a certain island.

Acts 27:27
But when the fourteenth night was come as we were carried in Adria, about midnight the shipmen deemed that there appeared some country unto them,

Acts 27:28
and they sounded, and found it xx. fathoms. they went a little further and sounded again, and found xv. fathoms.

Acts 27:29
Then fearing lest they should have fallen on some Rocke, they cast iiij. anchors out of the stern, and wished for the day.

Acts 27:30
As the shipmen were about to flee out of the ship, and had let down the boat into the sea, under a colour as though they would have cast anchors out of the foreship:

Acts 27:31
Paul said unto the undercaptain and the soldiers: except these abide in the ship ye cannot be safe.

Acts 27:32
Then the soldiers cut off the rope of the boat, and let it fall away.

Acts 27:33
And in the meantime, betwixt that and day, Paul besought them all to take meat, saying: this is the fourteenth day that ye have tarried and continued fasting receiving nothing at all,

Acts 27:34
wherefore I pray you to take meat: for this no doubt is for your health, for there shall not an hair fall from the head of any of you.

Acts 27:35
And when he had thus spoken he took bread and gave thanks to God in presence of them all, and brake it, and began to eat.

Acts 27:36
Then were they all of good cheer, and they also took meat.

Acts 27:37
We were all together in the ship, two hundred and three score and sixteen souls.

Acts 27:38
When they had eaten enough, they lightened the ship and cast out the wheat into the sea.

Acts 27:39
When it was day they knew not the land, but they spied a certain reach with a bank, into the which they were minded (if it were possible) to thrust in the ship.

Acts 27:40
And when they had taken up the anchors, they committed themselves unto the sea, and lowsed the rudder bonds and hoised up the main sail to the wind and drew to land,

Acts 27:41
but they fell into a place, which had the sea on both the sides, and thrust in the ship. And the fore part stuck fast, and moved not, but the hinderpart brake with the violence of the waves.

Acts 27:42
The Soldiers' counsel was to kill the prisoners lest any of them, when he had swum out should flee away:

Acts 27:43
but the undercaptain willing to save Paul kept them from their purpose, and commanded that they that could swim should cast themselves first in to the sea, and scape to land.

Acts 27:44
And the other he commanded to go, some on boards, and some on broken pieces of the ship. And so it came to pass, that they came all safe to land.

Acts 28:1
And when they were scaped they knew that the isle was called Mileta.

Acts 28:2
The people of the country shewed us no little kindness, for they kindled a fire and received us every one because of the present rain, and because of cold.

Acts 28:3
When Paul had gathered a bundle of sticks, And put them into the fire, a viper (because of the heat) crept out leapt on his hand.

Acts 28:4
When the men of the country saw the worm hang on his hand, they said among themselves: this man must needs be a murderer: Whom (though he have escaped the sea) yet vengeance suffereth not to live.

Acts 28:5
and he shook off the vermin into the fire, and felt no harm.

Acts 28:6
They waited when he should have swollen, or fallen down dead suddenly. But after they had looked a great while, and saw no harm come to him, they changed their minds, and said that he was a God.

Acts 28:7
In the same quarters, the chief man of the isle whose name was Publius, had a lordship: which received us, and lodged us three days courteously.

Acts 28:8
It fortuned that the father of Publius lay sick of a fever, and of a bloody flux to whom Paul entered in and prayed, and laid his hands on him and healed him.

Acts 28:9
When this was done, other also which had diseases in the isle, came and were healed:

Acts 28:10
And they did us great honour. And when we departed, they laded us with things necessary.

Acts 28:11
After three months we departed in a ship of Alexandry, which had wintered in the isle, whose badge was Castor and Pollux.

Acts 28:12
And when we came to Ciracusa, we tarried there iij. days,

Acts 28:13
from whence we sailed about and came to Regium. And after one day the south wind blew, and we came the next day to Putiolus

Acts 28:14
where we found brethren, and were desired to tarry with them seven days, and so came we to Rome.

Acts 28:15
and from thence, when the brethren heard of us, they came to Apiphorum, and three taverns, and met us. When Paul saw them he thanked God, and waxed bold.

Acts 28:16
When he came to Rome, the undercaptain delivered the prisoners to the chief captain of the host: but Paul was suffered to dwell alone with one Soldier that kept him.

Acts 28:17
It fortuned after three days Paul called the chief of the jewes to gether. When they were come, he said unto them: Men and brethren, though I have committed no thing against the people, or laws of our fathers: yet was I delivered prisoner from Ierusalem into the hands of the romans.

Acts 28:18
Which when they had examined me, would have let me go, because they found no cause of death in me:

Acts 28:19
but when the jewes cried contrary: I was constrained to appeal unto Cesar. Not because I had ought to accuse my people of.

Acts 28:20
For this cause have I called for you to see you, and to speak with you. For I because of the hope of Israhel, am bound with this chain.

Acts 28:21
And they said unto him: We neither received letters out of Jewry pertaining unto thee, neither came any of the brethren that shewed or spake any harm of thee.

Acts 28:22
But we will hear of thee what thou thinkest. For we have heard of this sect, that everywhere it is spoken against.

Acts 28:23
When they had appointed him a day, there came many unto him into his lodging: to whom he expounded and testified the kingdom of God. and preached unto them of Iesu: both by the law of Moses, and also out by the prophets from morning to night.

Acts 28:24
And some believed the things which were spoken, and some believed not.

Acts 28:25
When they agreed not among themselves, they departed, after that Paul had spoken one word: well spake the holy ghost by Esay the prophet unto our fathers,

Acts 28:26
saying: Go unto this people and say: with your ears shall ye hear, and shall not understand: and with your eyes shall ye see and shall not perceive.

Acts 28:27
For the heart of this people is waxed gross, and their ears wexe thick of hearing, and their eyes have they closed, lest they should see with their eyes, and hear with their ears, and understand with their hearts, and should be converted, and I should heal them.

Acts 28:28
Be it known therefore unto you, that this consolation of God is sent to the gentiles, and they shall hear it.

Acts 28:29
And when he had said that, the jewes departed from him, and had great despicions among themselves.

Acts 28:30
But Paul dwelt two years in his lodging. And received all that came to him,

Acts 28:31
preaching the kingdom of God, and teaching those things which concerned the Lord Iesus with all confidence, no man forbidding him. <Here endeth the Actes off the Apostles.>

Rom 1:1
Paul the servant of Iesus Christ, called unto the office of an apostle, put apart to preach the Gospell of God,

Rom 1:2
which he promised afore by his prophets, in the holy scriptures

Rom 1:3
that make mention of his son, the which was begotten of the seed of David, as pertaining to the flesh:

Rom 1:4
and declared to be the son of God with power of the holy ghost, that sanctifieth, since the time that Iesus Christ our Lord rose again from death,

Rom 1:5
by whom we have received grace and apostleship, that all gentiles should obey to the faith which is in his name,

Rom 1:6
of the which number are ye also, which are Iesus Christe's by vocation.

Rom 1:7
To all you of Rome beloved of God, and saints by calling. Grace be with you and peace from God our father, and from the Lord Iesus Christ.

Rom 1:8
First verily I thank my God thorow Iesus Christ for you all, because your faith is published throughout all the worlde.

Rom 1:9
For God is my witness, whom I serve with my spirit, in the gospell of his son that without ceasing I make mention of you always in my prayers,

Rom 1:10
beseeching that at one time or another, a prosperous journey (by the will of God) might fortune me to come unto you.

Rom 1:11
For I long to see you, that I might bestow among you some spiritual gift, to strengthen you withall

Rom 1:12
(that is) that I might have consolation together with you, through the common faith, which both ye and I have.

Rom 1:13
I would that ye should know, brethren, how that I have oftentimes purposed to come unto you (but have been let hitherto) to have some fruit among you, as I have among other of the gentiles.

Rom 1:14
For I am debtor both to the greeks, and to them which are no greeks, unto the learned and also unto the unlearned.

Rom 1:15
Likewise, as much as in me is, I am ready to preach the Gospell to you of Rome also.

Rom 1:16
For I am not ashamed of the Gospell of Christ, because it is the power of God unto salvation to all that believe, namely to the iewe, and also to the gentile.

Rom 1:17
For by it the righteousness which cometh of God is opened, from faith to faith. As it is written: The just shall live by faith.

Rom 1:18
For the wrath of God of heaven appeareth against all ungodliness and unrighteousness of men which withhold the truth in unrighteousness,

Rom 1:19
seeing that that, which may be known of God, is manifest among them. For God did shew it unto them.

Rom 1:20
For his invisible things (that is to say, his eternal power and godhead) are understood and seen, by the works from the creation of the world. So that they are without excuse,

Rom 1:21
in as much as when they knew God, they glorified him not as God, neither were thankful, but waxed full of vanities in their imaginations. And their foolish hearts were blinded.

Rom 1:22
When they counted themselves wise, they became fools

Rom 1:23
and turned the glory of the immortal God, unto the similitude of the image of mortal man, and of birds, and four footed beasts and serpents.

Rom 1:24
For this cause God gave them up unto their hearts' lusts, unto uncleanness to defile their own bodies between themselves:

Rom 1:25
which turned his truth unto a lie, and worshipped and served the creatures more then the maker, which is blessed forever Amen.

Rom 1:26
For this cause God gave them up unto shameful lusts. For even their women did change the natural use unto the unnatural.

Rom 1:27
And likewise also the men left the natural use of the woman, and brent in lust one on another among themselves. And man with man wrought filthiness, and received in themselves the reward of their error as it was according.

Rom 1:28
And as it seemed not good unto them to be aknown of God, even so God delivered them up unto a leawde mind, that they should do those things which were not comely,

Rom 1:29
being full of all unrighteous doing, of fornication, wickedness, covetousness, maliciousness, full of envy, murder, debate, deceit, evil conditioned whisperers,

Rom 1:30
backbiters, haters of God, doers of wrong, proude, boasters, bringers up of evil things, disobedient to fathers and mothers,

Rom 1:31
without understanding, covenant breakers, unloving, stubborn and merciless.

Rom 1:32
Which men, though they knew the righteousness of God, how that they which such things commit are worthy of death, yet not only do the same, but also had pleasure in them that did them.

Rom 2:1
Therefore art thou inexcusable o man whosoever thou be that judgest. For in the same wherein thou judgest another, thou condemnest thyself. For thou that judgest doest even the same self things.

Rom 2:2
But we are sure that the judgement of God is according to truth, against them which commit such things.

Rom 2:3
Thinkest thou O thou man that judgest them which do such things and yet doest even the very same, that thou shalt escape the judgement of God?

Rom 2:4
Other despisest thou the riches of his goodness and patience, and long sufferance? and rememberest not how that the kindness of God leadeth thee to repentance?

Rom 2:5
But thou after thine hard heart that cannot repent, heapest thee together the treasure of wrath against the day of vengeance, when shall be opened the righteous judgement of God,

Rom 2:6
which will reward every man according to his deeds,

Rom 2:7
that is to say praise, honour, and immortality, to them which continue in good doing, and seek eternal life:

Rom 2:8
But unto them that are rebellious, and disobey the truth, yet follow iniquity, shall come indignation, and wrath,

Rom 2:9
tribulation and anguish upon the soul of every man that doth evil. Of the iewe first And also of the gentile.

Rom 2:10
To every man that doth good shall come praise, honour and peace, to the iewe first, and also to the gentile.

Rom 2:11
For there is no partiality with God:

Rom 2:12
But whosoever hath sinned without law, shall perish without law. And as many as have sinned under the law, shall be judged by the law.

Rom 2:13
For before God they are not righteous which hear the law: but they which do the law shall be justified.

Rom 2:14
For if the gentiles which have no law, do of nature the things contained in the law: then they having no law, are a law unto themselves,

Rom 2:15
which shew the deed of the law written in their hearts: While their conscience beareth witness unto them, and also their thoughts, accusing one another, or excusing

Rom 2:16
at the day when God shall judge the secrets of men, by Iesus Christ according to my Gospell.

Rom 2:17
Behold, thou art called a Jewe, and trustest in the law and rejoicest in God,

Rom 2:18
and knowest his will, and hast experience of good and bad, in that thou art informed by the law:

Rom 2:19
And believest that thou thyself art a guide unto the blind, a light to them which are in darkness,

Rom 2:20
an informer of them which lack discretion, a teacher of the unlearned, which hast the ensample of that which ought to be known, and of the truth in the law.

Rom 2:21
Now teachest thou another: but teachest not thyself. Thou preachest, a man should not steal: and yet thou stealest.

Rom 2:22
Thou sayest, a man should not commit advoutry and thou breakest wedlock.

Rom 2:23
Thou abhorrest images, and robbest God of his honour. Thou rejoicest in the law, and thorow breaking the law dishonourest God.

Rom 2:24
For the name of God is evil spoken of among the gentiles thorow you as it is written.

Rom 2:25
Circumcision verily availeth if thou keep the law: But if thou break the law thy circumcision is made uncircumcision.

Rom 2:26
Therefore if the uncircumcised keep the right things contained in the law: shall not his uncircumcision be counted for circumcision?

Rom 2:27
And shall not uncircumcision which is by nature (if it keep the law) judge thee, which being under the letter and circumcision, dost transgress the law?

Rom 2:28
For he is not a Jewe, which is a Jewe outward. Neither is that thing circumcision, which is outward in the flesh:

Rom 2:29
But he is a Jewe which is hid within, and the circumcision of the heart is the true circumcision, which is in the spirit, and not in the letter: whose praise is not of men but of God.

Rom 3:1
What preferment than hath the Jewe? other what advantageth circumcision?

Rom 3:2
Surely very much. First unto them was committed the word of God.

Rom 3:3
What then though some of them did not believe? shall their unbelief make the promise of God without effect?

Rom 3:4
God forbid. Let God be true, and all men liars, as it is written: That thou mightest be justified in thy sayings and shouldest overcome when thou art judged.

Rom 3:5
If our unrighteousness make the righteousness of God more excellent: what shall we say? Is God unrighteous which taketh vengeance? (I speak after the manner of men.)

Rom 3:6
God forbid. For how then shall God judge the world?

Rom 3:7
if the verity of God appear more excellent thorow my lie, unto his praise, why am I hence forth judged as a sinner?

Rom 3:8
and say not rather (as men evil speak of us, and as some affirm that we say) let us do evil, that good may come thereof. Whose damnation is just.

Rom 3:9
What say we then? Are we better than they? no, in no wise. For we have all ready proved how that both Jewes and gentiles are all under sin,

Rom 3:10
as it is written: There is none righteous, no not one:

Rom 3:11
There is none that understandeth, there is none that seeketh after God,

Rom 3:12
they are all gone out of the way, they are all made unprofitable, there is none that doeth good, no not one.

Rom 3:13
Their throat is an open sepulchre, with their tongues they have deceived: the poison of Aspes is under their lips.

Rom 3:14
whose mouths are full of cursing and bitterness.

Rom 3:15
Their feet are swift to shed blood.

Rom 3:16
Destruction and wretchedness are in their ways:

Rom 3:17
And the way of peace have they not known.

Rom 3:18
There is no fear of God before their eyes.

Rom 3:19
Yea and we know that whatsoever the law saith, he saith it to them which are under the law: That all mouths may be stopped, and all the world be subdued to God,

Rom 3:20
because that by the deeds of the law, shall no flesh be justified in the sight of God. For by the law cometh the knowledge of sin.

Rom 3:21
Now verily is the righteousness that cometh of God declared with out the fulfilling of the law having witness yet of the law, and of the prophets.

Rom 3:22
The righteousness no doubt which is good before God cometh by the faith of Iesus Christ unto all, and upon all them that believe.

Rom 3:23
For there is no difference, all have sinned, and lack the praise that is of valour before God:

Rom 3:24
but are justified freely by his grace, through the redemption that is in Christ Iesu,

Rom 3:25
whom God hath made a seat of mercy thorow faith in his blood, to shew the righteousness which before him is of valour, in that he forgiveth the sins that are passed,

Rom 3:26
which God did suffer to shew at this time: the righteousness that is allowed of him, that he might be counted just, and a justifier of him which believeth on Iesus.

Rom 3:27
Where is then thy rejoicing? It is excluded. By what law? by the law of workes? Nay: but by the law of faith.

Rom 3:28
We suppose therefore that a man is justified by faith without the deeds of the law.

Rom 3:29
Is he the God of the jewes only? Is he not also the God of the gentiles? He is no doubt, God also of the gentiles.

Rom 3:30
For it is God only which justifieth circumcision, which is of faith: and uncircumcision throwe faith.

Rom 3:31
Do we then destroy the law throwe faith? God forbid. We rather maintain the law.

Rom 4:1
What shall we say then, that Abraham our father as pertaining to the flesh did find?

Rom 4:2
If Abraham were justified by deeds, then hath he wherein to rejoice: but not with God.

Rom 4:3
For what saith the scripture? Abraham believed God, and it was counted unto him for righteousness.

Rom 4:4
To him that worketh is the reward not reckoned of favour: but of duty.

Rom 4:5
To him that worketh not, but believeth on him that justifieth the ungodly, is faith counted for righteousness.

Rom 4:6
Even as David describeth the blessedfulness of a man, unto whom good ascribeth righteousness without deeds:

Rom 4:7
Blessed are they, whose unrighteousnesses is forgiven, and whose sins are covered.

Rom 4:8
Blessed is that man to whom the Lord imputeth not sin.

Rom 4:9
Came this blessedness then upon the circumcised or upon the uncircumcised? We say verily how that faith was reckoned to Abraham, for righteousness.

Rom 4:10
How was it reckoned? in the time of circumcision? or in the time before he was circumcised? Not in time of circumcision: but when he was yet uncircumcised.

Rom 4:11
And he received the sign of circumcision, as a seal of the righteousness which is by faith, which faith he had yet being uncircumcised, that he should be the father of all them that believe, though they be not circumcised, that righteousness might be imputed to them also,

Rom 4:12
And that he might be the father of the circumcised: not because they are circumcised only: but because they walk also in the steps of that faith, which was in our father Abraham before the time of circumcision.

Rom 4:13
For the promise that he should be heir of the world was not given to Abraham, or to his seed thorow the law: but thorow the righteousness which cometh of faith.

Rom 4:14
For if they which are of the law be heirs, then is faith but vain, and the promise of none effect.

Rom 4:15
Because the law causeth wrath. For where no law is, there is no transgression.

Rom 4:16
Therefore by faith is the inheritance given, that it might come of favour: and that the promise might be sure to all the seed. Not to them only which are of the law: but also to them which are of the faith of Abraham, which is the father of us all.

Rom 4:17
As it is written: I have ordained thee a father to many nations, before God whom thou hast believed, which quickeneth the dead and calleth those things which be not as though they were.

Rom 4:18
Which Abraham, contrary to hope, believed in hope, that he should be the father of many nations, according to that which was spoken: So shall thy seed be.

Rom 4:19
And he fainted not in the faith, nor yet considered his own body, which was now dead, even when he was almost an hundred year old. Neither considered he the barrenness of Sara.

Rom 4:20
He staggered not at the promise of God thorow unbelief: But was made strong in the faith, and gave honour to God and steadfastly believed,

Rom 4:21
that he which had made the promised was able also to make it good.

Rom 4:22
And therefore was it reckoned to him for righteousness.

Rom 4:23
It is not written for him only, that it was reckoned to him for righteousness:

Rom 4:24
but also for us, to whom it shall be counted for righteousness so we believe on him that raised, up Iesus our Lord from death.

Rom 4:25
Which was delivered for our sins, and rose again for to justify us.

Rom 5:1
Because therefore that we are justified by faith we are at peace with God thorow our Lord Iesus Christ:

Rom 5:2
by whom we have a way in thorow faith unto this faveour wherein we stand and rejoice in hope of the praise that shall be given of God.

Rom 5:3
Neither do we so only: but also we rejoice in tribulation: For we know that tribulation bringeth patience,

Rom 5:4
patience bringeth fealynge, fealynge bringeth hope.

Rom 5:5
and hope maketh not ashamed, because the love that God hath unto us, is shed abroad in our hearts, by the holy ghost, which is given unto us.

Rom 5:6
For when we were yet weak according to the time: Christ died for us which were ungodly.

Rom 5:7
Yet scarce will any man die for a righteous man. Peradventure for a good man durst a man die.

Rom 5:8
But God setteth out his love that he hath to us, Seeing that while we were yet sinners, Christ died for us.

Rom 5:9
Much more then now (seeing we are justified in his blood) shall we be preserved from wrath thorow him.

Rom 5:10
For if when we were enemies, we were reconciled to God by the death of his son: much more, seeing we are reconciled, we shall be preserved by his life.

Rom 5:11
Not only so, but we also joy in God by the means of our Lord Iesus Christ, by whom we have received this atonement.

Rom 5:12
Wherefore as by one man sin entered into the worlde, and death by the means of sin. And so death went over all men, insomuch that all men sinned.

Rom 5:13
For even unto the time of the law was sin in the worlde: but sin was not regarded, as long as there was no law:

Rom 5:14
nevertheless death reigned from Adam to Moses, even over them also that sinned not, with like transgression as did Adam: which is the similitude of him that was to come.

Rom 5:15
But the gift is not like as the sin. For if thorow the sin of one, many be dead: much more plenteous upon many was the faveour of God and gift by faveour: which faveour was given by one man Iesus Christ.

Rom 5:16
And the gift is not over one sin, as death came thorow one sin of one that sinned. For damnation came of one sin unto condemnation: But the gift came to justify from many sins.

Rom 5:17
For if by the sin of one, death reigned by the means of one, much more shall they which receive abundance of faveour and of the gift of righteousness reign in life by the means of one (that is to say) Iesus Christe.

Rom 5:18
Likewise then as by the sin of one, condemnation came on all men: even so by the justifying of one cometh the righteousness that bringeth life, upon all men.

Rom 5:19
For as by one man's disobedience many became sinners: so by the obedience of one shall many be made righteous.

Rom 5:20
The law in the mean time entered in that sin should increase. And where abundance of sin was, there was more plenteousness of grace.

Rom 5:21
That as sin had reigned unto death, even so might grace reign thorow righteousness unto eternal life, by the help of Iesu Christ.

Rom 6:1
What shall we say then? shall we continue in sin, that there may be abundance of grace?

Rom 6:2
God forbid. How shall we that are dead as touching sin live any longer therein?

Rom 6:3
Remember ye not that all we which are baptised in the name of Christ Iesu, are baptised to die with him?

Rom 6:4
We are buried with him by baptism for to die: That as Christ was raised up from death by the glory of the father: even so we also should walk in a new life.

Rom 6:5
For if we be graft in death like unto him: even so must we be in the resurrection.

Rom 6:6
This we must remember, that our old man is crucified with him also, that the body of sin might utterly be destroyed, that henceforth we should not be servants of sin.

Rom 6:7
For he that is dead, is justified from sin.

Rom 6:8
Wherefore if we be dead with Christ, we believe that we shall live with him:

Rom 6:9
remembering that Christ once raised from death, dieth no more. Death hath no more power over him.

Rom 6:10
For as touching that he died, he died as concerning sin once. And as touching that he liveth, he liveth unto God.

Rom 6:11
Likewise imagine ye also, that ye are dead concerning sin: but are alive unto God thorow Iesus Christ our Lord.

Rom 6:12
Let not sin reign therefore in your mortal bodies, that ye should thereunto obey in the lusts of it.

Rom 6:13
Neither give ye your members as instruments of unrighteousness unto sin: But give yourselves unto God, as they that are alive from death. And give your members as instruments of righteousness unto God.

Rom 6:14
Sin shall not have power over you. For ye are not under the law, but under grace.

Rom 6:15
