What is it then? I will pray with my spirit, and will pray with my mind also. I will sing with my spirit, and will sing with my mind also.

1Cor 14:16
For else when thou blessest with the spirit, how shall he that occupieth the room of the unlearned say amen at thy giving of thanks? seeing he understandeth not what thou sayest?

1Cor 14:17
Thou verily givest thanks well: but the other is not edified.

1Cor 14:18
I thank my god, I speak with tongues more then ye all.

1Cor 14:19
Yet had I lever in the congregation to speak five words with my mind to the information of other, rather than ten thousand words with the tongue.

1Cor 14:20
Brethren, be not children in wit: as concerning maliciousness be children: but in wit be perfect.

1Cor 14:21
In the law it is written, with other tongues, and with other lips will I speak unto this people, and yet for all that will they not hear me saith the Lord.

1Cor 14:22
Wherefore tongues are for a sign, not to them that believe: but to them that believe not. Contrariwise prophesying serveth not for them that believe not: but for them which believe.

1Cor 14:23
If therefore when all the congregation is come together, and all speak with tongues, there come in they that are unlearned, or they which believe not: will they not say that ye are out of your wits?

1Cor 14:24
But and if all prophesy, and there come in one that believeth not, or one unlearned, he is reproved of all men, and is judged of every man:

1Cor 14:25
and so are the secrets of his heart opened: and then falleth he down on his face, and worshippeth god, and saith that god is with you indeed.

1Cor 14:26
How is it then brethren? when ye come together every man hath his song, hath his doctrine, hath his tongue, hath his revelation, hath his interpretation: Let all things be unto edifying.

1Cor 14:27
If any man speak with tongues, let it be two at once: or at the most three at once: and that by course, and let another interpret it:

1Cor 14:28
But if there be no interpreter, let him keep silence in the congregation, and let him speak to himself, and to god.

1Cor 14:29
Let the prophets speak two at once, or three at once, and let other judge.

1Cor 14:30
If any revelation be made to another that sitteth by, let the first hold his peace.

1Cor 14:31
For ye may all prophesy one by one, that all may learn, and all may have comfort.

1Cor 14:32
For the spirits of the prophets are in the power of the prophets.

1Cor 14:33
For god is not causer of strife: but of peace, as he is in all other congregations of the saints.

1Cor 14:34
Let your wives keep silence in the congregations. For it is not permitted unto them to speak: but let them be under obedience, as saith the law:

1Cor 14:35
if they will learn any thing, let them ask their husbands at home. For it is a shame for women to speak in the congregation.

1Cor 14:36
Spronge the word of God from you? other came it unto you only?

1Cor 14:37
If any man think himself a prophet either spiritual: let him understand, what things I write unto you. For they are the commandments of the Lord.

1Cor 14:38
But and if any man be ignorant, let him be ignorant.

1Cor 14:39
Wherefore brethren covet to prophesy, and forbid not to speak with tongues.

1Cor 14:40
Let all things be done honestly and in order.

1Cor 15:1
Brethren as pertaining to the gospell which I preached unto you, which ye have also accepted, and in the which ye continue:

1Cor 15:2
by the which also ye are saved, I do you to wit after what manner I preached unto you, if ye keep it, except ye have believed in vain.

1Cor 15:3
For first of all I delivered unto you that which I received: how that Christ died for our sins, agreeing to the scriptures:

1Cor 15:4
and that he was buried, and that he arose again the third day according to the scriptures:

1Cor 15:5
and that he was seen of Cephas, then of the twelve,

1Cor 15:6
After that he was seen of more than five hundred brethren at once: of which many remain unto this day, and many are fallen asleep.

1Cor 15:7
After that appeared he to Iames, then to all the apostles.

1Cor 15:8
And last of all he was seen of me, as of one that was born out of due time.

1Cor 15:9
For I am the least of all the apostles, which am not worthy to be called an apostle, because I persecuted the congregation of God:

1Cor 15:10
But by the faveour of God I am that I am. And his faveour which is in me was not in vain: but I laboured more abundantly than they all, not I, but the faveour of God which is with me.

1Cor 15:11
Whether it were I or they, so have we preach, and so have ye believed.

1Cor 15:12
If Christ be preached how that he rose from death: how say some that are among you, that there is no resurrection of the dead?

1Cor 15:13
If there be no rising again of death: then is Christ not risen.

1Cor 15:14
If Christ be not risen, then is our preaching vain, and your faith is also in vain.

1Cor 15:15
Yea, and we are found false witnesses of God. For we have testified against god how that he raised up Christ, whom he raised not up, if it be so that the dead rise not up again.

1Cor 15:16
For if the dead rise not again, then is Christ not risen again.

1Cor 15:17
If it be so that Christ rose not, then is your faith in vain, and yet are ye in your sins.

1Cor 15:18
And they which are fallen asleep in Christ, are perished.

1Cor 15:19
If in this life only we believe on Christ, then are we of all men the miserablest.

1Cor 15:20
Now is Christ risen from death, and is become the first fruits of them that slept.

1Cor 15:21
For by a man came death, and by a man came resurrection of death.

1Cor 15:22
For as by Adam all die: even so by Christ, shall all be made alive,

1Cor 15:23
and every man in his own order: The first is Christ, then they that are Christis at his coming.

1Cor 15:24
Then cometh the end, when he hath delivered up the kingdom to God the father, when he hath put down all rule, authority, and power.

1Cor 15:25
For he must rule till he have put all his enemies under his feet.

1Cor 15:26
The last enemy that shall be destroyed is death.

1Cor 15:27
For he hath put all things under his feet. But when he saith, all things are put under him, it is manifest, that he is excepted, which did put all things under him.

1Cor 15:28
When all things are subdued unto him: then shall the son also himself be subject unto him that put all things under him, that God may be all in all things.

1Cor 15:29
Other else what do they which are baptised over the dead, if the dead rise not at all? why are they baptised over the dead?

1Cor 15:30
And why stand we in jeopardy every hour?

1Cor 15:31
by our rejoicing which I have in Christ Iesu our Lord, I die daily.

1Cor 15:32
That I have fought with beasts at Ephesus after the manner of men, what advantageth it me, if the dead rise not again? Let us eat and drink, tomorrow we shall die.

1Cor 15:33
Be not deceived: malicious speakings corrupt good manners.

1Cor 15:34
Awake truly out of sleep, and sin not. For some have not the knowledge of God. I speak this unto your rebuke.

1Cor 15:35
But some man will say: how shall the dead arise? with what body shall they come?

1Cor 15:36
Thou fool, that which thou sowest, is not quickened except it die.

1Cor 15:37
And what sowest thou? Thou sowest not that body that shall be: but bare corn (I mean either of wheat, or of some other)

1Cor 15:38
and God giveth it a body at his pleasure, to every seed a several body.

1Cor 15:39
All flesh is not one manner of flesh: but there is one manner flesh of men, another manner flesh of beasts, another manner flesh of fishes, and another of birds.

1Cor 15:40
There are celestial bodies, and there are bodies terrestrial: But the glory of the celestial is one, and the glory of the terrestrial is another.

1Cor 15:41
There is one manner glory of the sun, and another glory of the moon, an another glory of the stars. For one star differeth from another in glory.

1Cor 15:42
So is the resurrection of the dead. It is sown in corruption, and riseth in incorruption.

1Cor 15:43
It is sown in dishonour, and riseth in honour. It is sown in weakness, and riseth in power.

1Cor 15:44
It is sown a natural body, and riseth a spiritual body. There is a natural body and there is a spiritual body.

1Cor 15:45
as it is written: The first man Adam was made a living soul: and the last Adam was made a quickening spirit:

1Cor 15:46
but that is not first which is spiritual: but that which is natural, and then that which is spiritual.

1Cor 15:47
The first man is of the earth, earthy: The second man is from heaven, heavenly.

1Cor 15:48
As is the earthy, such are they that are earthy: And as is the heavenly, such are they that are heavenly.

1Cor 15:49
And as we have born the image of the earthy, so shall we bear the image of the heavenly.

1Cor 15:50
This say I brethren, that flesh and blood cannot inherit the kingdom of god. Neither doth corruption inherit uncorruption.

1Cor 15:51
Behold I shew a mystery unto you: we shall not all sleep: but we shall all be changed,

1Cor 15:52
and that in a moment, and in the twinkling of an eye, at the sound of the last trumpet. For the trumpet shall blow, and the dead shall rise incorruptible: And we shall be changed.

1Cor 15:53
For this corruptible must put on incorruptibility: and this mortal must put on immortality.

1Cor 15:54
When this corruptible hath put on incorruptibility: and this mortal hath put on immortality: then shall be brought to pass the saying that is written: Death is consumed into victory.

1Cor 15:55
Death where is thy sting? Hell where is thy victory?

1Cor 15:56
The sting of death is sin. The strength of sin is the law:

1Cor 15:57
But thanks be unto God, which hath given us victory thorow our Lord Iesus Christ.

1Cor 15:58
Therefore my dear brethren, be ye steadfast and unmoveable, always rich in the works of the Lord, forasmuch as ye know how that your labour is not in vain in the Lord.

1Cor 16:1
Of the gathering for the saints, as I have ordained in the congregations of Galacia, even so do ye.

1Cor 16:2
In some saboth day let every one of you put aside at home, and lay up whatsoever he thinketh meet, that there be no gatherings when I come.

1Cor 16:3
When I am come, whosoever ye shall allow by your letters, them will I send to bring your liberality unto Ierusalem.

1Cor 16:4
And if it be meet that I go, they shall go with me.

1Cor 16:5
I will come unto you after I have gone over Macedonia. For I will go thorowout Macedonia.

1Cor 16:6
With you peradventure I will abide a while: or else winter, that ye may bring me on my way whithersoever I go.

1Cor 16:7
I will not see you now in my passage: but I trust to abide a while with you, if god shall suffer me.

1Cor 16:8
I will tarry at Ephesus until witsontide:

1Cor 16:9
For a great door and a fruitful is opened unto me: and there are many adversaries.

1Cor 16:10
If Timotheus come, see that he be without fear with you. For he worketh the work of the Lord as I do.

1Cor 16:11
Let no man despise him: but convey him forth in peace, that he may come unto me. For I look for him with the brethren.

1Cor 16:12
To speak of brother Apollo: I greatly desired him to come unto you with the brethren, but his mind was not at all to come at this time. He will come when he shall have convenient time.

1Cor 16:13
Watch ye, stand fast in the faith, quit you like men, and be strong.

1Cor 16:14
Let all your business be done in love.

1Cor 16:15
Brethren (ye know the house of Stephana how that they are the first fruits of Achaia, and that they have appointed themselves to minister unto the saints:)

1Cor 16:16
I beseech you that ye be obedient unto such, and to all that help and labour.

1Cor 16:17
I am glad of the coming of Stephana, Fortunatus, and Achaicus: for that which was lacking on your part they have supplied.

1Cor 16:18
They have comforted my spirit and yours. Look therefore that ye know them that are such.

1Cor 16:19
The congregations of Asia salute you. Aquila and Priscilla salute you much in the Lord, and so doeth the congregation that is in their house.

1Cor 16:20
All the brethren greet you. Greet ye one another with an holy kiss.

1Cor 16:21
The salutation of me Paul with mine own hand:

1Cor 16:22
If any man love not the Lord Iesus Christ, the same be anathema maranatha.

1Cor 16:23
The faveour of the Lord Iesus Christ be with you all.

1Cor 16:24
My love be with you all in Christ Iesu, Amen. <The pistle unto the Corrinthyans sent from Philippos, By Stephana, and Fortunatus, and Acaichus, and Timotheus.>

2Cor 1:1
Paul an apostle of Iesus Christ by the will of God, and brother Timotheus. Unto the congregation of God, which is at Corinthum, with all the saints which are in all Achaia:

2Cor 1:2
Grace be with you and peace from God our father, and from the Lord Iesus Christ.

2Cor 1:3
Blessed be God the father of our Lord Iesus the Christ, father of mercy, and the God of all comfort,

2Cor 1:4
which comforteth us in all our tribulation, insomuch that we are able to comfort them which are troubled, in whatsoever tribulation it be, with the same comfort wherewith we our selves are comforted of God.

2Cor 1:5
For as the afflictions of Christ are plenteous in us: even so is our consolation plenteous by Christ.

2Cor 1:6
Whether we be troubled for your consolation, and health, which health sheweth her power in that ye suffer the same afflictions which we also suffer: or whether we be comforted for your consolation and health:

2Cor 1:7
yet our hope is steadfast for you inasmuch as we know how that as ye have your part in afflictions, so shall ye be part takers of consolation.

2Cor 1:8
Brethren I would not have you ignorant of our trouble, which happened unto us in Asia. For we were grieved out of measure passing strength, so greatly that we despaired even of life.

2Cor 1:9
Also we received an answer of death in ourselves, and that was done because we should not put our trust in ourselves: but in God, which raiseth the dead to life again:

2Cor 1:10
Which delivered us from so great a death, and doth deliver, on whom we trust, that yet hereafter he will deliver us,

2Cor 1:11
by the help of your prayer for us: That by the means of many occasions, thanks may be given of many on our behalf, For the grace given unto us.

2Cor 1:12
Our rejoicing is this, the testimony of our conscience, that we with out doubleness, but with godly pureness: not in fleshly wisdom, but by the grace of God, have had our conversation in the world, and most of all to youwards.

2Cor 1:13
We write no other things unto you, than that ye read and also know. Yea and I trust ye shall find us unto the end

2Cor 1:14
even as ye have found us partly, for we are your rejoicing, even as ye are ours in the day of the Lord Iesus.

2Cor 1:15
And in this confidence was I minded the other time to have come unto you (that ye might have had a double pleasure,)

2Cor 1:16
and to have passed by you into Macedonia, and to have come again out of Macedonia unto you, and to have been led forth to Jewryward of you.

2Cor 1:17
When I thuswise was minded: Did I use lightness? Or think I carnally those things which I think? that with me should be yea yea, and nay nay.

2Cor 1:18
God is faithful: For our preaching unto you, was not yea and nay.

2Cor 1:19
For Goddis son Iesus Christ which was preached among you by us (that is to say by me and Silvanus and Thimotheus) was not yea and nay: but in him it was Yea:

2Cor 1:20
For all the promises of God, in him are Yea: and are in him Amen, unto the laud of God thorow us.

2Cor 1:21
It is God which stablisheth us and you in Christ, and hath anointed us,

2Cor 1:22
which hath also sealed us, and hath given the earnest of the spirit into our hearts.

2Cor 1:23
I call God for a record unto my soul, that for to favor you with all, I came not any more unto Corinthum.

2Cor 1:24
Not that we be lords over your faith: but helpers of your joy. For by faith ye stand.

2Cor 2:1
But I determined this in myself, that I would not come again to you in heaviness.

2Cor 2:2
For if I make you sorry: who is it that should make me glad, but the same which is made sorry by me?

2Cor 2:3
And I wrote this same pistel unto you, lest if I came, I should take heaviness of them, of whom I ought to rejoice. Certainly this confidence have I in you all, that my joy is the joy of you all.

2Cor 2:4
For in great affliction and anguish of heart I wrote unto you with many tears: not to make you sorry, but that ye might perceive the love which I have most specially unto you.

2Cor 2:5
If any man hath caused sorrow, the same hath not made me sorry: but partly, lest I should grieve you all.

2Cor 2:6
It is sufficient unto the same man that he was rebuked of many.

2Cor 2:7
So that now contrarywise ye ought to forgive him and comfort him: lest that same should be swallowed up with overmuch heaviness.

2Cor 2:8
Wherefore I exhort you, that love may have strength over him.

2Cor 2:9
For this cause verily did I write, that I might know the proof of you, whether ye should be obedient in all things.

2Cor 2:10
To whom ye forgive any thing, I forgive also. And verily if I forgive any thing, to whom I forgave it for your sakes forgave I it, in the room of Christ,

2Cor 2:11
lest Satan should prevent us. For his thoughts are not unknown unto us.

2Cor 2:12
When I was come to Troada for Christe's gospel's sake (and a great door was opened unto me of the Lord)

2Cor 2:13
I had no rest in my spirit, because I found not Titus my brother: but took my leave of them and went away into Macedonia.

2Cor 2:14
Thanks be unto God which always giveth us the victory in Christ, and openeth the savor of his knowledge by us in every place.

2Cor 2:15
For we are unto God the sweet savor of Christ, both among them that are saved, and also among them which perish:

2Cor 2:16
to the one part are we the savor of death unto death: unto the other part are we the savor of life unto life. And who is meet unto these things?

2Cor 2:17
For we are not as many are which chop and change with the word of God: but as they which speak of pureness, and as they which speak off God in the sight of God, so speak we in Christ.

2Cor 3:1
We begin to praise ourselves again. Need we as some other of pistels of recommendation unto you? or letters of recommendation from you?

2Cor 3:2
Ye are our pistel written in our hearts, which is understood and read of all men,

2Cor 3:3
in that ye are known, how that ye are the pistel of Christ, ministered by us and written, not with ink: but with the spirit of the living God, not in tables of stone, but in fleshly tables of the heart.

2Cor 3:4
Such trust have we thorow Christ to Godward,

2Cor 3:5
not that we are sufficient of ourselves to think any thing as it were of ourselves: but our ableness cometh of God,

2Cor 3:6
which hath made us able to minister the new testament, not of the letter, but of the spirit: For the letter killeth, but the spirit giveth life.

2Cor 3:7
If the ministration of death thorow the letters figured in stones was glorious, so that the children of Israel could not behold the face of Moses for the glory of countenance (which glory nevertheless is done away)

2Cor 3:8
why shall not the ministration of the spirit be much more glorious?

2Cor 3:9
For if the ministering of condemnation be glorious: much more doth the administration of righteousness exceed in glory.

2Cor 3:10
For no doubt that which was there glorified is not once glorified in respect of this exceeding glory.

2Cor 3:11
Then if that which is destroyed was glorious, much more shall that which remaineth be glorious.

2Cor 3:12
Seeing then that we have such trust we use great boldness,

2Cor 3:13
and do not as Moses, which put a veil over his face that the children of Israell should not see for what purpose that served which is put away.

2Cor 3:14
But their minds were blinded. For until this day remaineth the same covering untaken away in the old testament when they read it, which in Christ is put away:

2Cor 3:15
But even unto this day, when Moses is read the veil hangeth before their hearts.

2Cor 3:16
Nevertheless when they turn to the Lord, the veil shall be taken away.

2Cor 3:17
The Lord no doubt is a spirit. And where the spirit of the Lord is, there is liberty.

2Cor 3:18
And now the Lordi's glory appeareth in us all, as in a glass: and we are changed unto the same similitude, from glory to glory, even of the Lord which is a spirit.

2Cor 4:1
Therefore seeing that we have such an office, even as mercy is come on us, we faint not:

2Cor 4:2
but have cast from us the cloaks of unhonesty, and walk not in craftiness, neither corrupt we the word of God: but walk in open truth, and report ourselves to every man's conscience in the sight of God.

2Cor 4:3
If our Gospell be yet hid, it is hid among them that are lost,

2Cor 4:4
in whom the God of this world hath blinded the minds of them which believe not, lest should shine unto them the light of the glorious gospel of Christ, which is the image of God,

2Cor 4:5
for we preach not ourselves, but Christ Iesus the Lord, and preach ourselves your servants for Iesus' sake.

2Cor 4:6
For it is God that commanded the light to shine out of darkness, which hath shined in our hearts, for to give the light of knowledge of the glorious God, in the face of Iesus Christ.

2Cor 4:7
But we have this treasure in earthen vessels that the excellent power of it might appear to be of God, and not of us.

2Cor 4:8
We are troubled on every side, yet are we not without shift. We are in poverty: but not utterly without somewhat.

2Cor 4:9
We are persecuted: but are not forsaken. We are cast down: nevertheless we perish not.

2Cor 4:10
And we always bear in our bodies the dying of the Lord Iesus, that the life of Iesu might appear in our bodies.

2Cor 4:11
For we which live, are always delivered unto death for Iesus' sake, that the life also of Iesu might appear in our mortal flesh.

2Cor 4:12
So then death worketh in us, and life in you.

2Cor 4:13
Seeing then that we have the same spirit of faith, according as it is written (I believed and therefore have I spoken) we also believe, and therefore speak.

2Cor 4:14
For we know that he which raised up the Lord Iesus, shall raise up us also by the means of Iesus, and shall set us with you,

2Cor 4:15
for all things I do for your sakes, that the plenteous grace by thanks given of many, may redound to the praise of God.

2Cor 4:16
Wherefore we are not wearied, but though our outward man perish, yet the inward man is renewed day by day.

2Cor 4:17
For our exceeding tribulation, which is momentary and light, prepareth an exceeding, and eternal weight of glory unto us,

2Cor 4:18
while we look not on the things which are seen, but on the things which are not seen. For things which are seen, are temporal: but things which are not seen are eternal.

2Cor 5:1
We know surely if our earthy mansion wherein we now dwell were destroyed, that we have a building ordained of God, an habitation not made with hands, but eternal in heaven:

2Cor 5:2
And herefore sigh we, desiring to be clothed with our mansion which is from heaven:

2Cor 5:3
if it happen that we be found clothed, and not naked.

2Cor 5:4
For as long as we are in this tabernacle, we sigh and are grieved: for we would not be unclothed: but would be clothed upon, that mortality might be swallowed up of life.

2Cor 5:5
He that hath ordained us for this thing, is God: which very same hath given unto us the earnest of the spirit.

2Cor 5:6
We are alway of good cheer, and know well that as long as we are at home in the body we are absent from God.

2Cor 5:7
For we walk in faith and see not.

2Cor 5:8
Nevertheless we are of good comfort, and had lever to be absent from the body and to be present with God.

2Cor 5:9
Wherefore we endeavor ourselves, wether we be at home or from home, to please God.

2Cor 5:10
For we must all be brought before the judgement seat of Christ that every man may receive the works of his body according to that he hath done, whether it be good or bad?

2Cor 5:11
Seeing then that we know how the Lord is to be feared, we fare fair with men. For we are known well enough unto God. I trust also that we are known in your consciences.

2Cor 5:12
We praise not ourselves again unto you, but give you an occasion to rejoice of us, that ye may have somewhat against them, which rejoice in the face, and not in the heart.

2Cor 5:13
For if we be too fervent, to God are we to fervent: if we keep measure, for your cause keep we measure.

2Cor 5:14
For the love of Christ constraineth us, because we thus judge, if one be dead for all, that then are all dead,

2Cor 5:15
and that he died for all, because that they which live, should not henceforth live unto themselves: but unto him which died for them and rose again.

2Cor 5:16
Wherefore henceforth know we no man after the flesh. Insomuch that though we have known Christ after the flesh, now henceforth know we him so no more.

2Cor 5:17
Therefore if any man be in Christ, he is a new creature. Old things are passed away, behold all things are become new.

2Cor 5:18
Nevertheless all things are of God, which hath reconciled us unto himself by Iesus Christ, and hath given unto us the office to preach the atonement.

2Cor 5:19
For God was in Christ, and made agreement between the world and him self, and imputed not their sins unto them: and hath committed to us the preaching of the atonement.

2Cor 5:20
Now then are we messengers in the room of Christ: even as though God did beseech you thorow us: So pray we you in Christe's stead, that ye be at one with God:

2Cor 5:21
for he hath made him to be sin for us, which knew no sin, that we by his means should be that righteousness which before God is allowed.

2Cor 6:1
We as helpers therefore exhort you, that ye receive not the grace of God in vain.

2Cor 6:2
For he saith: I have heard thee in a time accepted: and in the day of health, have I succoured thee. Behold now is that well accepted time: behold now is the day of health.

2Cor 6:3
Let us give no man occasion of evil, that in our office be found no fault:

2Cor 6:4
but in all things let us behave ourselves as the ministers of God. In much patience, in afflictions, in necessity, in anguish,

2Cor 6:5
in stripes, in prisonment, in strife, in labour, in watch, in fasting,

2Cor 6:6
in pureness, in knowledge, in longsuffering, in kindness, in the holy ghost, in love unfeigned,

2Cor 6:7
in the words of truth, in the power of God, by the armour of righteousness of the right hand and on the left hand,

2Cor 6:8
in honour and dishonour, in evil report and good report, as deceivers and yet true,

2Cor 6:9
as unknown, and yet known: as dying and behold we yet live: as chastened and not killed:

2Cor 6:10
as sorrowing and yet alwaye merry: as poor and yet make many rich: as having no thing and yet possessing all things.

2Cor 6:11
O ye Corinthians, our mouth is open unto you. Our heart is made large:

2Cor 6:12
ye are not brought into cumbrance by us, though that ye vex yourselves of a true meaning.

2Cor 6:13
I speake unto you as unto children, which have like reward with us:

2Cor 6:14
Stretch yourselves therefore out. bear not the yoke with the unbelievers. For what fellowship hath righteousness with unrighteousness? What company hath light with darkness?

2Cor 6:15
What concord hath Christ with beliall? Either what part hath he that believeth with an infidel?

2Cor 6:16
how agreeth the temple of God with images? And ye are the temple of the living God, as said God: I will dwell among them, and walk among them, and will be their God: and they shall be my people.

2Cor 6:17
Wherefore come out from among them, and separate yourselves (saith the Lord) and touch none unclean thing: so will I receive you,

2Cor 6:18
and will be a father unto you, and ye shall be unto me sons and daughters, saith the Lord almighty.

2Cor 7:1
Seeing that we have such promises dearly beloved, let us cleanse ourselves from all filthiness of the flesh and spirit, and grow up to full holiness in the fear of God.

2Cor 7:2
Understand us: we have hurt no man: we have corrupted no man: we have defrauded no man.

2Cor 7:3
I speak not this to condemn you: for I have shewed you before that ye are in our hearts to die and live with you.

2Cor 7:4
I am very bold over you, and rejoice greatly in you. I am filled with comfort, my joy exceeding in all our tribulations.

2Cor 7:5
For when we were come into Macedonia, our flesh had no rest, but we were troubled on every side: Outward was fighting, inward was fear.

2Cor 7:6
Nevertheless he that comforteth the abject, comforted us at the coming of Titus.

2Cor 7:7
And not with his coming only: but also with the consolation wherewith he was comforted of you. For he told us your desire, your mourning, your fervent mind to meward: So that I now rejoice the more.

2Cor 7:8
Wherefore though I made you sorry with a letter I repent not: though I did repent. For I perceive that that same Epistle made you sorry though it were but for a season.

2Cor 7:9
But I now rejoice, not that ye were sorry, but that ye so sorrowed, that ye repented.

2Cor 7:10
For ye sorrowed godly: so that in nothing were ye hurt by us. For godly sorrow causeth repentance unto health, not to be repented of: when worldly sorrow causeth death.

2Cor 7:11
Behold what diligence this godly sorrow that ye took hath wrought in you: yea it caused you to clear yourselves. It caused indignation, it caused fear, it caused desire, it caused a fervent mind, it caused punishment. For in all things ye have shewed yourselves that ye were clear in that business.

2Cor 7:12
Wherefore though I have written unto you, I did it not for his cause that did hurt, neither for his cause that was hurt: but that our good mind which we have toward you in the sight of God, might appear unto you.

2Cor 7:13
Therefore we are comforted, because ye are comforted: yea and exceedingly the more joyed we, for the joy that Titus had: because his spirit was refreshed of you all.

2Cor 7:14
I am therefore not now ashamed, though I boasted myself to him of you. For as all things which I preached unto you are true, even so is our boasting, that I boasted myself to Titus withall, found true.

2Cor 7:15
And now is his inward affection more abundant toward you, when he remembereth the obedience of every one of you: how with fear and trembling ye received him.

2Cor 7:16
I rejoice that I may be bold over you in all things.

2Cor 8:1
I do you to wit brethren of the grace of God, which is given in the congregations of Macedonia,

2Cor 8:2
how that the abundance of their rejoicing is, that they are tried with much tribulation. And how that their poverty, though it be deep, yet hath followed over, and is be come unto them riches in singleness.

2Cor 8:3
For to their powers (I bear them record) yea and beyond their power, they were willing of their own accord,

2Cor 8:4
and prayed us with great instance, that we would receive their benefit, and suffer them to be part takers with other in ministering to the saints.

2Cor 8:5
And this they did, not as we looked for: but gave their own selves first to the Lord, and after unto us by the will of God:

2Cor 8:6
so that we could not but desire Titus to accomplish the same benevolence among you also, even as he had begun.

2Cor 8:7
Now therefore, as ye are rich in all parts, in faith, in word, in knowledge, in all ferventness, and in love, which ye have to us: even so see that ye be plenteous in this benevolence.

2Cor 8:8
This say I not as commanding: but because other are so fervent, therefore prove I your love, whether it be perfect or no.

2Cor 8:9
Ye know the liberality of our Lord Iesus Christ, which though he were rich, yet for your sakes became poor: that ye thorow his poverty might be made rich.

2Cor 8:10
And I give counsel hereto: For this is expedient for you, which began, not to do only: but also to will, a year ago.

2Cor 8:11
Now therefore perform the deed, that as there was in you a readiness to will, even so ye may perform the deed, of that which ye have.

2Cor 8:12
For if there be first a willing mind, it is accepted according to that a man hath, and not according to that he hath not.

2Cor 8:13
It is not my mind that other be set at ease, and ye brought into cumbrance: but that there be egalness.

2Cor 8:14
Let your abundance succour their lack at this present time of dearth: that their abundance may supply your lack: that there may be equality,

2Cor 8:15
agreeing to that which is written: He that gathered much had never the more abundance, and he that gathered little, had nevertheless.

2Cor 8:16
Thanks be unto God, which put in the heart of Titus the same good mind toward you.

2Cor 8:17
For he accepted our request. yea rather he was so well willing, that of his own accord came unto you.

2Cor 8:18
We have sent with him that brother whose laud is in the gospel thorowout all the congregations:

2Cor 8:19
and not so only, but is also chosen of the congregations to be a fellow with us in our journey, as concerning this benevolence that is ministered by us unto the praise of the Lord, and to stir up your prompt mind.

2Cor 8:20
And this we eschew that any man should rebuke us in this abundance, that is ministered by us,

2Cor 8:21
and make provision for honest things, not in the sight of God only, but also in the sight of men.

2Cor 8:22
We have sent with them a brother of ours whom we have oft times proved diligent in many things, but now much more diligent. The great confidence which I have in you

2Cor 8:23
hath caused me this to do: partly for Titus' sake which is my fellow, and helper as concerning you: partly because of other which are our brethren, and the messengers of the congregations, and the glory of Christ.

2Cor 8:24
Wherefore shew unto them the proof of your love, and of the rejoicing that we have of you, that the congregations may see it.

2Cor 9:1
Of the ministering to the saints, it is but superfluous for me to write unto you:

2Cor 9:2
for I know your readiness of mind, whereof I boast myself unto them of Macedonia, and say that Achaia was prepared a year ago, and your ferventness hath provoked many.

2Cor 9:3
Nevertheless yet have I sent these brethren, lest our rejoicing over you should be in vain in this behalf, and that ye (as I have said) prepare yourselves,

2Cor 9:4
lest peradventure if they of Macedonia come with me and find you unprepared, the boast that I made in this matter should be a shame to us: I say not unto you.

2Cor 9:5
Wherefore I thought it necessary to exhort the brethren, to come before hand unto you, for to prepare your good blessing promised afore, that it might be ready: so that it be a blessing, and not a defrauding.

2Cor 9:6
This yet remember, how that he which soweth little, shall reap little: and he that soweth plenteously shall reap plenteously.

2Cor 9:7
And let every man do according as he hath purposed in his heart, not grudgingly, or of necessity. For God loveth a cheerful giver.

2Cor 9:8
God is able to make you rich in all grace, that ye in all things having sufficient unto the utmost, may be rich unto all manner good works,

2Cor 9:9
as it is written: He that sparse abroad and hath given to the poor, his righteousness remaineth for ever.

2Cor 9:10
He that findeth the sower seed, shall minister bread for food, and shall multiply your seed, and increase the fruits of your righteousness that on all parts,

2Cor 9:11
ye may be made rich in all singleness, which causeth throwe us, thanks giving unto God.

2Cor 9:12
For the office of this ministration, not only supplieth the need of the saints: but also is abundant herein, that for this laudable ministering, thanks might be given to God of many,

2Cor 9:13
which praise God for the obedience in knowledging the gospel of Christ, and for your singleness, in distributing to them, and to all men.

2Cor 9:14
and in their prayers to God for you, long after you, for the abundant grace of God given unto you.

2Cor 9:15
Thanks be unto God for his ineffable gift.

2Cor 10:1
I Paul myself beseech you by the meekness and softness of Christ, which when I am present among you, am of no reputation, but am bold toward you being absent.

2Cor 10:2
I beseech you that I need not to be bold when I am present (with that same confidence, wherewith I am supposed to be bold) against some which repute us as though we walked carnally.

2Cor 10:3
Nevertheless though we walk compassed with the flesh, yet we war not fleshly.

2Cor 10:4
For the weapons of our war are not carnal things, but things mighty in God to cast down strongholds,

2Cor 10:5
wherewith we overthrow imaginations, and every high thing that exalteth itself against the knowledge of God, and bring into captivity all understanding to the obedience of Christ,

2Cor 10:6
and are ready to take vengeance on all disobedience, when your obedience is fulfilled.

2Cor 10:7
Look ye on things after the utter appearance. If any man trust in himself that he is Christis, let the same also consider of himself, that as he is Christis, even so are we Christe's.

2Cor 10:8
And though I should boast myself somewhat more of our authority which the Lord hath given us to edify and not to destroy you, it should not be to my shame.

2Cor 10:9
This say I, lest I should seem as though I went about to make you afraid with letters.

2Cor 10:10
For the pistels (saith he) are sore and strong: but his bodily presence is weak, and his speech homely.

2Cor 10:11
Let him that is such think on this wise, that as we are in words by letters when we are absent, such are we in deeds when we are present.

2Cor 10:12
For we cannot find in our hearts to make ourselves of the number of them, or to compare ourselves to them, which laud themselves: but while they measure themselves with themselves, and compare themselves with themselves, they understand nought.

2Cor 10:13
But we will not rejoice above measure: but according to the quantity of the measure which God hath distributed unto us, a measure that reacheth even unto you.

2Cor 10:14
For we stretch not out ourselves beyond measure as though we had not reached unto you. For even unto you have we come with the gospel of Christ,

2Cor 10:15
and we boast not ourselves out of measure in other men's labors: yea and we hope, When your faith is increased among you, to be magnified according to our measure more largely:

2Cor 10:16
And to preach the gospel in those regions which are beyond you: and not to rejoice of that which is by another man's measure prepared all ready.

2Cor 10:17
Let him that rejoiceth, rejoice in the Lord.

2Cor 10:18
For he that praiseth himself, is not allowed: but he whom the Lord praiseth.

2Cor 11:1
Would to God, ye could suffer me a little in my foolishness: yea, and I pray you forbear me.

2Cor 11:2
For I am jealous over you with godly jealousy. For I coupled you to one man, to make you a chaste virgin to Christ:

2Cor 11:3
But I fear lest as the serpent beguiled Eve, thorow his subtlety, even so your wits should be corrupt from the singleness that is in Christ.

2Cor 11:4
For if he that cometh to you preach another Iesus than him whom we preached: or if ye receive another spirit than that which ye have received: either another gospel than that ye have received, ye might right well have been content.

2Cor 11:5
I suppose that I was not behind the chief apostles.

2Cor 11:6
Though I be rude in speaking, yet I am not so in knowledge. How be it among you we are known to the utmost what we are in all things.

2Cor 11:7
Did I therein sin, because I submitted myself, that ye might be exalted? and because I preached the gospel to you free?

2Cor 11:8
I robbed other congregations, and took wages of them, to do you service withall.

2Cor 11:9
And when I was present with you and had need, I was grievous to no man. For that which was lacking unto me, the brethren which came from Macedonia supplied: and in all things I kept myself that I should not be grievous to you: and so will I keep myself.

2Cor 11:10
If the truth of Christ be in me, this rejoicing shall not be taken from me in the regions of Achaia.

2Cor 11:11
Wherefore? because I love you not? God knoweth.

2Cor 11:12
Nevertheless what I do, that will I do to cut away occasion from them which desire occasion, that they might be found like unto us in that wherein they rejoice:

2Cor 11:13
For these false apostles are deceitful workers, and fashion them selves like unto the apostles of Christ.

2Cor 11:14
And no marvel, for Satan himself is changed into the fashion of an angel of light.

2Cor 11:15
Therefore it is no great thing, though his ministers fashion themselves as though they were the ministers of righteousness: whose end shall be according to their deeds.

2Cor 11:16
I say again lest any man think that I am foolish: or else even now take me as a fool, that I may boast myself a little.

2Cor 11:17
That I speak, I speak it not after the ways of the Lord: but as it were foolishly, while we are now come to boasting.

2Cor 11:18
Seeing that many rejoice after the flesh I will rejoice also.

2Cor 11:19
For ye suffer fools gladly because that ye yourselves are wise.

2Cor 11:20
For ye suffer even if a man bring you into bondage: if a man devour: if a man take: if a man exalt himself: if a man smite you on the face.

2Cor 11:21
I speak as concerning rebuke, as though we had been weak. Whereinsoever any man dare be bold (I speak foolishly) I dare be bold also.

2Cor 11:22
They are Hebrews, so am I: They are Israelites, even so am I: They are the seed of Abraham, even so am I.

2Cor 11:23
They are the ministers of Christ (I speak as a fool) I am more: In labors more abundant: In stripes above measure: In prison more plenteously:

2Cor 11:24
In death often. Of the Jewes five times received I every time xl. stripes, one except.

2Cor 11:25
Thrice was I beaten with rods. I was once stoned. I suffered thrice shipwreck. Night and day have I been in the deep of the sea.

2Cor 11:26
In journeying often: In perils of waters In perils of robbers. In jeopardies of mine own nation: In jeopardies among the heathen. I have been in perils in cities, in perils in wilderness, in perils in the sea, in perils among false brethren,

2Cor 11:27
in labour and travail, in watching often, in hunger, in thirst, in fastings often, in cold and in nakedness.

2Cor 11:28
Beside the things which outwardly happen unto me, I am cumbered daily and do care for all congregations.

2Cor 11:29
Who is sick: and I am not sick? Who is hurt in the faith: and my heart burneth not?

2Cor 11:30
If I must needs rejoice, I will rejoice of mine infirmities.

2Cor 11:31
God the father of our Lord Iesus Christ, which is blessed for evermore, knoweth that I lie not.

2Cor 11:32
In the city of Damaschon, the governor of the people under king Aretas, laid watch in the city of the Damascens, and would have caught me,

2Cor 11:33
and at a window was I let down in a basket thorow the wall, and so escaped his hands.

2Cor 12:1
It is not expedient for me no doubt to rejoice, Nevertheless I will come to visions and revelations of the Lord.

2Cor 12:2
I know a man in Christ above xiiij years agone (whether he were in the body I cannot tell, or whether he were out of the body I cannot tell, God knoweth) which was taken up into the third heaven.

2Cor 12:3
And I know the same man (whether in the body, or out of the body, I cannot tell, God knoweth)

2Cor 12:4
how that he was taken up into paradise, and heard words not to be spoken, which no man can utter.

2Cor 12:5
Of this man will I rejoice, of myself will I not rejoice, except it be of mine infirmities:

2Cor 12:6
and yet though I would rejoice I should not be a fool: for I would say the truth. Nevertheless I spare, lest any man should think of me above that he seeth me to be, or heareth of me.

2Cor 12:7
And lest I should be exalted out of measure thorow the abundance of revelations, there was given unto me of God unquietness of the flesh, the messenger of Satan to buffet me: because I should not be exalted out of measure.

2Cor 12:8
For this thing besought I the Lord thrice, that it might depart from me:

2Cor 12:9
and he said unto me: my grace is sufficient for thee. For my strength is made perfect throu weakness. Very gladly therefore will I rejoice of my weakness, that the strength of Christ may dwell in me.

2Cor 12:10
Therefore have I delectation in infirmities, in rebukes, in need, in persecutions, in anguish, for Christis sake. For when I am weak, then am I strong.

2Cor 12:11
I am made a fool in boasting myself. Ye have compelled me: I ought to have been commended of you. For in nothing was I inferior unto the chief apostles, though I be nothing,

2Cor 12:12
yet the tokens of an apostle were wrought among you with all patience: with signs, and wonders, and mighty deeds.

2Cor 12:13
For what is it wherein ye were inferiors unto other congregations? except it be therein that I was not grievous unto you. Forgive me this wrong done unto you.

2Cor 12:14
Behold now the third time I am ready to come unto you, neither will I be grievous unto you. For I seek not yours but you. Also the children ought not to lay up for the fathers and mothers: but the fathers and mothers for the children.

2Cor 12:15
I will very gladly bestow, and will be bestowed for your souls: though the more I love you, the less I am loved again.

2Cor 12:16
But be it that I grieved you not: nevertheless I was crafty and took you with guile.

2Cor 12:17
Did I pill you by any of them which I sent unto you?

2Cor 12:18
I desired Titus, and with him I sent a brother: Did Titus defraud you of any thing? walked we not in one spirit? walked we not in like steps?

2Cor 12:19
Again, think ye that we excuse ourselves? we speak in Christ in the sight of God. But we do all things dearly beloved for your edifying.

2Cor 12:20
For I fear lest it come to pass, that when I come, I shall not find you such as I would: and I shall be found unto you such as ye would not: I fear lest there be found among you lawynge, envying, wrath, strife, backbitings, whisperings, swellings, and debate.

2Cor 12:21
I fear lest when I come again, God bring me low among you, and I be constrained to bewail many of them which have sinned already, and have not repented of the uncleanness, and fornication, and wantonness which they have committed.

2Cor 13:1
Now come I the third time unto you: in the mouth of two or three witnesses shall every word stand.

2Cor 13:2
I told you before, and tell you before, as I said when I was present with you the second time, so write I now being absent to them which in time past have sinned, and to all other: If I come again, I will not spare

2Cor 13:3
seeing that ye seek experience of Christ which speaketh in me, which among you is not weak, but is mighty in you.

2Cor 13:4
And verily though it came of weakness that he was crucified, yet liveth he thorow the power of God: and we no doubt are weak in him: but we shall live with him, by the might that God gave us to youward.

2Cor 13:5
Prove yourselves whether ye are in the faith or not. Examine your own selves: know ye not your own selves, how that Iesus Christ is in you? except ye be castaways.

2Cor 13:6
I trust that ye shall know that we are not castaways.

2Cor 13:7
I desire before God that ye do none evil, not that we should seem commendable: but that ye should do, that which is honest: and let us be counted as lewd persons.

2Cor 13:8
We can do nothing against the truth, but for the truth.

2Cor 13:9
We are glad when we are weak, and ye strong. This also we wish for, even that ye were perfect.

2Cor 13:10
Therefore write I these things being absent, lest when I am present I should use sharpness according to the power which the Lord hath given me, to edify, and not to destroy.

2Cor 13:11
Furthermore brethren fare ye well, be perfect, be of good comfort, be of one mind, live in peace, and the God of love and peace, shall be with you.

2Cor 13:12
Greet one another in an holy kiss.

2Cor 13:13
All the saints salute you.

2Cor 13:14
The faveour of our Lord Iesus Christ, and the love of God, and the fellowship of the holy ghost, be with you all Amen. <The second pistle to the Corinthians. Sent from Phillippos a citie in Macedonia by Titus and Lucas.>

Gal 1:1
Paul an Apostle, not of men, neither by man, but by Iesus Christ, and by God the father which raised him from death,

Gal 1:2
and all the brethren which are with me. Unto the congregations of Galacia.

Gal 1:3
Grace be with you and peace from God the father, and from our Lord Iesus Christ,

Gal 1:4
which gave himself for our sins, to deliver us from this present evil world, thorow the will of God our father,

Gal 1:5
to whom be praise for ever and ever Amen.

Gal 1:6
I marvel that ye are so soon turned from him that called you in the grace of Christ, unto another gospell,

Gal 1:7
which is nothing else, but that there be some which trouble you, and intend to pervert the gospell of Christ.

Gal 1:8
Nevertheless though we ourselves, or an angel from heaven, preach any other gospell unto you than that which we have preached unto you, hold him as accursed.

Gal 1:9
As I said before, so say I now again, if any man preach any other thing unto you, than that ye have received, hold him accursed.

Gal 1:10
Seek I now the faveour of men, or of God? Other go I about to please men? If I studied to please men, I were not the servant of Christ.

Gal 1:11
I certify you brethren, that the gospell which was preached of me, was not after the manner of men,

Gal 1:12
neither received I it of man, neither was I taught it: but received it by the revelation of Iesus Christ.

Gal 1:13
Ye have heard of my conversation in times past in the Jewes' ways, how that beyond measure I persecuted the congregation of God, and spoiled it:

Gal 1:14
and prevailed in the jewes' law, above many of my companions, which were of mine own nation, and was a much more fervently maintained the traditions of the elders.

Gal 1:15
But when it pleased God, which separated me from my mother's womb, and called me by his grace,

Gal 1:16
for to declare his son by me, that I should preach him among the heathen: Immediately I commended not of the matter with flesh and blood,

Gal 1:17
neither returned to Ierusalem to them which were apostles before me: but went my ways into Arabia, and came again unto Damascon.

Gal 1:18
Then after three years, I returned to Ierusalem unto Peter and abode with him xv days,

Gal 1:19
no other of the apostles saw I, save Iames the Lord's brother.

Gal 1:20
The things which I write, behold, God knoweth I lie not.

Gal 1:21
After that I went into the coasts of Siria and Cicill:

Gal 1:22
and was unknown as touching my person unto the congregations of Jewry, which were in Christ.

Gal 1:23
But they heard only, that he which persecuted us in time past, now preacheth the faith, which before he destroyed.

Gal 1:24
And they glorified God in me.

Gal 2:1
Then xiiij. years there after, I went up again to Ierusalem with Barnabas, and took with me Titus also.

Gal 2:2
Yea, and I went up by revelation, and commended with them of the gospell, which I preach among the gentiles: but apart with them that are counted chief, lest it should have been thought that I should run, or had run in vain.

Gal 2:3
Also Titus which was with me, though he were a Greek, yet was not compelled to be circumcised,

Gal 2:4
and that because of incomers being false brethren, which came in among others to spy out our liberty which we have in Christ Iesus, that they might bring us into bondage.

Gal 2:5
To whom we gave no room, no not for the space of an hour, as concerning to be brought into subjection: and that because that the truth of the gospell might continue with you.

Gal 2:6
Of them which seemed to be great (what they were in time passed it maketh no matter to me: God looketh on no man's person) nevertheless they which seem great, added nothing to me:

Gal 2:7
But contrariwise, when they saw that the gospell over the uncircumcision was committed unto me, as the gospell over circumcision was unto Peter

Gal 2:8
(For he that was mighty in Peter in the apostleship over the circumcision, the same was mighty in me among the gentiles:)

Gal 2:9
and as soon as Iames, Cephas, and Ihon, which seemed to be pillars, perceived the grace that was given unto me, they gave to me and Barnabas their hands, and agreed with us that we should preach among the heathen, and they among the Jewes:

Gal 2:10
warning only that we should remember the poor, which thing also I was diligent to do.

Gal 2:11
When Peter was come to Antioch, I withstood him in the face, for he was worthy to be blamed.

Gal 2:12
For yer that certain came from Iames, he ate with the gentiles: but when they were come, he withdrew and separated himself, fearing them which were of the circumcision,

Gal 2:13
and the other Jewes dissembled likewise, In so much that Barnabas was brought into their simulation also.

Gal 2:14
But when I saw that they went not the right way after the truth of the gospell, I said unto Peter, before all men, if thou being a Jewe, livest after the manner of the gentiles, and not as do the Jewes: why causest thou the gentiles to follow the Jewes?

Gal 2:15
we which are Jewes by nature and not sinners of the gentiles,

Gal 2:16
know that a man is not justified by the deeds of the law: but by the faith of Iesus Christ: and we have believed on Iesus Christ, that we might be justified by the faith of Christ and not by the deeds of the law: because that no flesh shall be justified by the deeds of the law:

Gal 2:17
If then while we seek to be made righteous by Christ, we ourselves are found sinners, is not then Christ the minister of sin? God forbid.

Gal 2:18
For if I build again that which I destroyed, then make I my self a trespasser.

Gal 2:19
But I thorow the law am dead to the law, that I might live unto God.

Gal 2:20
I am crucified with Christ. I live verily, yet now not I, but Christ liveth in me. The life which I now live in the flesh, I live by the faith of the son of God, which loved me, and gave himself for me.

Gal 2:21
I despise not the grace of God: For if righteousness come of the law, then is Christ dead in vain.

Gal 3:1
O foolish Galatians: who hath bewitched you, that ye should not believe the truth? to whom Iesus Christ was described before the eyes, and among you crucified?

Gal 3:2
This only would I learn of you, received ye the spirit by the deeds of the law? or else by preaching of the faith?

Gal 3:3
Are ye so unwise, that after ye have begun in the spirit, ye would now end in the flesh?

Gal 3:4
So many things ye have suffered in vain. If it be so that ye have suffered in vain.

Gal 3:5
Which ministered to you the spirit, and worketh miracles among you doth he it thorow the deeds of the law? or by preaching of the faith?

Gal 3:6
Even as Abraham believed God, and it was ascribed to him for righteousness.

Gal 3:7
Understand therefore, that they which are of faith, are the children of Abraham.

Gal 3:8
The scripture saw aforehand, that God would justify the heathen thorow faith, and shewed beforehand glad tidings unto Abraham: In thee shall all nations be blessed.

Gal 3:9
So then they which be of faith, are blessed with faithful Abraham.

Gal 3:10
For as many as are under the deeds of the law, are under malediction. For it is written: cursed is every man that continueth not in all things which are written in the book of the law to fulfil them.

Gal 3:11
That no man is justified by the law in the sight of God is evident. For the just shall live by faith.

Gal 3:12
The law is not of faith: but the man that fulfilleth the things contained in the law, shall live in them.

Gal 3:13
Christ hath delivered us from the curse of the law, and was made a cursed for us (for it is written: Cursed is everyone that hangeth on tree)

Gal 3:14
that the blessing of Abraham might come on the gentiles throwe Iesus Christ, that we might receive the promise of the spirit thorow faith.

Gal 3:15
Brethren I will speak after the manner of men. Though it be but a man's testament, yet no man despiseth it, or addeth any thing thereto when it is once allowed.

Gal 3:16
To Abraham and his seed were the promises made. He saith not, in thy seeds as in many: But in thy seed, as in one, which is Christ.

Gal 3:17
This I say that the law which began afterward, beyond iiij. C. and xxx. years, doth not disannul the testament, that was confirmed of God unto Christward, to make the promise of none effect.

Gal 3:18
For if the inheritance come of the law, it cometh not of promise: but God gave it unto Abraham by promise.

Gal 3:19
Wherefore then serveth the law? The law was added because of transgression (till the seed came to which the promise was made) and it was ordained by angels in the hand of a mediator.

Gal 3:20
A mediator is not a mediator of one. But God is one.

Gal 3:21
Is the law then against the promise of God? God forbid. If there had been a law given which could have given life: then no doubt righteousness should have come by the law:

Gal 3:22
but the scripture concluded all things under sin, that the promise by the faith of Iesus Christ, should be given unto them that believe.

Gal 3:23
Before that faith came, we were kept and shut up under the law, unto the faith which should afterward be declared.

Gal 3:24
Wherefore the law was our schoolmaster unto the time of Christ, that we might be made righteous by faith.

Gal 3:25
But after that faith is come, now are we no longer under a schoolmaster.

Gal 3:26
For ye are all the sons of God, by the faith which is in Christ Iesus.

Gal 3:27
For all ye that are baptised, have put Christ on you.

Gal 3:28
Now is there no Jewe, neither Greek: there is neither bond, neither free: there is neither man, neither woman: for all are one thing in Christ Iesu.

Gal 3:29
If ye be Christe's, then are ye Abraham's seed, and heirs by promise.

Gal 4:1
And I say that the heir as long as he is a child differeth not from a servant, though he be lord of all,

Gal 4:2
but is under tutors and governors, until the time appointed of the father.

Gal 4:3
Even so we, as long as we were children, were in bondage under the ordinances of the world:

Gal 4:4
But when the time was full come, God sent his son born of a woman, and made bond unto the law,

Gal 4:5
to redeem them which were under the law: that we thorow election should receive the inheritance that belongeth unto the natural sons.

Gal 4:6
Because ye are sons, God hath sent the spirit of his son into our hearts, which crieth Abba father.

Gal 4:7
Wherefore now art thou not a servant, but a son. If thou be the son, thou art also the heir of God thorow Christ.

Gal 4:8
Notwithstanding, when ye knew not God, ye did service unto them, which by nature were not goddes:

Gal 4:9
But now seeing ye know God (yea rather are known of God) how is it that ye turn again unto the weak and beggarly ceremonies, whereunto again ye desire afresh to be in bondage?

Gal 4:10
Ye observe the days, and months, and times, and years.

Gal 4:11
I fear of you, lest I have bestowed on you labour in vain.

Gal 4:12
Brethren I beseech you, be ye as I am: for I am as ye are. Ye have not hurt me.

Gal 4:13
Ye know well how that thorow infirmity of the flesh, I preached the gospell unto you at the first:

Gal 4:14
and my temptation which I suffered by reason of my flesh, ye despised not, neither abhorred: but received me as an angel of God: yea as Christ Iesus.

Gal 4:15
How happy were ye then? for I bear you record that if it had been possible, ye would have digged out your own eyes, and have given them to me.

Gal 4:16
Am I so greatly become your enemy, because I tell you the truth?

Gal 4:17
They are jealous over you amiss. Yea they intend to exclude you that ye should be fervent to themward.

Gal 4:18
It is good always to be fervent, so it be in a good thing, and not only when I am present with you.

Gal 4:19
My little children (of whom I travail in birth again until Christ be fashioned in you)

Gal 4:20
I would I were with you now, and could change my voice, for I stand in a doubt of you.

Gal 4:21
Tell me ye that desire to be under the law: have ye not heard of the law?

Gal 4:22
For it is written that Abraham had two sons, the one by a bondmaid, the other by a free woman.

Gal 4:23
Yea and he which was of the bondwoman, was born after the flesh: but he which was of the freewoman, was born by promise.

Gal 4:24
Which things betoken mystery. For these women are two testaments, the one from the mount Sina, which gendreth unto bondage, which is Agar.

Gal 4:25
(For mount Sinai is called Agar in Arabia, and bordereth upon the city which is now Ierusalem) and is in bondage with her children.

Gal 4:26
But Ierusalem, which is above, is free: which is the mother of us all.

Gal 4:27
For it is written: rejoice thou barren, that bearest no children: break forth and cry, thou that travailest not. For the desolate hath many more children, than she which hath an husband.

Gal 4:28
Brethren we are after the manner of Isaac children of promise:

Gal 4:29
But as then he that was born carnally, persecuted him that was born spiritually, Even so is it now.

Gal 4:30
Nevertheless what saith the scripture: Cast a way the bondwoman and her son. For the son of the bondwoman shall not be heir with the son of the free woman.

Gal 4:31
So then brethren we are not children of the bondwoman: but of the freewoman.

Gal 5:1
Stand fast therefore in the liberty wherewith Christ hath made us free, and wrap not yourselves again in the yoke of bondage.

Gal 5:2
Be hold I Paul say unto you, that if ye be circumcised, Christ shall profit you nothing at all.

Gal 5:3
I testify again to every man which is circumcised that he is bound to keep the whole law.

Gal 5:4
Ye are gone quite from Christ as many as are justified by the law, and are fallen from grace.

Gal 5:5
We look for and hope to be justified by the spirit which commeth of faith.

Gal 5:6
For in Iesu Christ, neither is circumcision anything worth, neither yet uncircumcision, but faith which by love is mighty in operation.

Gal 5:7
Ye did run well. Who was a lett unto you, that ye should not obey the truth?

Gal 5:8
Even that counsel that is not of him that called you.

Gal 5:9
A little leaven doth leaven the whole lump of dough.

Gal 5:10
I have trust toward you in God, that ye will be none otherwise minded. He that troubleth you shall bear his judgement, whatsoever he be.

Gal 5:11
Brethren if I yet preach circumcision: why do I then yet suffer persecution? For then had the offense which the cross giveth ceased.

Gal 5:12
I would to God they were sundered from you which trouble you.

Gal 5:13
Brethren ye were called into liberty, only let not your liberty be an occasion unto the flesh but in love serve one another.

Gal 5:14
For all the law is fulfilled in one word, which is this: Thou shalt love thine neighbour as thyself.

Gal 5:15
If ye bite and devour one another: take heed lest ye be consumed one of another.

Gal 5:16
I say walk in the spirit, and fulfil not the lusts of the flesh.

Gal 5:17
For the flesh lusteth contrary to the spirit, and the spirit contrary to the flesh. These are contrary one to the other, so that ye cannot do that which ye would.

Gal 5:18
But and if ye be led of the spirit, then are ye not under the law.

Gal 5:19
The deeds of the flesh are manifest, which are these, advoutry, fornication, uncleanness, wantonness,

Gal 5:20
idolatry, witchcraft, hatred, lawyinge, zeal, wrath, strife, sedition, parte takings,

Gal 5:21
envying, murder, drunkenness, gluttony, and such like: of the which I tell you before, as I have told you in time past, that they which commit such things shall not be inheritors of the kingdom of God:

Gal 5:22
but the fruit of the spirit is, love, joy, peace, longsuffering gentleness, goodness, faith fulness, meekness, temperancy:

Gal 5:23
Against such there is no law.

Gal 5:24
They that are Christis, have crucified the flesh with the appetites and lusts.

Gal 5:25
If we live in the spirit let us walk in the spirit.

Gal 5:26
Let us not be vain glorious, provoking one another, and envying one another.

Gal 6:1
Brethren, if any man be fallen by chance into any fault: ye which are spiritual, help to amend him, in the spirit of meekness: considering thyself, lest thou also be tempted.

Gal 6:2
Bear ye one another's burden: and so fulfil the law of Christ.

Gal 6:3
If a man seem to himself that he is somewhat when indeed he is nothing, the same deceiveth himself in his imagination.

Gal 6:4
Let every man prove his own work, and then shall he have rejoicing in his own self, and not in another.

Gal 6:5
For every man shall bear his own burden.

Gal 6:6
Let him that is taught in the word, minister unto him that teacheth him in all good things.

Gal 6:7
Be not deceived, God is not mocked. For whatsoever a man soweth, that shall he reap.

Gal 6:8
He that soweth in his flesh, shall of the flesh reap corruption: but he that soweth in the spirit shall, of the spirit reap life everlasting.

Gal 6:9
Let us do good, and let us not faint. For when the time is come we shall reap without weariness.

Gal 6:10
While we have therefore time let us do good unto all men, and specially, unto them which are of the household of faith.

Gal 6:11
Behold how large a letter I have written unto you with mine own hand.

Gal 6:12
As many as desire with utward appearance to please carnally, they constrain you to be circumcised, only because they would not suffer persecution with the cross of Christ.

Gal 6:13
For they them selves which are circumcised keep not the law: but desire to have you circumcised that they might rejoice in your flesh.

Gal 6:14
God forbid that I should rejoice but in the cross of our Lord Iesu Christ, whereby the world is crucified as touching me, and I as concerning the world.

Gal 6:15
For in Christ Iesu nether circumcision availeth any thing at all nor uncircumcision: but a new creature.

Gal 6:16
And as many as walk according to this rule, peace be on them, and mercy, and upon Israhel that pertaineth to God.

Gal 6:17
From hence forth, let no man put me to business. For I bear in my body the marks of the Lord Iesu.

Gal 6:18
Brethren the grace of our Lord Iesu Christe be with your spirit, Amen. <Unto the Galathyans written from Rome.>

Eph 1:1
Paul an apostle of Iesu Christ, by the will of God. To the saints at Ephesus, and to them which believe on Iesus Christ.

Eph 1:2
Grace be with you and peace from God our father, and from the Lord Iesus Christ.

Eph 1:3
Blessed be God the father of our Lord Iesus Christ, which hath blessed us with all manner of spiritual blessings in heavenly things by Christ,

Eph 1:4
according as he had chosen us in him throwe love, before the foundation of the world was laid, that we should be saints, and without blame in his sight.

Eph 1:5
And ordained us before unto him self that we should be chosen to heirs throwe Iesus Christ, according to the pleasure of his will,

Eph 1:6
to the praise of his glorious grace, where with he hath made us accepted in the beloved.

Eph 1:7
By whom we have redemption thorow his blood, that is to say the forgiveness of sins, according to the riches of his grace,

Eph 1:8
which grace he shed on us abundantly in all wisdom, and prudency.

Eph 1:9
And hath opened unto us the mystery of his will according to his pleasure, and purposed

Eph 1:10
the same in himself to have it declared when the time were full come, that all things, both the things which are in heaven, and also the things which are in earth, should be gathered together, even in Christ: that is to say in him

Eph 1:11
in whom we are made heirs, and were thereto predestinate according to the purpose of him which worketh all things after the purpose of his own will:

Eph 1:12
that we should be unto the praise of his glory, which before hoped in Christ.

Eph 1:13
In whom also ye (after that ye heard the word of truth, I mean the gospell of your health, wherein ye believed) were sealed with the holy spirit of promise,

Eph 1:14
which is the earnest of our inheritance, to redeem the possession purchased unto the laud of his glory.

Eph 1:15
Wherefore even I (after that I heard of the faith which ye have in the Lord Iesu, and love unto all the saints)

Eph 1:16
cease not to give thanks for you, making mention of you in my prayers,

Eph 1:17
that the God of our Lord Iesus Christ, and the father of glory, might give unto you the spirit of wisdom, and open to you the knowledge of himself,

Eph 1:18
and lighten the eyes of your minds, that ye might know what thing that hope is, whereunto he hath called you, and how glorious the riches of his inheritance is upon the saints,

Eph 1:19
and what is the exceeding greatness of his power to usward, which believe according to the working of that his mighty power,

Eph 1:20
which he wrought in Christ, when he raised him from death, and set him on his right hand in heavenly things,

Eph 1:21
above all rule, power, and might, and domination, and above all names that are named, not in this world only, but also in the world to come.

Eph 1:22
And hath put all things under his feet, and hath made him above all things, the head of the congregation,

Eph 1:23
which is his body, and fullness of him, that filleth all in all things.

Eph 2:1
And hath quickened you also that were dead in trespass and sin,

Eph 2:2
in the which in time passed ye walked, according to the course of this world, and after the governor, that ruleth in the air, the spirit that now worketh in the children of unbelief,

Eph 2:3
among which we also had our conversation in time past, in the lusts of our flesh, and fulfilled the will of the flesh, and of the mind: and were naturally the children of wrath, even as well as other.

Eph 2:4
But God which is rich in mercy thorow his great love wherewith he loved us,

Eph 2:5
even when we were dead by sin, hath quickened us with Christ (For by grace are ye saved)

Eph 2:6
and with him hath raised us up, and with him hath made us sit in heavenly things, thorow Iesus Christ,

Eph 2:7
For to shew in times to come the exceeding riches of his grace, in kindness to usward, thorow Christ Iesus.

Eph 2:8
For by grace are ye made safe throwe faith, and that not of your selves: For it is the gift of God,

Eph 2:9
and cometh not of works, lest any man should boast himself.

Eph 2:10
For we are his workmanship, created in Christ Iesu unto good works, unto the which God ordained us before, that we should walk in them.

Eph 2:11
Wherefore remember that ye being in time past gentiles in the flesh, and were called uncircumcision of them which are called circumcision in the flesh, which circumcision is made by hands:

Eph 2:12
Remember I say, that ye were at that time without Christ, and were reputed aliens from the common wealth of Israhel, and were fremed from the testaments of promise, and had no hope, and were without God in this world.

Eph 2:13
But now in Christ Iesu, ye which a while ago were far off, are made nye by the blood of Christ.

Eph 2:14
For he is our peace, which hath made of both one, and hath broken down the wall in the midst, that was a stop between us,

Eph 2:15
and hath also put away thorow his flesh, the cause of hatred (that is to say, the law of commandments contained in the law written,) for to make of twain one new man in himself, so making peace:

Eph 2:16
and to reconcile both unto God in one body throwe his cross, and slew hatred thereby:

Eph 2:17
and came and preached peace to you which were afar off, and to them that were nye.

Eph 2:18
For thorow him we both have an open way in, in one spirit unto the father.

Eph 2:19
Now therefore ye are no more strangers and foreigners: but citizens with the saints, and of the household of God:

Eph 2:20
and are built upon the foundation of the apostles and prophets, Iesus Christ being the head cornerstone,

Eph 2:21
in whom every building coupled together, groweth unto an holy temple in the Lord,

Eph 2:22
in whom ye also are built together, and made an habitation for God in the spirit.

Eph 3:1
For this cause I Paul the servant of Iesus am in bonds, For your sakes which are gentiles.

Eph 3:2
If ye have heard of the ministration of the grace of God which is given me to youward:

Eph 3:3
For by revelation shewed he this mystery unto me, as I wrote above in few words,

Eph 3:4
whereby, when ye read ye may know mine understanding in the ministry of Christ,

Eph 3:5
which mystery in times passed was not opened unto the sons of men as it is now declared unto his holy apostles and prophets by the spirit:

Eph 3:6
that the gentiles should be inheritors also, and of the same body, and partakers of his promise that is in Christ, by the means of the gospell,

Eph 3:7
whereof I am made a minister, by the gift of the grace of God given unto me, after the working of his power.

Eph 3:8
Unto me the least of all saints is this grace given, that I should preach among the gentiles the unsearchable riches of Christ,

Eph 3:9
and to give light to all men, that they might know what is the fellowship of the mystery, which from the beginning of the world hath been hid in God which made all things thorow Iesus Christ,

Eph 3:10
to the intent, that now unto the rulers and powers in heaven might be known by the congregation the manyfold wisdom of God,

Eph 3:11
according to that eternal purpose, which he purposed in Christ Iesu our Lord,

Eph 3:12
by whom we are bold to draw nye in that trust, which we have by faith on him.

Eph 3:13
Wherefore I desire, that ye faint not because of mine tribulations which I suffer for you: which is your praise.

Eph 3:14
For this cause I bow my knees unto the father of our Lord Iesus Christ,

Eph 3:15
which is father over all that is called father In heaven and in earth, that he would grant you according to the riches of his glory,

Eph 3:16
that ye may be strengthened with might by his spirit in the inner man,

Eph 3:17
that Christ may dwell in your hearts by faith, that ye being rooted and grounded in love,

Eph 3:18
might be able to comprehend with all saints, what is that breadth and length, depth and height:

Eph 3:19
and to know what is the love of Christ, which love passeth knowledge: that ye might be fulfilled with all manner of fullness which cometh of God.

Eph 3:20
Unto him that is able to do exceeding abundantly, above all that we ask or think, according to the power that worketh in us,

Eph 3:21
be praise in the congregation by Iesus Christ, thorow out all generations from time to time. Amen.

Eph 4:1
I therefore which am in bonds for the Lord's sake exhort you, that ye walk worthy of the vocation wherewith ye are called,

Eph 4:2
in all humbleness of mind, and meekness, and long suffering, forbearing one another thorow love,

Eph 4:3
and that ye be diligent to keep the unity of the spirit in the bond of peace,

Eph 4:4
being one body, and one spirit, even as ye are called in one hope of your calling.

Eph 4:5
Let there be but one Lord, one faith, one baptism:

Eph 4:6
one God and father of all, which is above all, thorow all, and in us all.

Eph 4:7
Unto every one of us is given grace according to the measure of the gift of Christ.

Eph 4:8
Wherefore he saith: He is gone up on high, and hath led captivity captive, and hath given gifts unto men.

Eph 4:9
That he ascended: what meaneth it, but that he also descended first into the lowest parts of the earth?

Eph 4:10
He that descended, is even the same also that ascended up, even above all heavens, to fulfil all things.

Eph 4:11
And the very same, made some Apostles, some prophets, some Evangelists, some Shepherds, some Teachers:

Eph 4:12
that the saints might have all things necessary to work and minister withall, to the edifying of the body of Christ,

Eph 4:13
till we everyeachone (in the unity of faith, and knowledge of the son of God) grow up unto a perfect man, after the measure of age which is in the fullness of Christ:

Eph 4:14
That we henceforth be no more children wavering and carried with every wind of doctrine, by the wiliness of men and craftiness, whereby they lay a wait for us to deceive us.

Eph 4:15
But let us follow the truth in love, and in all things grow in him which is the head, that is to say Christ,

Eph 4:16
in whom all the body is coupled and knit together, in every joint, wherewith one ministereth to another (according to the operation as every part hath his measure) and increaseth the body, unto the edifying of itself in love.

Eph 4:17
This I say herefore, and testify in the Lord, that ye henceforth walk not as other gentiles walk, in vanities of their mind,

Eph 4:18
blinded in their understanding, being strangers from the life which is in God, thorow the ignorancy that is in them, because of the blindness of their hearts:

Eph 4:19
which being past repentance have given themselves unto wantonness, to work all manner of uncleanness even with greediness.

Eph 4:20
But ye have not so learned Christ,

Eph 4:21
If so be ye have heard of him, and are taught in him, even as the truth is in Iesu:

Eph 4:22
so then as concerning the conversation in time past, lay from you that old man, which is corrupt thorow the deceivable lusts,

Eph 4:23
and be ye renewed in the spirit of your minds,

Eph 4:24
and put on that new man, which after a godly wise, is shapen in righteousness, and true holiness.

Eph 4:25
Wherefore put away lying, and speak every man truth unto his neighbor, for as much as we are members one of another.

Eph 4:26
Be angry, but sin not: let not the son go down upon your wrath,

Eph 4:27
give no place unto the backbiter,

Eph 4:28
let him that stole steal no more, but let him rather labour with his hands some good thing, that he may have to give unto him that needeth.

Eph 4:29
